title: AdornedSpectrumImage
text:
Handle to the spectrum image result existing on the server.

Properties

Methods

save()

Transfers the spectrum image file to the client and saves it to disk.

Remarks

This object represents a spectrum image file that resides on the MPC disk. It can be sent to the client over the network
 using the
save()
 method.

The file is valid on the MPC for about 24 hours and is then removed.

title: AdornedSpectrumImage.save
text:
.

Transfers the spectrum image file to the client and saves it to disk.

Syntax

save(path)

Parameters

path

str

Path of the file to be saved.

Remarks

Transfers the acquired spectrum image to the client and saves it to the specified path. The only supported file extension is *.emd.

title: ApertureMechanism.aperture
text:
.

Gets or sets the selected aperture on this mechanism.

Data type

Aperture

Remarks

An aperture has a pre-defined position where it is located. This location can be modified by changing the value
 of the position property with the given aperture selected. You can change the selected aperture only when the aperture mechanism is enabled.
 Setting the aperture property will insert the aperture mechanism that contains it into the column (if retracted). None is returned if no aperture is selected.

Examples

Select the second aperture on the SA aperture mechanism and inspect its name, type and diameter:

# Select the second aperture
 apertures = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.apertures
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.aperture = apertures[1]

# Read and print aperture properties
 aperture = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.aperture
 print("Name: ", aperture.name)
 print("Type: ", aperture.type)
 print("Diameter:", aperture.diameter)

See also

ApertureMechanism.apertures

ApertureMechanism.position

title: ApertureMechanism
text:
Contains properties and enables control of an aperture mechanism.

Properties

aperture

Gets or sets the selected aperture on this mechanism.

apertures

[Read only]
 Returns available apertures on this mechanism.

insertion_state

[Read only]
 The insertion state of the aperture mechanism. Maps to
ApertureMechanismInsertionState
 enumeration.

is_enabled

[Read only]
 Whether this aperture mechanism is currently enabled.

is_retractable

[Read only]
 Whether this aperture mechanism is a retractable device.

position

Gets or sets the X and Y position of the selected aperture. 2D vector in meters (x, y).

Methods

disable()

Disables this aperture mechanism.

enable()

Enables this aperture mechanism.

insert()

Inserts this aperture mechanism.

reset_positions()

Resets positions of all apertures on this mechanism to default values from microscope alignment.

retract()

Retracts this aperture mechanism.

Remarks

An aperture mechanism is a representation of a physical motorized device that contains individual
apertures
 (holes punched in a thin metal sheet).
 If the mechanism is retractable, it can be inserted into the column and retracted. Non-retractable mechanisms are always inserted.

The
position
 property positions the aperture mechanism to a new location. This new location is associated with the currently selected

aperture
 and can be recovered by re-selecting the
aperture
.
 The position property can therefore be thought of as a preset for the currently selected aperture.

The
reset_positions()
 method restores these presets for all apertures in a mechanism to their default values. A given position cannot be reset individually.

See
aperture_mechanisms
 and

get_mechanism
 for information on how to create aperture mechanism dynamic objects.

See also

optics.aperture_mechanisms

title: ApertureMechanism.apertures
text:
.

Returns available apertures on this mechanism.

Data type

[Read only]
 List[
Aperture
]

Examples

Enumerate available apertures on the C1 aperture mechanism:

apertures = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.apertures

for aperture in apertures:
 print("Type:", aperture.type)
 print("Diameter:", aperture.diameter)

See also

ApertureMechanism.aperture

title: ApertureMechanism.disable
text:
.

Disables this aperture mechanism.

Syntax

disable()

Remarks

If the aperture mechanism is already disabled, does nothing.

Examples

Disable the C1 aperture mechanism and check the status:

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.disable()
 print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.is_enabled)

See also

ApertureMechanism.enable()

ApertureMechanism.is_enabled

title: ApertureMechanism.enable
text:
.

Enables this aperture mechanism.

Syntax

enable()

Remarks

If the aperture mechanism is already enabled, does nothing.

Examples

Enable the objective aperture mechanism and check the status:

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.objective.enable()
 print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.objective.is_enabled)

See also

ApertureMechanism.disable()

ApertureMechanism.is_enabled

title: ApertureMechanism.insert
text:
.

Inserts this aperture mechanism.

Syntax

insert()

Remarks

When you insert the aperture mechanism, an aperture that was used before retraction is automatically selected.
 If the mechanism is inserted for the first time, the last aperture is selected.

The mechanism must be enabled and retractable to allow insertion.

Examples

Insert the SA aperture mechanism:

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.insert()

Inserts the C1 aperture mechanism if it is retractable:

if microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.is_retractable:
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.insert()
 print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.insertion_state)
 else:
 print("Aperture mechanism is not retractable.")

See also

ApertureMechanism.retract()

insertion_state

ApertureMechanism.enable()

ApertureMechanism.is_retractable

title: ApertureMechanism.insertion_state
text:
.

The insertion state of the aperture mechanism. Maps to
ApertureMechanismInsertionState
 enumeration.

Data type

[Read only]
 str

Remarks

Mechanism must be enabled to get the insertion state.

See also

ApertureMechanism.retract()

ApertureMechanism.insert()

insertion_state

title: ApertureMechanism.is_enabled
text:
.

Whether this aperture mechanism is currently enabled.

Data type

[Read only]
 bool

Examples

Find out if the C2 aperture mechanism is enabled:

print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C2.is_enabled)

Disable and enable the SA aperture mechanism and print the current state:

print("SA is enabled:", microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.is_enabled)

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.disable()
 print("SA is enabled:", microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.is_enabled)

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.enable()
 print("SA is enabled:", microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.is_enabled)

See also

ApertureMechanism.enable()

ApertureMechanism.disable()

title: ApertureMechanism.is_retractable
text:
.

Whether this aperture mechanism is a retractable device.

Data type

[Read only]
 bool

Examples

Find out whether the SA aperture mechanism is retractable:

print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.is_retractable)

See also

ApertureMechanism.retract()

ApertureMechanism.insert()

insertion_state

title: ApertureMechanism.position
text:
.

Gets or sets the X and Y position of the selected aperture. 2D vector in meters (x, y).

Data type

Get:
Point
Set:
Point
 | list | tuple

Remarks

Each aperture has a default position that is determined during microscope alignment.
 Use
reset_positions()
 to restore positions to default values or to recover from an invalid aperture position.

When setting the value, the coordinates of the given point can be None. That means the position of this axis will remain the same. Getting the position
 can also return None, meaning that no aperture is currently selected.

Mechanism must be enabled and inserted to set or get the position.

Examples

Find out current position of the selected aperture in the C3 mechanism. C3 is assumed to be inserted and enabled.

position = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position
 print(position)

Move selected aperture by 1Âµm in X:

# Get current position
 old_position = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position
 print(old_position)

# Move by 1um in X
 new_position = Point(old_position.x + 1e-6, old_position.y)
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position = new_position

# Move by 1um in Y (value of X is None, that means no movement on this axis)
 new_position = Point(y=old_position.y + 1e-6)
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position = new_position

# Print new position
 print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position)

A list or tuple can also be used to change the position:

# Using a list to modify the position
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position = [2e-6, 2e-6]

# Using a tuple to modify the position
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position = (1e-6, 1e-6)

See also

ApertureMechanism.reset_positions()

ApertureMechanism.enable()

title: ApertureMechanism.reset_positions
text:
.

Resets positions of all apertures on this mechanism to default values from microscope alignment.

Syntax

reset_positions()

Remarks

Mechanism must be enabled to reset the position.
reset_positions
 can be used to recover the aperture from an invalid position.

Examples

# Move selected aperture to some position
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position = Point(0.002, 0.002)
 print("Selected aperture position:", microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position)

# Reset positions of all apertures to defaults
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.reset_positions()

# Print the selected aperture position again
 print("Selected aperture position:", microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C3.position)

See also

ApertureMechanism.enable()

title: ApertureMechanism.retract
text:
.

Retracts this aperture mechanism.

Syntax

retract()

Remarks

No aperture is selected after the aperture mechanism is retracted. Mechanism must be enabled and retractable to retract it.

Examples

Retract the SA aperture mechanism:

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.retract()

Retracts aperture mechanism if it is retractable:

if microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.is_retractable:
 microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.retract()
 print(microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.C1.insertion_state)
 else:
 print("Aperture mechanism is not retractable.")

See also

ApertureMechanism.insert()

insertion_state

ApertureMechanism.enable()

ApertureMechanism.is_retractable

title: BiPrism
text:
Contains properties and enables control of a bi-prism.

Properties

is_enabled

[Read only]
 Whether the bi-prism is currently enabled.

name

[Read only]
 The name of the bi-prism.

rotation

[Read only]
 The rotation control of the bi-prism.

voltage

[Read only]
 The voltage control of the bi-prism.

Methods

recover()

Recover the bi-prism from error state.

Remarks

Enabling bi-prism

To enable the bi-prism, holography mode
is_holography_mode_on
 has to be enabled and bi-prism aperture has to be set as
aperture
 in desired
ApertureMechanism
 and inserted.

Examples

Setting the rotation by degrees

import math
 biprism.rotation.set(math.radians(45))

Setting the max voltage

biprism.voltage.value = biprism.voltage.limits.max

Selecting bi-prism aperture enables control of bi-prism

microscope.optics.is_holography_mode_on = True

aperture_mechanism = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.get_mechanism("C3")

for aperture in aperture_mechanism.apertures:
 if aperture.type == ApertureType.BI_PRISM:
 aperture_mechanism.aperture = aperture

is_enabled = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.bi_prisms.get_bi_prism("C3").is_enabled
 print(f"Bi-prism is enabled: {is_enabled}")

title: BiPrismRotation
text:
Contains properties and enables control of a bi-prism rotation.

Properties

is_available

[Read only]
 Whether the bi-prism is motorized and can be rotated.

limits

[Read only]
 The range of valid rotation values.

value

[Read only]
 The rotation of the bi-prism in radians.

Methods

rotate()

Rotates the bi-prism to a given angle in radians.

title: CameraDetector
text:
Contains properties of a camera detector.

Properties

Methods

Remarks

Camera detectors are uniquely identifiable by name. The enumeration
CameraType
 contains all supported scanning detectors.

See also

detectors.get_camera_detector()

insert_context()

retract_context()

title: CameraDetector.exposure_time_limits
text:
.

Minimum and maximum exposure times in seconds. Flucam only.

Data type

[Read only]

Limits

Remarks

This property returns valid results only for Flucam cameras. For all other cameras it return an exception.

title: CameraDetector.get_supported_image_sizes
text:
.

Returns the list of supported image sizes.

Syntax

get_supported_image_sizes()

Return value

Remarks

Returns a list of supported image sizes, broken down into the square size of the image in pixels and the fixed readout area. These settings can be used for all standard camera acquisitions.
 The list is ordered by image size, starting with the smallest.

Examples

The example shows how the function can be used to acquire all supported sizes from the camera:

camera = self.detectors.get_camera_detector(CameraType.BM_CETA)

# Run acquisition for each supported image size
 for image_size in camera.get_supported_image_sizes():
 # Create acquisition settings
 settings = CameraAcquisitionSettings(
 camera.name,
 image_size.size,
 exposure_time=1e-6,
 fixed_readout_area=image_size.fixed_readout_area)

# Acquire image
 image = self.acquisition.acquire_camera_image_advanced(settings)

See also

acquire_camera_image()

acquire_camera_image_advanced()

acquire_camera_series_advanced()

title: DetectorSegment
text:
Represents a single segment on a
ScanningDetector
.

Properties

detector_name

[Read only]
 Name of the detector containing this segment. Uses values from
DetectorType
.

gain

The gain of the segment. The unit depends on the detector type.

is_enabled

Whether this segment is currently enabled.

name

[Read only]
 Name of the segment. Uses values from
DetectorSegmentType
.

offset

The offset of the segment. The unit depends on the detector type.

title: DetectorSegment.gain
text:
.

The gain of the segment. The unit depends on the detector type.

Data type

float

Remarks

The value affects the gain of the entire detector and should be reset after the work with the segment is finished.

See also

gain

title: DetectorSegment.offset
text:
.

The offset of the segment. The unit depends on the detector type.

Data type

float

Remarks

The value affects the offset of the entire detector and should be reset after the work with the segment is finished.

See also

offset

title: EdsDetector
text:
Contains properties and enables control of a EDS detector.

Properties

Methods

Remarks

EDS detectors are uniquely identifiable by name. The enumeration
EdsDetectorType
 contains all supported EDS detectors.

Examples

The following example shows how to obtain and work with an EDS detector:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Get a list of segments on the detector and inspect their names
 segments = detector.get_segments() # 4 objects returned
 for segment in segments:
 print(segment.name)

# Insert the detector (if already inserted, do nothing)
 detector.insert()
 print(detector.insertion_state)

# Retract the detector (if already retracted, do nothing)
 detector.retract()
 print(detector.insertion_state)

See also

detectors.get_eds_detector()

title: EdsDetector.get_enabled_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of enabled segments.

Syntax

get_enabled_segments()

Return value

Remarks

This function can be used to create a list of segments for the spectrum acquisition function
acquire_spectrum()
.
 after the segments have been selected for acquisition by calling
EdsDetector.set_enabled_segments()
.

Examples

Enable all segments on SuperX detector:

# Enable all segments on the SuperX detector (4 segments in total)
 super_x = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)
 super_x.set_enabled_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.ALL)

# 4 segments
 enabled_segments = super_x.get_enabled_segments()

See also

set_enabled_segments()

title: EdsDetector.get_segment
text:
.

Returns an object representing one detector segment. Enumeration
EdsDetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segment(segment_name)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Only single segment names are valid (i.e.
ALL

is not allowed).

See also

EdsDetector.get_segments()

title: EdsDetector.get_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of segments by their names. By default returns all available segments. Enumeration
EdsDetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segments()
get_segments(segment_names)

Parameters

segment_names

str | List[str]

Return value

Remarks

The parameter-less function returns all segments that are on the detector.

Segment name or a list of segment names can be passed, group segments are 'unpacked' and translated into their members
 (e.g.
ALL
 is translated into all available segments).
 The objects are returned in the same order as the names specified in the input list.

Examples

Enumerate all segments on the SuperX detector:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Get a list of segments on the detector and inspect their names
 segments = detector.get_segments() # 4 objects returned

# Same as
 # segments = detector.get_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.ALL)

for segment in segments:
 print(segment.name)

Get specified segments of the SuperX detector:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Get a list of specific segments
 segments = detector.get_segments([EdsDetectorType.SEGMENT1, EdsDetectorType.SEGMENT2]) # 2 objects returned

# Same as
 # inner_ring_segments = detector.get_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

for segment in inner_ring_segments:
 print(segment.name)

See also

EdsDetector.get_segment()

EdsDetectorSegmentType

title: EdsDetector.reset_segments
text:
.

Disables all segments.

Syntax

reset_segments()

Examples

The following example shows how to reset the segments of a DF-S detector:

detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 detector.reset_segments()

See also

is_enabled

title: EdsDetector.set_enabled_segments
text:
.

Enables a given segment and disables all others. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
EdsDetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_enabled_segments(segment_name)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

Remarks

The function can act on a single segment or multiple segments. It accepts the input parameter in several forms:

A string representing a single segment, such as
"Segment1"
.

A string representing a group of segments, e.g.
"All"
.

A list of segment names, e.g.
["Segment1", "Segment2"]
.

In any case, it is recommended to use the
EdsDetectorSegmentType

enumeration instead of strings to avoid typos.

Examples

The following examples show several ways in which segments can be enabled:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Enable all segments
 detector.set_enabled_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.ALL)

# Enable a single segment, disable all others
 detector.set_enabled_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)

# Enable the first two segments, disable all others
 detector.set_enabled_segments([EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1, EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT2])

It is also possible to access the
is_enabled
 property directly on the segment object.
 Note that this approach doesn't allow for batch processing (acting on multiple segments at once).

# Get the SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Enable its first segment
 segment1 = detector.get_segment(EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)
 segment1.is_enabled = True

See also

EdsDetectorSegment.is_enabled

title: EelsDetector
text:
Contains properties of an EELS detector.

Properties

display_name

[Read only]
 The commercial name of the detector.

maximum_bin_count

[Read only]
 Returns the maximum number of bins supported by the detector.

name

[Read only]
 The identifier of the detector.

Examples

The following example shows how get and work with an EELS detector:

# Get the Zebra detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eels_detector(EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA)

# Print detector name
 print(detector.name)

# Print detector display name
 print(detector.display_name)

# Inspect detector state and properties
 print(detector.maximum_bin_count)

title: Dynamic objects
text:
Dynamic objects

Dynamic objects are objects that live on the server and have only a thin representation on the client. This means that the client can work with the dynamic object as if it were a simple data structure,
 but all calls are resolved by the server. Dynamic objects are often used to model and encapsulate more complex functionality (e.g. detectors, aperture mechanisms).

title: Lens
text:
Contains properties of a lens.

Properties

limits_raw

[Read only]
 Minimum and maximum raw output value.

name

[Read only]
 Name of the Lens. Uses values from
LensType
.

value

Output value as a ratio of the raw output and the limit value.

value_raw

Raw output as a 2D vector in optical units (x, y).

Remarks

The excitation of each lens can be controlled using two different properties.

The first one is a ratio
value
. Its allowed range is -1 to 1 and corresponds to the
limits_raw
 min to max values. The value describes the degree to which the lens is excited,
 with a value of -1 indicating that the lens is excited to the
limits_raw
.min. Value of 0 indicates that the lens is not excited at
 all and value of 1 indicates excitation to the
limits_raw
.max.

The second property to control the lens excitation is
value_raw
 measured in optical units. The allowed range is in this case defined by

limits_raw
 property.

Both
value
 and
value_raw
 properties are dependent on each other, so updating one of them will result in a corresponding update to the other.

Raw value properties (
value_raw
,
limits_raw
) are not available for the
X
 lens type.
 Instead, specific alignments for the X lens type are provided (see
x alignment page
).

About the Free Control mode

Free control mode functionality is licensed under separate Free Control feature license. Accessing the functionality without the proper license will result in an error.

Adjusting any lens value triggers the system to enter free control mode. In this mode, the mathematical model governing the
 optics is deactivated, allowing users direct control over all lenses.
 The accuracy of the optics model relies on calibrations to assess the system's state. Directly altering any lens parameter
 renders the calibrations ineffective in predicting the model's state. Once the system transitions to free control mode,
 the values derived from the optical model are no longer accurate (such as optical modes, magnification, camera length, etc.).

Storing the state of the optical model before entering free control mode is possible through PEOUI with FEG registers and alignments.

The system reverts to calibrated values when the state of the optical model changes, which can occur due to any currently active
 application on the microscope. In AutoScript, modifying the following parameters deactivates free control mode:

Optical mode

Probe mode

Projector mode

Objective lens mode

Illumination mode

Is EFTEM on

Magnification

Camera length

Simply reading the values does not disable free control mode; however, as mentioned earlier, the values may be inaccurate.
 Free control mode deactivates even if the same value is set.

Examples

# retrieve the C1 lens
 lens = microscope.optics.lenses.get_lens(LensType.C1)

# read the value_raw limits
 print(lens.limits_raw)

# set the value_raw property
 lens.value_raw = 0.125

# read both value and value_raw
 print(lens.value)
 print(lens.value_raw)

See also

lenses.get_available()

lenses.get_lens()

LensType

title: ScanningDetector.get_enabled_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of enabled segments.

Syntax

get_enabled_segments()

Return value

Remarks

This function can be used to create a list of segments for the image acquisition function

acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images()

after the segments have been selected for acquisition by calling
ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()
.

The resulting list can be combined with similar lists obtained from other detectors.

Examples

Enable inner ring segments on BF-S and DF-S detectors and combine them to a single list:

# Enable inner ring segments on the BF-S detector (4 segments in total)
 bf_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 bf_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

# Enable inner ring segments on the DF-S detector (4 segments in total)
 df_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 df_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

# 4 + 4 segments
 enabled_segments = bf_s.get_enabled_segments() + df_s.get_enabled_segments()

Enabling segments on the DF4 detector:

# Enable SEGMENT1 detector
 df4 = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF4)
 df4.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)

# Enabling INNER_RING or INNER1 segments fails, DF4 detectors don't have rings
 # df4.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)
 # df4.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER1)

See also

ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()

title: ScanningDetector.get_segment
text:
.

Returns an object representing one detector segment. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segment(segment_name)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Only single segment names are valid (i.e.
INNER_RING
,

ALL
 etc. are not allowed).

See also

ScanningDetector.get_segments()

title: ScanningDetector.get_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of segments by their names. By default returns all available segments. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segments()
get_segments(segment_names)

Parameters

segment_names

str | List[str]

Return value

Remarks

The parameter-less function returns all segments that are on the detector.

Segment name or a list of segment names can be passed, group segments are 'unpacked' and translated into their members
 (e.g.
ALL
 is translated into all available segments).
 The objects are returned in the same order as the names specified in the input list.

Examples

Enumerate all segments on the DF-S detector:

# Get DF-S detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)

# Get a list of segments on the detector and inspect their names
 segments = detector.get_segments() # 8 objects returned

# Same as
 # segments = detector.get_segments(DetectorSegmentType.ALL)

for segment in segments:
 print(segment.name)

Get segments that form the inner ring of DF-S:

# Get DF-S detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)

# Get inner ring segments
 inner_ring_segments = detector.get_segments(
 [DetectorSegmentType.INNER1, DetectorSegmentType.INNER2,
 DetectorSegmentType.INNER3, DetectorSegmentType.INNER4]) # 4 objects returned

# Same as
 # inner_ring_segments = detector.get_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

for segment in inner_ring_segments:
 print(segment.name)

See also

ScanningDetector.get_segment()

DetectorSegmentType

title: ScanningDetector.relative_offset
text:
.

Offset value relative to its range. The range is from 0 to 1.

Data type

float

Remarks

The minimum offset value corresponds to 0, the maximum to 1. For detectors
BF_S
 and

DF_S
 the transformation is not linear but logarithmic.

See also

offset

offset_limits

title: ScanningDetector
text:
Contains properties and enables control of a scanning (STEM) detector.

Properties

collection_angle_limits

[Read only]
 The range of the collection angles (annular detectors) in radians.

display_name

[Read only]
 The commercial name of the detector.

gain

The gain of the detector. The unit depends on the detector type.

gain_limits

[Read only]
 The range of valid gain values. The unit depends on the detector type.

insertion_state

[Read only]
 The insertion state of the detector. Maps to
DetectorInsertionState
 enumeration.

is_insertable

[Read only]
 Whether the detector can be inserted/retracted.

name

[Read only]
 The identifier of the detector.

offset

The offset of the detector. The unit depends on the detector type.

offset_limits

[Read only]
 The range of valid offset values. The unit depends on the detector type.

relative_gain

Gain value relative to its range. The range is from 0 to 1.

relative_offset

Offset value relative to its range. The range is from 0 to 1.

Methods

Remarks

Scanning detectors are uniquely identifiable by name. The enumeration
DetectorType
 contains all supported scanning detectors.

Examples

The following example shows how to obtain and work with the BF-S detector and it's first inner segment:

detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 print(detector.name)
 print(detector.insertion_state)

segment = detector.get_segment(DetectorSegmentType.INNER1)
 print(segment.detector_name)
 print(segment.name)
 print(segment.is_enabled)
 print(segment.gain)
 print(segment.offset)

See also

detectors.get_scanning_detector()

title: ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments
text:
.

Enables a given segment and disables all others. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_enabled_segments(segment_name)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

Remarks

The function can act on a single segment or multiple segments. It accepts the input parameter in several forms:

A string representing a single segment, such as
"Inner1"
 or
"Segment1"
.

A string representing a group of segments, e.g.
"InnerRing"
 or
"All"
.

A list of segment names, e.g.
["Inner1", "Inner2"]
 or
["Segment1", "Segment2"]
.

In any case, it is recommended to use the
DetectorSegmentType

enumeration instead of strings to avoid typos.

Examples

The following examples show several ways in which segments can be enabled:

# Get BF-S detector object.
 # BF-S is an 8-segment detector divided into two rings, inner and outer. Both rings have 4 segments.
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)

# Enable all segments
 detector.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.ALL)

# Enable a single segment, disable all others
 detector.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER1)

# Enable the first two segments of the inner ring, disable all others
 detector.set_enabled_segments([DetectorSegmentType.INNER1, DetectorSegmentType.INNER2])

# Enable inner ring (INNER1, INNER2, INNER3 and INNER4) and disable all other segments (OUTER_RING).
 detector.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

The function is also applicable to detectors without segments.
 Such detectors are assumed to have a virtual segment
SINGLE
.
 Enabling this segment is necessary if you want to include the detector in the segment acquisition task with other detectors,
 e.g. acquire images from DF-S segments and HAADF detector simultaneously.

# Get the HAADF detector object
 haadf = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.HAADF)

# Enable its virtual segment "Single"
 haadf.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.SINGLE)

# Get the DF-S detector object and enable its outer ring segments
 df_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 df_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING)

# Combine all enabled segments into one list (len=5)
 segments = df_s.get_enabled_segments() + haadf.get_enabled_segments()

# Acquire images from all segments simultaneously
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(segments, 1024, 25e-9)

# 5 images returned

It is also possible to access the
is_enabled
 property directly on the segment object.
 Note that this approach doesn't allow for batch processing (acting on multiple segments at once).

# Get the DF4 detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF4)

# Enable its first segment
 segment = detector.get_segment(DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)
 segment.is_enabled = True

See also

DetectorSegment.is_enabled

ScanningDetector.set_segment_gain()

ScanningDetector.set_segment_offset()

title: ScanningDetector.set_segment_gain
text:
.

Sets gain on a given segment. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_segment_gain(segment_name, value)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

value

float

Remarks

The function can act on a single segment or multiple segments. It accepts the input parameter in several forms:

A string representing a single segment, such as
"Inner1"
 or
"Segment1"
.

A string representing a group of segments, e.g.
"InnerRing"
 or
"All"
.

A list of segment names, e.g.
["Inner1", "Inner2"]
 or
["Segment1", "Segment2"]
.

In any case, it is recommended to use the
DetectorSegmentType

enumeration instead of strings to avoid typos.

Examples

The following examples show several ways of setting the segment gain:

# Get the BF-S detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)

# Set gain to value 5 on all segments
 detector.set_segment_gain(DetectorSegmentType.ALL, 5)

# Set gain to value 5 on outer ring segments; do not change gain of other segments
 detector.set_segment_gain(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING, 5)

# Set gain to value 5 on explicitly listed segments; do not change gain of other segments
 detector.set_segment_gain([DetectorSegmentType.INNER1, DetectorSegmentType.OUTER1], 5)

It is also possible to access the
gain
 property directly on the segment object.

Note that this approach doesn't allow for batch processing (acting on multiple segments at once).

# Get the DF4 detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF4)

# Set the first segment gain
 segment = detector.get_segment(DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)
 segment.gain = 5

See also

DetectorSegment.gain

ScanningDetector.set_segment_offset()

ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()

title: ScanningDetector.set_segment_offset
text:
.

Sets offset on a given segment. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_segment_offset(segment_name, value)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

value

float

Remarks

The function can act on a single segment or multiple segments. It accepts the input parameter in several forms:

A string representing a single segment, such as
"Inner1"
 or
"Segment1"
.

A string representing a group of segments, e.g.
"InnerRing"
 or
"All"
.

A list of segment names, e.g.
["Inner1", "Inner2"]
 or
["Segment1", "Segment2"]
.

In any case, it is recommended to use the
DetectorSegmentType

enumeration instead of strings to avoid typos.

Examples

The following examples show several ways of setting the segment offset:

# Get the BF-S detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)

# Set offset to a specified value on all segments
 detector.set_segment_offset(DetectorSegmentType.ALL, -1e-5)

# Set offset to a specified value on the four outer ring segments; do not change other segments
 detector.set_segment_offset(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING, -1e-5)

# Set offset to a specified value on the explicitly listed segmentsl do not change other segments
 detector.set_segment_offset([DetectorSegmentType.INNER1, DetectorSegmentType.OUTER1], -1e-5)

It is also possible to access the
offset
 property directly on the segment object.

Note that this approach doesn't allow for batch processing (acting on multiple segments at once).

# Get the DF4 detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF4)

# Set the first segment offset
 segment = detector.get_segment(DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)
 segment.offset = -1e-5

See also

DetectorSegment.offset

ScanningDetector.set_segment_gain()

ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()

title: AdornedImage
text:
Contains microscope image data along with metadata describing the state of the microscope under which the image was acquired.

Items

width

[Read only]
 int

The width of the image in pixels.

height

[Read only]
 int

The height of the image in pixels.

bit_depth

[Read only]
 int

Bit depth of the image data.

metadata

[Optional]

AdornedImageMetadata

Metadata containing information about the system setup at the time the image was captured.

data

[Read only]
 Numpy.ndarray

The data arranged either in 2D (for grayscale images) or 3D (for RGB images) numpy array.

encoding

[Read only]
 int

Encoding of the image. To explain this property use enumeration
ImageDataEncoding
.

checksum

[Read only]
 int

The checksum of the raw data.

thumbnail

[Read only]

AdornedImage

The thumbnail of the original image.

Methods

load()

Loads an image from a file. Supported formats: tiff, png, bmp.

save()

Saves the image to the specified path. Supported formats: tiff, png, bmp, gif.

Remarks

The structure contains both the numpy array representing the image and the metadata.
 It is used as a result by most acquisition functions, but can also be created manually by
 specifying a numpy array and a metadata object (both arguments are optional).
 The object construction uses deep copy internally for the metadata object to avoid overwriting them later.
 This way, multiple images do not share the same metadata object.

Metadata

When AutoScript loads a file from disk using the
load()
 function, the existing EXIF
 metadata is lost during the subsequent
save()
. AutoScript uses its own metadata structure,
 which is employed by most Thermo Fisher applications; this structure is defined in
AdornedImageMetadata
.

Supported formats

The following table explains the supported bit depths and encoding combinations. Note that this table refers
 to the default and recommended TIFF image format. Other formats may contain additional unsupported combinations.
 See
save
 and
load
 pages for more information.

UNSIGNED

SIGNED

RGB

BGR

8

Supported

-

-

-

16

Supported

Partially supported *

-

-

24

-

-

Supported (8 bits per channel)

Supported (8 bits per channel)

32

-

Supported

-

-

* AutoScript does not support
save
 and
load
 operations with signed 16-bit
 grayscale images. As a workaround, these images are converted to int32.

Examples

The following example shows how to calculate the mean of the image (using the numpy package):

import numpy as np
 print(np.mean(image.data))

The next example shows how to load a TIFF file from the disk:

image = AdornedImage.load("c:\\image.tiff")

The next example shows how to create an empty image with a numpy array and a metadata object:

# Creates a numpy array filled with zeroes
 numpy_array = numpy.full(shape=(1024, 1024), fill_value=0, dtype=numpy.uint16)

# Creates a blank metadata object
 metadata = AdornedImageMetadata()

# Creates an empty image
 image = AdornedImage(numpy_array, metadata)

# Created metadata object and the image metadata object are different
 # (a deep copy was performed to avoid overwriting data)
 assert id(metadata) != id(image.metadata)

See also

acquisition

AdornedImageMetadata

title: AdornedImage.load
text:
.

Loads an image from a file. Supported formats: tiff, png, bmp.

Syntax

load(path)

Parameters

path

File path from which to load the image.

Return value

Remarks

TIFF
 is a preferred image format because it allows metadata to be stored with the image.
 However, the function can also read
BMP
 and
PNG
 image formats.
 For those two formats, the member
metadata
 is left uninitialized.

PNG images with the 16-bit bit depth are loaded as 32 bit.

AutoScript needs read access for the file to open it. All locks are released after load method finishes (no resource release or close required).

Examples

Load TIFF file from disk:

image = AdornedImage.load("c:\\image.tiff")

See also

AdornedImageMetadata

save()

title: AdornedImage.save
text:
.

Saves the image to the specified path. Supported formats: tiff, png, bmp, gif.

Syntax

save(path)

Parameters

path

Path of the file to be saved.

Remarks

The path extension determines which image format to use. If the file has no extension,
TIFF
 is used by default.
 An error will be raised if an unsupported extension is used.
TIFF
 is a preferred image format because it allows
 metadata to be stored with the image.

If
BMP
 or
GIF
 format is used, the image is first normalized and converted to 8-bit RGB format (if not already).
 If the
PNG
 format is used, 32-bit images are converted to 16-bit when saved (with data loss!). These operations
 have no effect on the objects in memory, only on the images stored on disk.

TIFF
 is considered a raw data format, meaning no automatic corrections are applied to the image. If the image contrast is too low,
 you must explicitly call the
stretch_histogram
 function before saving the image.

Examples

The following example shows different ways to save the image to disk:

# Load an image from disk
 image = AdornedImage.load(r"c:\image.tiff")

# Resave the image in tiff format
 image.save(r"c:\AutoScript images\image")
 image.save(r"c:\AutoScript images\image2.tiff")

# Save the image in png format
 image.save(r"c:\AutoScript images\image.png")

# Save the image in bitmap format
 image.save(r"c:\AutoScript images\image.bmp")

# Save the image in gif format
 image.save(r"c:\AutoScript images\image.gif")

See also

load()

stretch_histogram()

title: AdornedImage.thumbnail
text:
.

The thumbnail of the original image.

Data type

[Read only]

AdornedImage

Remarks

The thumbnail is recreated each time the property is accessed to account for possible changes to the image data.
 You may want to cache the thumbnail in a variable for performace critical applications.

The thumbnail is created by resizing the original image in each dimension to a maximum of 512 pixels, maintaining the aspect ratio where possible.
 The minimum size in each dimension is 1 pixel, so extremely large aspect ratios will distort the image.

title: AdornedSpectrum
text:
Contains EDS spectrum data and metadata.

Items

Remarks

The structure contains both the numpy array representing the spectrum and the metadata. It is used as a result by EDS acquisition functions,
 but can also be created manually by specifying a numpy array and a metadata object. Both arguments are optional, the numpy array
 must be one-dimensional and contain only unsigned integer values (see
SpectrumEncoding
 for all supported formats).

The object construction uses deep copy internally for the metadata object to avoid
 overwriting it later. This way, multiple spectra do not share the same metadata object.

Examples

The following example shows how to create an AdornedSpectrum object filled with random data:

import numpy as np

# Creates a random spectrum with 4096 bins (the array must be casted to unsigned integer type)
 empty_metadata = AdornedImageMetadata()
 random_spectrum = AdornedSpectrum(np.random.randint(low=0, high=1024, size=4096).astype(np.uint32), empty_metadata)

The next example shows how the interaction between AdornedSpectrum and the
HyperSpy package

might look like. See Python distribution for information about the HyperSpy installation.

import hyperspy.api as hs
 from matplotlib import pyplot as plot

signal = hs.signals.Signal1D(spectrum.data)
 signal.plot()
 plot.show()

See also

analysis

AdornedImageMetadata

title: EmdFile.close
text:
.

Closes the Emd file and releases all resources.

Syntax

close()

Remarks

After opening the file, AutoScript keeps it locked until the script ends or the file is closed.
 The
close()
 function can be called explicitly, or the
with
 statement can be used.

Examples

The following example shows implicit resource releasing using the
with
 statement:

# Open emd file and read all images
 with EmdFile.open(r"C:\emd_file.emd") as emd_file:
 images = emd_file.read_all_images()

# The file is closed automatically when the with statement ends

The next example demonstrates releasing the file explicitly:

# Open emd file and read all images
 emd_file = EmdFile.open(r"C:\emd_file.emd")
 images = emd_file.read_all_images()

# Close the file by calling the close method
 emd_file.close()

Attempting to read the file multiple times at once will raise an exception:

path = r"C:\emd_file.emd"

emd_file1 = EmdFile(path)
 emd_file2 = EmdFile(path) # Raises an error, emd_file1 is not closed

See also

EmdFile.open()

title: EmdFile.convert
text:
.

Converts an Emd experiment file to a new format version.

Syntax

convert(input_path, output_path)

Parameters

input_path

str

Path to the Emd file.

output_path

str

Path to the output Emd file.

Remarks

The function raises an error if the output file already exists.

Examples

The following example shows how to convert an EMD file to a new format and open it:

old_file = r"C:\old_emd_file.emd"
 new_file = r"C:\new_emd_file.emd"

EmdFile.convert(old_file, new_file)
 EmdFile.open(new_file)

See also

EmdFileFormat

open()

title: EmdFile.create
text:
.

Creates a new Emd experiment file.

Syntax

create(path, feature)

Parameters

path

str

Path to the Emd file.

feature

EmdStemFeature

STEM feature to be added to the Emd file.

Return value

EmdFile

Created Emd file as EmdFile object.

title: EmdFile
text:
Describes one Emd experiment file.

Methods

Remarks

The Emd file holds experiment data from Velox or Metrios applications. It has
*.emd
 file extension.
 AutoScript can read images from the file and convert them to
AdornedImage

objects.

Note that not all Emd file formats are supported.
 The format evolves with new versions of Velox and Metrios applications. It is being optimized for real-time data storage use cases,
 and its structure is being extended to accommodate new data types. In AutoScript, support for older Emd formats is limited.
 See the
Emd file format
 page or the
convert()

function for more information.

The current functionality is limited to reading and writing images and metadata from the Emd file. See snippets for examples of how to read spectra from the Emd file.

Examples

To open an Emd file you can use the static function
open()
 or a constructor. The two options are equivalent.

path = r"C:\emd_file.emd"

# Open emd file with open()
 emd_file = EmdFile.open(path)

# Open emd file with constructor
 emd_file = EmdFile(path)

See also

AdornedImage

EmdFile.open

title: EmdFile.open
text:
.

Opens an Emd experiment file.

Syntax

open(path)
open(path, read_only)

Parameters

path

str

Path to the Emd file.

read_only

bool

Indicates whether the file should be opened in read-only mode. False by default

Return value

EmdFile

Opened Emd file as EmdFile object.

Remarks

After opening the file, AutoScript will keep it locked until the script ends
 or until the file is closed explicitly. See
close()
 for more information.

See the
Emd file format
 page or the
convert()

function for more information about supported Emd file formats.

Examples

To open an Emd file you can use the static function
open()
 or a constructor.
 The two options are equivalent.

path = r"C:\emd_file.emd"

# Open emd file with open()
 emd_file = EmdFile.open(path)

# Open emd file with constructor
 emd_file = EmdFile(path)

To open an emd file in read-only mode to prevent accidental changes, use the read_only parameter.

path = r"C:\emd_file.emd"

# Open emd file in read-only mode with open()
 emd_file = EmdFile.open(path, read_only=True)

# Open emd file in read-only mode with constructor
 emd_file = EmdFile(path, read_only=True)

See also

EmdFile.close()

convert()

title: EmdFile.read_all_images
text:
.

Reads all images from the Emd file and converts them to
AdornedImage
.

Syntax

read_all_images()

Return value

Remarks

The method parses the Emd file and reads all images with
supported pixel formats
. Those are
uint8, uint16, int16, uint32 and int32
.

An exception is
not thrown
 if the file contains an unsupported image.

Examples

# Open emd file and read all images
 with EmdFile.open(r"C:\emd_file.emd") as emd_file:
 images = emd_file.read_all_images()

# Print xml metadata from all images
 for image in images:
 print(image.metadata.metadata_as_xml)

See also

EmdFile.open()

AdornedImage

title: EmdStemFeature
text:
Items

images

List[
AdornedImage
]

List of AdornedImage objects representing the frames acquired by the detector.

Remarks

Each
AdornedImage
 needs to satisfy metadata requirements for the EMD file to be valid.
 These metadata are already provided when acquiring images using the AutoScript functionality (e.g.,
acquire_stem_images
).
 So you can directly save the images to an EMD file.
 If any required metada are missing, exception is thrown when saving the EMD file.

Examples

To save EmdStemFeature to an EMD file, you can use the static function
.

stem_image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_image(DetectorType.HAADF, 1024, 1e-6)

# Create an emd file and save the image to it
 EmdFile.create('C:\\stem_image.emd', EmdStemFeature([stem_image])).close()

See also

EmdFile.close

EmdFile.create

AdornedImageMetadata

title: AdornedImageMetadata
text:
A structure representing metadata of
AdornedImage
.

Items

Methods

Remarks

The metadata format is designed to be flexible and extensible, supporting multiple types of systems (TEM, SEM, FIB, etc.).
 Its naming convention and overall design are intentionally generic to accommodate this variety. Extensibility is achieved
 through custom properties elements, which can contain any data (see
AdornedImageMetadataCustomProperty
),
 or custom sections, which can contain any XML element (see
AdornedImageMetadataCustomSection
).

AutoScript presents the metadata as an object tree, though the underlying format is XML. The XML format is used for serialization
 and saving metadata into an image, as well as for transferring metadata between client and server. Serialization can also be
 explicitly triggered by calling the
metadata_as_xml
 property.

Since the metadata format is used across multiple ThermoFisher systems and applications, AutoScript is not the owner of the format.
 This also explains slight inconsistencies in the naming conventions between the AutoScript API and the metadata format.
 Any AutoScript-specific metadata are saved in custom properties or custom sections.

Examples

All parts of metadata objects can be modified:

# Acquire new image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1)

# Modify image metadata object
 image.metadata.stage_settings.stage_position = AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(0, 0, 0, 0, 0)
 image.metadata.binary_result.image_size = Point(1024, 1024)
 image.metadata.acquisition.acquisition_date_time = "2021-08-03T20:00:00+01:00"

# Print modified metadata xml
 print(image.metadata.metadata_as_xml)

# Save image to tiff (with modified metadata)
 image.save(r"C:\image_with_modified_metadata.tiff")

Metadata objects can also be created from scratch:

metadata = AdornedImageMetadata()

core = AdornedImageMetadataCore()
 core.application_software = "AutoScript"
 core.application_software_version = "1.2"
 metadata.core = core

binary_result = AdornedImageMetadataBinaryResult(image_size=Point(1024, 1024), bits_per_pixel=16)
 metadata.binary_result = binary_result

# Print created metadata as xml
 print(metadata.metadata_as_xml)

See also

AdornedImage

title: AdornedImageMetadata.create_from_xml
text:
.

Creates new metadata structure from an XML string.

Syntax

create_from_xml(xml)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Tries to deserialize the given XML document into a metadata structure. If it fails, returns None.

title: AdornedImageMetadata.get_custom_property
text:
.

Retrieves custom metadata entries from the metadata object

Syntax

get_custom_property(name)
get_custom_property(name, scope)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Retrieves a custom metadata entry by its name from a specified scope. By default searches
 the empty string scope "" as this is where most custom metadata are saved to.
 If the entry does not exist, raises a ValueError.

Examples

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator

with beam_modulator_context(beam_modulator, duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6):
 # Acquire image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1)

# Get the duty cycle custom property from the default scope of the image metadata
 duty_cycle_property = image.metadata.get_custom_property("Optics.BeamModulator.DutyCycle")
 if duty_cycle_property.type == "double":
 print(f"Duty cycle: {duty_cycle_property.value}")
 duty_cycle = float(duty_cycle_property.value)

title: AdornedImageMetadataAcquisition.acquisition_date_time
text:
.

The time when the result was acquired and the acquisition was completed.

Data type

[Optional]
 str

Remarks

The dateTime should be specified in the following form:
YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.fff
.
 E.g.:
2021-03-29T16:11:28.000
. For more information see XML rules for xs:dateTime datatype.

title: AdornedImageMetadataAcquisition.acquisition_id
text:
.

Identifier of the acquisition event, which may have captured more than one result.

Data type

[Optional]
 str

Remarks

Acquisition id has to be in a guid format. A valid guid value should contain five groups of hexadecimal characters separated by hyphens.
 The form is 8-4-4-4-12 for a total of 36 characters. E.g.:
123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000.

title: AdornedImageMetadataAcquisition.acquisition_start_date_time
text:
.

The UTC time when the acquisition started.

title: AdornedImageMetadataCore.guid
text:
.

Unique identifier of the image.

Data type

[Optional]
 str

Remarks

A valid guid value should contain five groups of hexadecimal characters separated by hyphens.
 The form is 8-4-4-4-12 for a total of 36 characters. E.g.:
123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000.

text:
.

Data type

[Optional]
 bytes

Remarks

A valid checksum value should contain binary content encoded in hexadecimal.
 E.g.:
3f3c6d78206c657673726f693d6e3122302e20226e656f636964676e223d54552d4622383e3f.

 str

123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000.

title: AdornedImageMetadataScanningDetector
text:
Image metadata structure representing a scanning detector.

detector_name

[Optional]

String indicating the type of detector.

[Optional]

Unique identifier for the detector model that can be used to cross-reference external data such as quantification properties.

[Optional]

Indicates if the detector is switched on, which may influence the optics.

inserted

[Optional]

Indicates if the detector is inserted.

[Optional]

The amount this detector's signal contributes to the final result. -1 means inverted. Can be a proportion. If there is only one signal, it would be 1.0.

[Optional]

A setting on the detector to help determine the difference between backscatter and secondary electrons in the ETD detector, for example.

title: AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition
text:
Image metadata structure representing a stage position.

Items

x

[Optional]
 float

X coordinate in meters.

y

[Optional]
 float

Y coordinate in meters.

z

[Optional]
 float

Z coordinate in meters.

a

[Optional]
 float

Alpha angle in radians.

b

[Optional]
 float

Beta angle in radians.

r

[Optional]
 float

Rotation angle in radians.

Methods

create_from()

Creates a new instance of the structure from a collection object.

Overloaded operators

Indexer

Lower or upper case names, values from
StageAxis
 enumerations,
 or integers can be used as an index:

'x' == 'X' == StageAxis.X == 0
.
 Integer indexes have following order:
x, y, z, a, b, r
.

Addition

A scalar value or a position-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 6 values).

Subtraction

A scalar value or a position-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 6 values).

Multiplication

A scalar value is supported.

Division

A scalar value is supported.

Floor division

A scalar value is supported.

Equality

A position-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 6 values). Tests approximate equality with maximum tolerance of 1e-6.

Remarks

This structure inherits from
StagePosition

structure so it can be used instead. For conversion in the opposite direction, use
create_from()
.

Tilt values should follow an inclusive interval of -3.15 to 3.15.

Examples

Example of using AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition instead of
StagePosition
:

# grab stage position from the image metadata
 stage_position = image.metadata.stage_settings.stage_position
 # move the stage to the position
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(stage_position)

Overloaded operator examples:

position_a = AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
 position_b = AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)

print(position_a[2]) # 4
 print(position_a[StageAxis.Y] # 3
 print(position_a["r"] # 7
 print(position_a + position_b) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13)
 print(position_a + 5) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12)
 print(position_a - position_b) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1)
 print(position_a - 3) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(-1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4)
 print(position_a * 2) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14)
 print(position_a / 2) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5)
 print(position_a // 3) # AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2)
 print(position_a == position_b) # False

See also

StagePosition

text:
.

Syntax

create_from(value)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

The collection object can be either a list or a tuple with up to six values,
 or another instance of

AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition

or
StagePosition
. The function always creates a new object.

Examples

# created from a list with a length of six
 AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition.create_from([0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

# created from a tuple with a length of five (r is None)
 AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition.create_from((0, 1, 2, 3, 4))

# created from a StagePosition (r is None)
 AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition.create_from(StagePosition(1, 2, 3, 4, 5))

# created from another AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition
 AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition.create_from(AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition(0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5))

title: CameraImageSize
text:
Represents a size of a camera image with square pixel value and a fixed readout area.

Items

Remarks

The structure defines a combination of image size and camera readout area. Together they implicitly define binning as well. For example, a camera with a full size of 4096x4096 pixels and values

CameraImageSize(size=2048, fixed_readout_area=FixedReadoutArea.FULL)
 has a binning of 2x2.

See the following table for an example of how the image size, readout area and binning are related for a Ceta camera:

Image size

Readout area

Sampling / Binning

4096

Full

1

2048

Full

2

1024

Full

4

512

Full

8

2048

Half

1

1024

Half

2

512

Half

4

256

Half

8

1024

Quarter

1

512

Quarter

2

256

Quarter

4

Acquisition functions without the readout area parameter (e.g.
acquire_camera_image()
)
 will use the full readout area by default. Sizes outside the range given by the chosen readout area are not accepted. Sizes within the range but not equal to
 any specific value are rounded to the nearest supported size.

title: Limits.is_in
text:
.

Checks if the given value falls into the limits. Tests approximate equality with maximum tolerance of 1e-9.

Syntax

is_in(value)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

None values function as open intervals.

Examples

limits = Limits(1, 5)

# interval is closed
 print(limits.is_in(1)) # True
 print(limits.is_in(5)) # True

# acceptable tolerance is 1e-9
 print(limits.is_in(1 - 2e-10)) # True
 print(limits.is_in(5 + 2e-10)) # True

# None values function as open intervals
 open_limits = Limits(max=1) # min is None
 print(open_limits.is_in(2)) # False
 print(open_limits.is_in(0)) # True
 print(open_limits.is_in(-1000)) # True

title: Point.angle
text:
.

Returns the angle of the point in radians.

Syntax

angle()

Return value

Remarks

Function returns a signed angle in radians between the ray from the origin to the point (1,0), and the ray from origin to the given point (x, y).

Error is thrown if one of the point coordinates is None.

Examples

import numpy as np

print(Point(1, 0).angle()) # 0.0 radians
 print(Point(1, 1).angle() * 180 / np.pi) # 45Â°

title: Point
text:
Defines the X and Y coordinates of a point in 2D space.

Items

x

[Optional]
 float

X coordinate of the point.

y

[Optional]
 float

Y coordinate of the point.

Methods

angle()

Returns the angle of the point in radians.

create_from()

Creates a new instance of the structure from a collection object.

magnitude()

Returns the magnitude of the point which is the distance from 0, 0.

Overloaded operators

Indexer

Values are indexed in following order:
x, y
.

Addition

A scalar value or a point-like object is supported (indexable object with a length of 2).

Subtraction

A scalar value or a point-like object is supported (indexable object with a length of 2).

Multiplication

A scalar value or a point-like object is supported (indexable object with a length of 2). Returns dot product in case of point-like object.

Division

A scalar value is supported.

Floor division

A scalar value is supported.

Equality

A point-like object is supported (indexable object with a length of 2). Tests approximate equality with maximum tolerance of 1e-9.

Examples

Overloaded operator examples:

point_a = Point(2, 2)
 point_b = Point(1, 1)

print(point_a[0]) # 2
 print(point_a + point_b) # Point(3, 3)
 print(point_a + 5) # Point(7, 7)
 print(point_a - point_b) # Point(1, 1)
 print(point_a - 3) # Point(-1, -1)
 print(point_a * 2) # Point(4, 4)
 print(point_a * point_b) # 4 (dot product)
 print(point_a / 2) # Point(1, 1)
 print(point_a // 3) # Point(0, 0)
 print(point_a == point_b) # False

title: StagePosition
text:
Defines a stage position.

Items

x

[Optional]
 float

X coordinate in meters.

y

[Optional]
 float

Y coordinate in meters.

z

[Optional]
 float

Z coordinate in meters.

a

[Optional]
 float

Alpha coordinate in radians.

b

[Optional]
 float

Beta coordinate in radians.

Methods

create_from()

Creates a new instance of the structure from a collection object.

Overloaded operators

Indexer

Lower or upper case names, values from
StageAxis
 enumerations,
 or integers can be used as an index:

'x' == 'X' == StageAxis.X == 0
.
 Integer indexes have following order:
x, y, z, a, b
.

Addition

A scalar value or a position-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 5 values).

Subtraction

A scalar value or a position-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 5 values).

Multiplication

A scalar value is supported.

Division

A scalar value is supported.

Floor division

A scalar value is supported.

Equality

A position-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 5 values). Tests approximate equality with maximum tolerance of 1e-6.

Examples

Following example shows different ways of creating stage position:

import math

StagePosition(0.001, 0.002, 0.003, 0.4, 0.5) # x = 0.001 m, y = 0.002 m, z = 0.003 m, alpha = 0.4 rad, beta = 0.5 rad
 StagePosition(z=0.003) # z = 0.003 m, other axes are None

# Conversion from degrees to radians
 StagePosition(a=math.radians(5)) # alpha = 5 deg

# Get current stage position and update it
 position = microscope.specimen.stage.position
 position.x = 0.005
 position.y = 0.006

Overloaded operator examples:

position_a = StagePosition(2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
 position_b = StagePosition(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

print(position_a[2]) # 4
 print(position_a[StageAxis.Y]) # 3
 print(position_a["b"]) # 6
 print(position_a + position_b) # StagePosition(3, 5, 7, 9, 11)
 print(position_a + 5) # StagePosition(7, 8, 9, 10, 11)
 print(position_a - position_b) # StagePosition(1, 1, 1, 1, 1)
 print(position_a - 3) # StagePosition(-1, 0, 1, 2, 3)
 print(position_a * 2) # StagePosition(4, 6, 8, 10, 12)
 print(position_a / 2) # StagePosition(1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3)
 print(position_a // 3) # StagePosition(0, 1, 1, 1, 2)
 print(position_a == position_b) # False

See also

stage
,
AdornedImageMetadataStagePosition
,
StageVelocity
.

 float

Methods

create_from()

Creates a new instance of the structure from a collection object.

Overloaded operators

Indexer

Lower or upper case names, values from
StageAxis
 enumerations,
 or integers can be used as an index:

'x' == 'X' == StageAxis.X == 0
.
 Integer indexes have following order:
x, y, z, a, b
.

Addition

A scalar value or a velocity-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 5 values).

Subtraction

A scalar value or a velocity-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 5 values).

Multiplication

A scalar value is supported.

Division

A scalar value is supported.

Floor division

A scalar value is supported.

Equality

A velocity-like object is supported (indexable object with up to 5 values). Tests approximate equality with maximum tolerance of 1e-6.

Examples

Following example shows different ways of creating stage velocity:

import math

StageVelocity(1e-6, 2e-6, 3e-6) # x = 1e-6 m/s, y = 2e-6 m/s, z = 3e-6 m/s
 StageVelocity(z=4e-6) # z = 4e-6 m/s, other axes are None

# Conversion from degrees to radians
 StageVelocity(a=math.radians(5)) # alpha = 5 deg/s

# Get current piezo stage jogging velocity and update it
 velocity = microscope.specimen.stage.jogging_velocity
 velocity.x = 5e-6
 velocity.y = 6e-6

Overloaded operator examples:

velocity_a = StageVelocity(2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
 velocity_b = StageVelocity(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

print(velocity_a[2]) # 4
 print(velocity_a[StageAxis.Y]) # 3
 print(velocity_a["b"]) # 6
 print(velocity_a + velocity_b) # StageVelocity(3, 5, 7, 9, 11)
 print(velocity_a + 5) # StageVelocity(7, 8, 9, 10, 11)
 print(velocity_a - velocity_b) # StageVelocity(1, 1, 1, 1, 1)
 print(velocity_a - 3) # StageVelocity(-1, 0, 1, 2, 3)
 print(velocity_a * 2) # StageVelocity(4, 6, 8, 10, 12)
 print(velocity_a / 2) # StageVelocity(1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3)
 print(velocity_a // 3) # StageVelocity(0, 1, 1, 1, 2)
 print(velocity_a == velocity_b) # False

title: ApertureMechanismInsertionState
text:
Possible states of an aperture mechanism.

Values

ARBITRARY

"Arbitrary"

Aperture mechanism is in the arbitrary state. This state is not inserted or retracted, but somewhere in between (free moving alignment mode).

ERROR

"Error"

Aperture mechanism is reporting a HW error, cannot insert or retract.

INSERTED

"Inserted"

title: AutoBeamBlankMode
text:
Defines auto beam blank modes.

Values

Remarks

OFF
:

Automatic beam blanking is completely disabled. No blanking or unblanking takes place without manual user interventions.

BLANK_WHEN_IDLETEM
:

When selected the blanking is automatically triggered under these circumstances:

When no cameras are in the beam's path anymore the beam is blanked.

When the fluorescent screen is inserted into the beam's path the beam unblanks.

When a camera is inserted into the beam's path the beam is blanked.

When the system exits TEM mode the beam is unblanked.

BLANK_WHEN_IDLE
:

When selected the system automatically unblanks before an acquisition starts and blanks when the last acquisition finishes.
 This mode is only available for systems with the NanoPulser hardware.

RETRACTED

UNKNOWN

"Unknown"

Beam stopper state is unknown.

title: EdsDetectorType.DUAL_X
text:
.

EDS detector with two segments.

Remarks

The Dual-X detectors can be inserted and retracted to protect them. There are some optics modes
 (like LM and
 Lorentz) where the detector cannot be inserted.
 In other cases the detector is inserted automatically when acquisition is started. In case it is necessary to insert
 the detector before the actual acquisition is started, they can be inserted manually using the

insert()
 function.

To prevent damage, the detectors are automatically retracted when switching the
 optical_mode,
 when closing the column valves or when the input count rate is too high.

title: EdsDetectorType
text:
Specifies EDS detector types.

Values

DUAL_X

"DualX"

EDS detector with two segments.

SUPER_X

"SuperX"

EDS detector with four segments and a protective shutter.

ULTRA_X

"UltraX"

High sensitive EDS detector with six segments.

Remarks

AutoScript is using values from this enumeration as detector identifiers. For displaying names to the end user, use property

display_name
.
 EDS detectors that are not listed in this enumeration are not supported.

title: EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X
text:
.

EDS detector with four segments and a protective shutter.

Remarks

The Super-X detectors have mechanical shutters to protect them. There are some optics modes
 (like LM and
 Lorentz) where the shutters cannot be opened.
 In other cases the shutters are opened automatically when acquisition is started
 and closed some seconds after the acquisition is finished.

To prevent damage to the detector the shutters are automatically closed when switching the
 optical_mode,
 when closing the column valves or when the input count rate is too high.

The SuperX and SuperX G2 variants of the detector have four segments, designated

SEGMENT1
,

SEGMENT2
,

SEGMENT3
, and

SEGMENT4
.
 The SuperX G2 Lite variant has only two segments, designated

SEGMENT3
 and

SEGMENT4
.

Values

Reads out quarter of the area of the sensor (centered).

title: Enumerations
text:
Enumerations are simple static objects consisting of constant integer or string values.
 They do not inherit from the
Enum
 class from the Python standard library, nor do the behave like types.
 Enumerations are often used to denote all or the most frequently used values in various API calls.
 All possible uses of enumeration values are documented with the phrase
"Enumeration X can be used"
 or similar.

title: MoveToPixelMethod.ANY
text:
.

Tries to move with optics, and if out of range, moves with the stage.

Remarks

The method will never move both the optics and the stage simultaneously.

See also

MoveToPixelMethod.OPTICS

MoveToPixelMethod.STAGE

title: MoveToPixelMethod
text:
Methods of move to pixel function.

Values

ANY

"Any"

Tries to move with optics, and if out of range, moves with the stage.

OPTICS

"Optics"

Moves with optics (image shift/beam shift/image tilt).

STAGE

"Stage"

Moves with the stage.

title: MoveToPixelMethod.OPTICS

.

Remarks

Image shift is used in
optical_mode

 Beam shift is used in

optics.optical_mode

optics.deflectors.image_shift
