title: Microscope API
text:
Microscope API

AutoScript TEM is a comprehensive software package from Thermo Fisher Scientific designed to facilitate Transmission Electron Microscope scripting and related data processing utilities in a Python 3 language environment.

The most important class in this package is
TemMicroscopeClient
, which after instantiation and connection
 to an
AutoScript server
 provides a wide range of functions through itsÂ members (child objects, properties and functions) organized
 in a
static tree
.

The package contains also other classes.
Data structures
 make parameters and return values of static tree methods more comprehensive,
 while
enumerations
 can save some time and help avoid typos when used instead of string or integer values.

Dynamic objects
 are objects whose lifetime is expected to be shorter than the lifetime of
TemMicroscopeClient

and which often have to be created explicitly during script execution. Detectors may serve as a good example of dynamic objects.

In the following sections you will find detailed information on all the above mentioned parts:

title: Aperture
text:
Contains properties of an aperture.

Items

name

str

Aperture name.

type

str

Aperture type. Uses values from
ApertureType
.

diameter

[Optional]
 float

Diameter in meters if type is circular, None otherwise.

Remarks

The aperture
name
 is used to uniquely identify each aperture. When selecting an aperture only the
name
 value is used to identify the aperture. If the given
name
 doesn't match the
name
 of any existing aperture, the aperture selection will fail.

title: CameraAcquisitionSettings
text:
Contains settings for image acquisition from a camera detector.

Items

Remarks

This structure contains a set of advanced settings for camera acquisition. It is used as an argument for several acquisition functions.

See also

acquire_camera_image_advanced()

acquire_camera_series_advanced()

title: CameraAcquisitionSettings.electron_counting
text:
.

Whether or not an electron counted image is produced (counting detectors only). True by default.

Data type

[Optional]
 bool

Remarks

The parameter applies only to counting cameras (Falcon). For other camera types, the acquisition will return an error if this parameter
 is set to both true and false (leave the parameter as it is or set it to None).

If the parameter is set to false, the counts are integrated and can no longer be related to electrons.

title: CameraAcquisitionSettings.fixed_readout_area
text:
.

Readout area of the sensor. Enumeration
FixedReadoutArea
 can be used.
FULL
 by default.

Data type

[Optional]
 str

Remarks

For information about supported camera sizes and readout area combinations see members of
CameraType
 enumeration.

title: CameraAcquisitionSettings.frame_combining
text:
.

The number of sub-frames the camera will combine (Ceta only). Default value is 1.

Data type

[Optional]
 int

Remarks

The parameter applies only to Ceta cameras. For other camera types, the acquisition will return an error if this parameter
 is set to any value except None.

Ceta cameras are capable of capturing a fixed number of sub-frames depending on their fixed internal frame rate. This means that
 the greater the value of the sub-frames, the greater the exposure time must be. Sub-frames are used to reduce the noise of the final frame.
 The specified value is not validated. The values that are outside the limits are changed to the closest acceptable values. Metadata can be used
 to check the actual value of the sub-frames.

title: CameraAcquisitionSettings.size
text:
.

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

Data type

int

Remarks

For information about supported camera sizes and readout area combinations see members of
CameraType
 enumeration.

title: CameraLengthData
text:
Contains properties of a camera length.

Items

nominal

[Read only]
 float

The nominal camera length in meters.

calibrated

[Read only]
 float

The calibrated camera length in meters.

rotation

[Read only]
 float

The rotation of the camera length in radians.

label

[Read only]
 str

A label fully describing the camera length.

objective_lens_mode

[Read only]
 str

The objective lens mode. Values from enumeration
ObjectiveLensMode
 are used.

title: EdsSpectrumImageSettings
text:
Contains settings for EDS spectrum image acquisition.

Items

Remarks

This structure contains a set of settings used for the EDS spectrum image acquisition. Not all settings are intercompatible.
 A valid Settings structure must adhere to the following criteria:

dwell_time
,
shaping_time
,
 and
dispersion
 must be specified.

Either the
size
 or the
region
 must be specified.
 If both are specified, the region must fit into the size dimensions. If the size is not specified, the maximum scan size of the system is assumed.

region
 has to contain exactly one shape.

Either
scanning_detectors
 or
scanning_detector_segments

must be specified. If both are given, they cannot overlap. In other words, segments from a detector listed in scanning detectors can't be used.

eds_detector
 must be specified, configuring the EDS segments is optional.

Scan region

When a region is specified, both the scanning area and scanning time are reduced. This technique can be utilized for
 optimization purposes. Additionally, the resulting images will have a smaller size, as they will be cropped to match the
 specified region area.

See also

acquire_spectrum_image()

title: EdsSpectrumImageSettings.save_eds_event_stream
text:
.

Defines whether EDS data events are to be saved. True by default.

Data type

[Optional]
 bool

Remarks

Disabling this option will prevent EDS data events from being stored individually in the output file.
 As a result, the file size is significantly reduced, allowing for faster transportation to the client.
 However, the data will only be accessible in a compressed format using proprietary compression algorithm.
 This means that only Velox can be used for further analysis of the acquired data. Additionally, certain analysis features,
 such as frame removal, will no longer be possible without the individual data events.

When EDS events are enabled, one summed spectrum per segment (stream) is also saved to the EMD file.

title: EelsExposureSettings
text:
Contains settings for EELS spectrum exposure.

Items

Remarks

The scan engine iterates over the exposure settings at each dwell location. Multiple exposure settings allow to acquire multiple spectra
 or spectrum image cubes with a single scan. The exposure settings are applied in the order they are defined in the list.

See also

acquire_spectra()

acquire_spectrum_image()

title: EelsSpectrumImageSettings
text:
Contains settings for EELS spectrum image acquisition.

Items

Remarks

The minimum dwell time value is 100Âµs. The dwell time must also be higher than the sum of exposure times (plus the necessary overhead depending on
 the number of spectra and HW limitations).

See the following table for some minimum dwell time examples:

Sum of exposure times [s]

Minimum dwell time [s]

1e-6

1e-4

1e-5

1e-4

1e-4

1.3e-4

1e-3

1.03e-3

1e-2

1.01e-2

1e-1

1.01e-1

title: Data structures
text:
Data structures are simple objects for transporting data. They usually contain some helper functions and/or overloaded
 operators for convenience. Structures are often used to combine multiple arguments or return values (e.g.

CameraAcquisitionSettings
),
 or to represent data formats (e.g.
AdornedImage
,

EmdFile
).

Structures can be created on the client as well as on the server.
 When the structure is passed as a parameter to the function call, the entire structure is serialized and sent to the server.
 When accepting structures from the server, some structures may not be fully deserialized until their data is accessed, i.e.,
 lazy deserialization.

title: MoveToPixelSettings.image_size
text:
.

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used. Default value is the maximum size supported by the camera (with the given fixed readout area in mind), or the maximum supported scanning resolution.

Data type

[Optional]
 int

title: MoveToPixelSettings
text:
Additional settings for move to pixel functionality.

Items

image_size

[Optional]
 int

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used. Default value is the maximum size supported by the camera (with the given fixed readout area in mind), or the maximum supported scanning resolution.

fixed_readout_area

[Optional]
 str

Readout area used to acquire the image (camera acquisition only). Enumeration
FixedReadoutArea
 can be used.
FULL
 by default.

method

[Optional]
 str

Method of the move to pixel. Enumeration
MoveToPixelMethod
 can be used. Default value is
STAGE
.

use_safe_stage_moves

[Optional]
 bool

Whether the stage should be moved safely by setting the tilt to zero before moving the stage to avoid pole touches. True by default.

See also

specimen.stage.move_to_pixel()

title: MoveToPixelSettings.use_safe_stage_moves
text:
.

Whether the stage should be moved safely by setting the tilt to zero before moving the stage to avoid pole touches. True by default.

Data type

[Optional]
 bool

Remarks

The function uses safe stage moves by default, but in some cases, it may be necessary to use unsafe moves because the safe move
 may cause some shift of the specimen. It is recommended to use this option with caution.

See also

absolute_move()

absolute_move_safe()

title: Region
text:
Defines a generic region shape.

Items

Remarks

Region is a generic shape that can be used to define a scanning area. Exactly one of the items must be specified.
 Currently, only rectangles are supported, but it is expected that the options will expand in the future.

Precision

If
PIXELS
 coordinates are used and float values are provided, the rectangle values
 are floored.

If
RELATIVE
 coordinates are used, the actual size
 is calculated as
relative_value * size
. The result is then floored.
 If the size is not specified, the maximum scan size is assumed.

See also

Rectangle

RegionCoordinateSystem

StemAcquisitionSettings

See also

auto_functions.run_beam_tilt_auto_focus()

title: RunBeamTiltAutoFocusSettings
text:
Contains settings for the beam tilt automatic focus routine.

Items

camera_detector

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
CameraType
 can be used.

size

[Optional]
 int

Square image size in pixels. Default is 1024. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

exposure_time

[Optional]
 float

The exposure time in seconds. Default is 1.

focus_method

[Optional]
 str

Focus correction method to be used. Maps to enumeration
FocusMethod
. Default is
OBJECTIVE_LENS
.

auto_stigmate

[Optional]
 bool

Whether the procedure should optimize astigmatism or not. False by default.

use_three_image_method

[Optional]
 bool

Whether the procedure should use 3 images to be less sensitive to drift. False by default.

maximum_focus_change

[Optional]
 float

A new iteration is started as long as the applied focus change is larger than this value. Default is 0.25e-6.

maximum_iterations

[Optional]
 int

Maximum number of iterations that is applied. Default is 4.

maximum_astigmatism_change

[Optional]
 float

A new iteration is started as long as the applied astigmatism change is larger than this value. Default is 0.1e-6.

iterate_to_defocus

[Optional]
 float

Iterate to defocus value in meters. Makes the procedure more robust for samples where the contrast at focus is too low. Default is 0.

Remarks

All attributes without specified default values are required.

See also

auto_functions.run_beam_tilt_auto_focus()

A value between 0 and 1 as a measure for quality: 0 = perfect fit, 1 = poor fit.

Indication whether the result is reliable.

See also

title: RunOptiStemSettings.cutoff_in_pixels
text:
.

Interval between any two adjacent samples - Nyquist interval in pixels. The default value is 4 pixels. This parameter is not used for B2A2 method and will result in exception if set.

Data type

[Optional]
 int

title: RunOptiStemSettings
text:
Contains settings for the OptiStem routine.

Items

method

[Optional]
 str

Specifies what
OptiStemMethod
 should be used. The default value is C1A1.

dwell_time

[Optional]
 float

STEM dwell time in seconds. The default value depends on method.

cutoff_in_pixels

[Optional]
 int

Interval between any two adjacent samples - Nyquist interval in pixels. The default value is 4 pixels. This parameter is not used for B2A2 method and will result in exception if set.

cutoff_spatial_frequency

[Optional]
 float

Amount of cycles per meter. The default value is 2.85e+9. This parameter is not used for B2A2 method and will result in exception if set.

title: RunStemAutoFocusSettings
text:
Contains settings for the automatic focus routine in STEM optical mode.

Items

scanning_detector

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
DetectorType
 can be used.

size

[Optional]
 int

Square image size in pixels. Default is 1024. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

dwell_time

[Optional]
 float

The dwell time in seconds. Default is 1e-6.

auto_stigmate

[Optional]
 bool

Whether the procedure should optimize stigmation or not. False by default.

accuracy_level

[Optional]

Specifies level of accuracy. Enumeration
AccuracyLevel

COARSE
.

reset_beam_blanker_afterwards

[Optional]

If true, beam blanker will will be set to its previous status after the task completes. If false, beam will be left blanked. False by default.

Remarks

All attributes without specified default values are required.

title: StemAcquisitionSettings.auto_beam_blank
text:
.

Automatic beam blanking. False by default.
[The property is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.21]

Data type

[Optional]
 bool

Remarks

Systems equipped with the NanoPulser hardware may utilize the

auto_beam_blank.mode
 setting
 to set automatic blanking. The auto_beam_blank context manager can be used instead of setting the auto_beam_blank property or
 the
blank()
 and

unblank()
 methods may be called manually.

Examples

from autoscript_tem_toolkit.context_managers import blanker_context

settings = StemAcquisitionSettings(
 1e-6,
 detector_types=[DetectorType.HAADF, DetectorType.BF_S],
 size=1024)

with blanker_context(microscope.optics.blanker):
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_images_advanced(settings)

See also

blanker_context

optics.blanker

title: StemAcquisitionSettings
text:
Contains advanced settings for scanning detector image acquisition.

Items

Remarks

This structure contains a set of settings used for the advanced stem acquisition. Not all settings are intercompatible.
 A valid Settings structure must adhere to the following criteria:

dwell_time
 must be specified.

Either
size
 or
region
 must be specified.
 If both are specified, the region must fit into the size dimensions. If the size is not specified, the maximum scan size of the system is assumed.

region
 has to contain exactly one shape.

Either
detector_types
 or
detector_segments
 must be specified.
 If both are given, they cannot overlap. In other words, segments from a detector listed in detector types can't be used.

Beware that auto beam blanking is False by default.

When a region is specified, both the scanning area and scanning time are reduced. This technique can be utilized for
 optimization purposes. Additionally, the resulting images will have a smaller size, as they will be cropped to match the
 specified region area.

See also

acquisition.acquire_stem_images_advanced()

Region

title: StemDataSettings
text:
Contains advanced settings for scan trigger acquisition.

Items

dwell_time

float

STEM dwell time in seconds.

detector_types

[Optional]
 List[str]

The name(s) of the detector(s) used for the acquisition. Enumeration
CameraType
 can be used.

region

[Optional]

Region

Acquisition area to be scanned. Use
Region
.

size

[Optional]
 int

Square scan size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

Remarks

This structure contains a set of settings used for the advanced stem data acquisitions, where the data are not handled by AutoScript.
 Not all settings are intercompatible. A valid Settings structure must adhere to the following criteria:

dwell_time
 must be specified.

Either
size
 or
region
 must be specified.
 If both are specified, the region must fit into the size dimensions. If the size is not specified, the maximum scan size of the system is assumed.

region
 has to contain exactly one shape.

detector_types
 list can be empty or None (in that case, any 3rd party detector can be connected
 to the scan engine directly and HW synchronization is used). If a detector is specified, it must be one of the EMPAD-type cameras. The list can contain multiple detectors.

When a region is specified, both the scanning area and scanning time are reduced. This technique can be utilized for
 optimization purposes. Additionally, the resulting images will have a smaller size, as they will be cropped to match the
 specified region area.

See also

acquire_stem_data_advanced()

title: acquisition.acquire_camera_image
text:
.

Acquires an image from a camera.

Syntax

acquire_camera_image(camera_detector, size, exposure_time)

Parameters

camera_detector

str

The name of the camera detector. Enumeration
CameraType
 can be used.

size

int

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

exposure_time

float

The exposure time in seconds.

Return value

Remarks

For information about supported image sizes see
get_supported_image_sizes()
 method.

The screen does not have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The selected detector is also inserted automatically.

Examples

The following code shows how a 1024 x 1024 image is acquired by the Ceta camera with an exposure time of 1s.
 Note that you need to specify the correct camera name, either as a string or (better) a value from from
 the
CameraType
 enumeration.
 You can find out names of installed cameras by calling the
detectors.camera_detectors()
 function.

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1.0)

Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used to select acquisition size:

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_1024, 1.0)

See also

acquisition.acquire_camera_series()

detectors.camera_detectors

title: acquisition.acquire_camera_image_advanced
text:
.

Acquires an image from a camera with advanced settings.

Syntax

acquire_camera_image_advanced(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

For information about supported image sizes see
get_supported_image_sizes()
 method.

The screen does not have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The selected detector is also inserted automatically.

Examples

The following code shows how a 1024 x 1024 image is acquired by the Ceta camera with an exposure time of 1s.
 Readout area is set to half and frame combining (Ceta specific setting) is set to 6.

settings = CameraAcquisitionSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_1024, 0.5,
 fixed_readout_area=FixedReadoutArea.HALF, frame_combining=6)

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image_advanced(settings)

See also

CameraAcquisitionSettings

title: acquisition.acquire_camera_series
text:
.

Acquires a series of images from a camera.

Syntax

acquire_camera_series(camera_detector, size, exposure_time, length)

Parameters

camera_detector

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
CameraType
 can be used.

size

int

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

exposure_time

float

The exposure time in seconds.

length

int

The number of images to acquire.

Return value

Remarks

The entire series of images must fit into memory. The maximum number of images returned in one call is 64.
 To take and process a longer stream of images, you must call the function in a loop and process the images in batches.
 See the example below.

For information about supported image sizes see
get_supported_image_sizes()
 method.

The screen does not have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The selected detector is also inserted automatically.

Examples

Take 5 images with Flucam and save them to disk with increasing index in the filename.

images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_series(CameraType.FLUCAM, ImageSize.PRESET_1024, 0.5, 5)

index = 1
 for image in images:
 image.save(f"c:\\image{index}.tiff")
 index += 1

Acquire 100 images with Ceta camera and save them with increasing index in the filename.
 Note that we need to implement a processing loop to overcome the limit of 64 images in a single acquisition call.

index = 1
 for loops in range(1, 10):
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_series(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1.0, 10)
 for image in images:
 print("Saving image", index)
 image.save(f"c:\\image{index}.tiff")
 index += 1

See also

acquisition.acquire_camera_image()

screen

title: acquisition.acquire_camera_series_advanced
text:
.

Acquires a series of images from a camera with advanced settings.

Syntax

acquire_camera_series_advanced(settings, length)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

The entire series of images must fit into memory. The maximum number of images returned in one call is 64.
 To take and process a longer stream of images, you must call the function in a loop and process the images in batches.
 See the example in
acquire_camera_series()
.

For information about supported image sizes see
get_supported_image_sizes()
 method.

The screen does not have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The selected detector is also inserted automatically.

Examples

Take 5 images with Ceta with advanced acquisition settings and save them to disk with increasing index in the filename.

settings = CameraAcquisitionSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_1024, 0.5,
 fixed_readout_area=FixedReadoutArea.HALF, frame_combining=6)
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_series_advanced(settings, 5)

index = 1

 image.save(f"c:\\image{index}.tiff")
 index += 1

CameraAcquisitionSettings

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_data
text:
.

Triggers a scan task with a given scan synchronizable camera without returning the data.

Syntax

acquire_stem_data(camera_detector, size, dwell_time)

Parameters

camera_detector

str

The name of the camera detector. Enumeration
CameraType
 can be used.

size

int

Square scan size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

dwell_time

float

The dwell time in seconds.

Remarks

The function can be used to trigger acquisitions with scan synchronized cameras to acquire one camera image per scan point. The data is not returned, but stored on a different computer (offloaded),
 depending on the camera type used:

BM_EMPAD
 or
SH_EMPAD
:

The resulting data are stored on the EMPAD PC. Size of the image from each scan point is 128x128 and cannot be changed.
 For experiments with EMPAD, it is recommended to upgrade to the latest available version of the TEM server software and the EMPAD control software. Older versions are known to have issues with
 storing acquired images on the EMPAD computer.

BM_CETA
:

The resulting data are stored on the storage server. Size of the image from each scan point is 256x256 and cannot be changed.

Other detector types are not supported.

Keep in mind that after the function returns, it may take some time before the data is actually stored and can be accessed. The time depends on the size of the resulting data.

Examples

The following example shows how to trigger a 4D STEM acquisition with the EMPAD detector:

# Change optical mode to STEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM

# Trigger EMPAD scan, scan size: 128x128, dwell time 1ms
 microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_data(CameraType.BM_EMPAD, ImageSize.PRESET_128, 1e-3)

The next example shows how to trigger a 4D STEM acquisition with Ceta detector:

# Change optical mode to STEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM

# Trigger Ceta scan, scan size: 128x128, dwell time 10ms
 microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_data(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_128, 10e-3)

See also

Scanning

acquire_stem_data_advanced()

optics.optical_mode

CameraType

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_data_advanced
text:
.

Triggers a scan task without returning the data.

Syntax

acquire_stem_data_advanced(settings)

Parameters

Remarks

The function extends the
acquire_stem_data
 function by allowing the user to control the acquisition
 in more detail. The data is not returned, but stored on a different computer (offloaded), depending on the camera type used:

BM_EMPAD
 or
SH_EMPAD
:

The resulting data are stored on the EMPAD PC. Size of the image from each scan point is 128x128 and cannot be changed.
 For experiments with EMPAD, it is recommended to upgrade to the latest available version of the TEM server software and the EMPAD control software. Older versions are known to have issues with
 storing acquired images on the EMPAD computer.

BM_CETA
:

The resulting data are stored on the storage server. Size of the image from each scan point is 256x256 and cannot be changed.

Other detector types are not supported.

If the detector type is not provided, the function will run an "empty" scan that can be used for third-party detector acquisition. AutoScript cannot access the data,
 and the detector must be hardware synchronized in this case.

Keep in mind that after the function returns, it may take some time before the data is actually stored and can be accessed. The time depends on the size of the resulting data.

Examples

The following example shows how to trigger a 4D STEM acquisition with the EMPAD detector:

# Change optical mode to STEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM

# Trigger EMPAD scan
 microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_data_advanced(StemDataSettings(dwell_time=1e-3, size=ImageSize.PRESET_128, detector_types=[CameraType.BM_EMPAD]))

The next example shows how to trigger a 4D STEM acquisition with the Ceta detector:

# Change optical mode to STEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM

# Trigger scan
 microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_data_advanced(StemDataSettings(dwell_time=10e-3, size=ImageSize.PRESET_128, detector_types=[CameraType.BM_CETA]))

The next example show how to trigger acquisition with a region and a 3rd party detector:

# Change optical mode to STEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM

# Create settings structure
 settings = StemDataSettings(dwell_time=1e-3, size=ImageSize.PRESET_512,
 region=Region(RegionCoordinateSystem.PIXELS, rectangle=(0, 0, 30, 30)))

# Trigger scan
 microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_data_advanced(settings)

See also

Scanning

acquire_stem_data()

optics.optical_mode

CameraType

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_image
text:
.

Acquires an image using a scanning detector.

Syntax

acquire_stem_image(scanning_detector, size, dwell_time)

Parameters

scanning_detector

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
DetectorType
 can be used.

size

int

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

dwell_time

float

The dwell time in seconds.

Return value

Remarks

If a multisegment detector (DF-S or BF-S) is specified, the image is acquired from all of its segments, regardless of
 which segments may have been disabled by calling

ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()
.
 The function does not permanently reset the segment configuration, but simply ignores it.

If you want to acquire images from individual segments, use

acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images()
.

The screen doesn't have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The chosen detector is inserted automatically as well.

Examples

Acquire a STEM image of 512 x 512 pixels from the HAADF detector with 1 Âµs dwell time:

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_image("HAADF", ImageSize.PRESET_512, 1e-6)

Acquire a STEM image of 1024 x 1024 pixels from the BF detector with 2 Âµs dwell time and save it to disk in TIFF format:

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_image(DetectorType.BF, ImageSize.PRESET_1024, 2e-6)
 image.save("c:\\result.tiff")

See also

Scanning

acquisition.acquire_stem_images()

acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images()

DetectorType

ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()

screen

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_images
text:
.

Acquires images using multiple scanning detectors.

Syntax

acquire_stem_images(scanning_detectors, size, dwell_time)

Parameters

scanning_detectors

List[str]

The list of scanning detectors to use in acquisition. Enumeration
DetectorType
 can be used.

size

int

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

dwell_time

float

The dwell time in seconds.

Return value

Remarks

The screen doesn't have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The chosen detector is inserted automatically as well.

See
this page
 for information about the acquisition overhead.

Examples

Take image with each STEM detector installed on the microscope and save it as TIFF with detector name noted in the file name:

detectors = microscope.detectors.scanning_detectors
 print("Available detectors:", detectors)

# Take one image with each detector; resolution will be 1k and dwell time 1us
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_images(detectors, 1024, 1e-6)
 print(f"{len(images)} images taken.")

# Save the images
 for i in range(0, len(images)):
 print("Saving image from", detectors[i])
 images[i].save(f"c:\\image_{detectors[i]}.tiff")

See also

Scanning

acquisition.acquire_stem_image()

DetectorType

screen

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_images_advanced
text:
.

Acquires images with advanced settings using specified detectors or segments.

Syntax

acquire_stem_images_advanced(settings)

Parameters

Return value

List[
AdornedImage
]

List of STEM images. Order in the list corresponds to the order of segments in the settings.

Remarks

The images are returned as a list. The returned image sequence maintains the order given by detector types and segments in the settings.
 In case both segments and detector types are specified, all detector images are returned first. When using segment groups,
 (such as All) the images are ordered as follows: inner-1, inner-2, ..., outer-1, outer-2, ..., outer-4.
 For more information about about supported settings see
StemAcquisitionSettings
.

See
this page
 for information about the acquisition overhead.

Examples

The following example shows an advanced acquisition from selected detector segments and detector types.
 Dwell time is set to 1 Âµs, the size of the image is 1024x1024 pixels, and the region of interest is set to a Rectangle
 in the upper left corner of the sensor with relative size 0.2 by 0.8.
 The resulting image will be cropped to the size of the given rectangle (205x819).

# Select segments from segmented detectors
 bf_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 bf_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

df_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 df_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING)

# Combine enabled segments
 segments = df_s.get_enabled_segments() + bf_s.get_enabled_segments()

# Select detector
 detector_types = [DetectorType.HAADF]

# Create settings and acquire images
 settings = StemAcquisitionSettings(1e-6,
 detector_types=detector_types,
 detector_segments=segments,
 size=1024,
 region=Region(RegionCoordinateSystem.RELATIVE, Rectangle(0, 0, 0.2, 0.8)),
 auto_beam_blank=False)

images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_images_advanced(settings)

See also

Scanning

Detectors

DetectorType

DetectorSegment

DetectorSegmentType

RegionCoordinateSystem

detectors.get_scanning_detector()

ScanningDetector.get_enabled_segments()

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images
text:
.

Acquires images from scanning detector segments.

Syntax

acquire_stem_segment_images(detector_segments, size, dwell_time)

Parameters

detector_segments

List[
DetectorSegment
]

The list of detector segments.

size

int

Square image size in pixels. Enumeration
ImageSize
 can be used.

dwell_time

float

The dwell time in seconds.

Return value

List[
AdornedImage
]

The list of images. The order of the images in the list corresponds to the order of the segments in the input array.

Remarks

As a basic use case, the function takes a list of segments from one detector, simultaneously acquires images on those that are enabled,
 and returns the resulting images as a list of AdornedImage objects, maintaining their input order.

The input array may also include segments from multiple detectors.
 Images are acquired simultaneously on all such detectors and their segments.
 Non-segmented detectors, such as HAADF, can also participate in the acquisition.
 For such detectors, include a virtual segment named
"Single"
 in the input array.

Typically, detector segments are configured by accessing the
detector object

before calling this function. Gain, offset and enable/disable state can be set for each segment.

The name of the segment from which the image originates is stored in the custom section of the image metadata under the key
"StemSegment"
.
 An example of how to retrieve this information can be found in the Examples section.

The screen doesn't have to be retracted before calling this function; the acquisition manages it automatically.
 The chosen detector is inserted automatically as well.

The Panther STEM detectors (DF-S and BF-S) consist of eight segments: 4 quadrants on a inner and outer ring,
 resulting in 16 segments in total. However,
only 12 segments can be active at once as the outer 4 quadrants
 of the BF-S detector are shadowed by the DF-S detector when both are inserted
.
 When combined with the HAADF detector the maximum of 13 signals can be recorded (see the examples).

See
this page
 for information about the acquisition overhead.

Examples

The following example shows acquisition on two segments of the BF-S detector:

# Get object representing the BF-S detector
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)

# Enable first two segments of the inner ring and disable all other segments
 detector.set_enabled_segments([DetectorSegmentType.INNER1, DetectorSegmentType.INNER2])

# Get list of enabled segments for the acquisition method
 segments = detector.get_enabled_segments()

# Acquire the images
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(segments, size=1024, dwell_time=200e-9)

# images[0] holds the image from "Inner1" segment
 # images[1] holds the image from "Inner2" segment

DF4 detectors also contain segments, but these are not divided into rings and different identifiers must be used:

# Get object representing the DF4 detector
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF4)

# Enable first two segments of the detector
 detector.set_enabled_segments([DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1, DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT2])

# Acquire the images
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(detector.get_enabled_segments(), size=1024,
 dwell_time=200e-9)

# images[0] holds the image from "Segment1" segment
 # images[1] holds the image from "Segment2" segment

title: acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images
text:
ntType.SEGMENT1, DetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT2])

# Acquire the images
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(detector.get_enabled_segments(), size=1024,
 dwell_time=200e-9)

# images[0] holds the image from "Segment1" segment
 # images[1] holds the image from "Segment2" segment
The function can also acquire images from multiple detectors at the same time.
 Detectors without segments are assumed to have a virtual segment "Single".

# Get detector objects
 bf_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 haadf = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.HAADF)

# Enable all four segments of BF-S outer ring and disable all others
 bf_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING)

# Enable SINGLE segment on HAADF
 haadf.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.SINGLE)

# Join the lists together
 segments = bf_s.get_enabled_segments() + haadf.get_enabled_segments()

# Acquire one image per segment, a total of five images in this case
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(segments, size=1024, dwell_time=200e-9)

Acquire 13 images from BF-S, DF-S and HAADF detectors simultaneously.

# Get detector objects
 bf_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 df_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 haadf = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.HAADF)

# Enable the inner segments on the BF-S detector
 bf_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

# Enable all segments on the DF-S detector
 df_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.ALL)

# Enable a single segment on HAADF
 haadf.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.SINGLE)

# Join the lists together
 segments = bf_s.get_enabled_segments() + df_s.get_enabled_segments() + haadf.get_enabled_segments()

# Acquire one image per segment, a total of 13 images in this case
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(segments, size=256, dwell_time=1e-6)

Retrieve segment information from metadata:

# Get object representing the BF-S detector
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)

# Enable first two segments of the inner ring and disable all other segments
 detector.set_enabled_segments([DetectorSegmentType.INNER1, DetectorSegmentType.INNER2])

# Acquire the images
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(detector.get_enabled_segments(), size=1024,
 dwell_time=200e-9)

# Retrieve segment information from the metadata
 for image in images:
 # Find first metadata custom property collection with an empty scope
 custom_properties = [property_list for property_list in image.metadata.custom_properties
 if property_list.scope == ""][0].properties

# Find first custom property by the name "StemSegment"
 segment_custom_property = [custom_property for custom_property in custom_properties
 if custom_property.name == "StemSegment"][0]

# Print segment info
 print(segment_custom_property.value)

See also

Scanning

ScanningDetector

DetectorSegment

DetectorSegmentType

ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments()

ScanningDetector.set_segment_gain()

ScanningDetector.set_segment_offset()

title: analysis.spectrum_image_history
text:
.

Returns a list of previously acquired spectrum images.

Data type

[Read only]
 List[
AdornedSpectrumImage
]

Remarks

The files are ordered by acquisition time, with the most recent acquisition first.
 Faulted acquisitions are also included in the list and can be downloaded. This means that incomplete acquisition results can also be downloaded and analyzed.

The files are only valid for a limited time. During the AutoScript startup sequence, the acquired files are checked, and all files older than 24 hours are deleted.

Examples

The example shows how the last acquired spectrum image can be downloaded:

# Get the last acquired spectrum image from the history
 last_spectrum_image = analysis.spectrum_image_history[0]

# Download and save the spectrum image to a file
 last_spectrum_image.save(r"C:\users\factory\desktop\last_spectrum_image.emd")

See also

acquire_spectrum_image()

acquire_spectrum_image()

title: auto_functions.run_auto_coma_correction
text:
.

Performs automatic coma correction. Available only in TEM mode.

Syntax

run_auto_coma_correction(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

The autofunction consists of two steps:

Measure coma by fitting Thon rings of a beam tilt tableau.

Automatically correct for measured coma error.

Most of the parameters in
RunAutoComaCorrectionSettings
 have default values and can be omitted.
 The first three parameters are linked to image acquisition and have the same meaning as the arguments to the

acquire_camera_image()
 function.
 The default values are documented on the
RunAutoComaCorrectionSettings
 page.

For information on supported camera types see members of the
CameraType
 enumeration.
 Running this autofunction with the

FLUCAM
 camera type is not supported.

The screen does not need to be retracted before calling this auto function; the acquisition part of the task manages it automatically.
 The selected detector is also inserted automatically.

Preconditions and recommendations:

Only available on systems without Image Corrector.

optical_mode
 must be
TEM
.

projector_mode
 must be
IMAGING
.

The microscope is properly aligned. Check the Direct Alignments (especially rotation center) and roughly correct objective astigmatism.

EPU / Auto Functions / Autofocus calibration has been performed.

Magnification calibrations have been performed.

A specimen is loaded which enables the display of Thon rings in the power spectrum of the TEM image.
 This is typically a thin amorphous carbon film, such as Quantifoil, Lacey Carbon, or a Cross Grating sample.

Spot size is 3 or higher.

Defocus is between -1 Âµm and -3 Âµm.

Magnification is approximately 150 kX.

The beam diameter can be narrowed a bit to increase signal strength.

Accurately set the specimen to eucentric height, using the Stage Alpha tilt wobbler.

If the coma error cannot be corrected within a specified number of iterations,
 the optical settings are reset to the state before the start of the correction procedure.

Examples

The following example shows how to run the auto coma correction routine with default parameters:

# Save settings into a variable with all optional settings left as defaults
 settings = RunAutoComaCorrectionSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA)
 # Run the auto coma correction routine with the created settings
 result = microscope.auto_functions.run_auto_coma_correction(settings)

Optional parameters can be added to the structure:

settings = RunAutoComaCorrectionSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 2, 5, tile_size=1024)
 microscope.auto_functions.run_auto_coma_correction(settings)

See also

RunAutoComaCorrectionSettings

acquisition.acquire_camera_image()

title: auto_functions.run_beam_tilt_auto_focus
text:
.

Runs a routine to automatically focus using the beam tilt method. Available only in TEM mode.

Syntax

run_beam_tilt_auto_focus(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Most of the parameters in
RunBeamTiltAutoFocusSettings
 have default values and can be omitted.
 The first three parameters are linked to image acquisition and have the same meaning as the arguments to the

acquire_camera_image()
 function.
 The default values are documented on the
RunBeamTiltAutoFocusSettings
 page.

For information on supported camera types, see the members of the
CameraType
 enumeration.
 Running this autofunction with the
FLUCAM
 camera type is not supported.

The screen doesn't have to be retracted before calling this auto function; the acquisition part of the task manages it automatically.
 The chosen detector is inserted automatically as well.

Preconditions and recommendations:

optical_mode
 must be
TEM
. To run auto focus in STEM mode, use
run_stem_auto_focus()
.

projector_mode
 must be
IMAGING
.

Calibration of the auto function must be performed on the microscope beforehand ("Focus TEM Stigmator" calibration).

A sample must be present and positioned at eucentric height.

If the auto function results with an error
'Auto Focus did not converge.'
,
 try setting the
maximum_iterations
 parameter to a higher value.

Examples

The following example shows how to run the autofocus routine with default parameters:

# Save settings into a variable with all optional settings left as defaults
 settings = RunBeamTiltAutoFocusSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA)
 # Run the auto focus routine with the created settings
 result = microscope.auto_functions.run_beam_tilt_auto_focus(settings)

Optional parameters can be added to the structure. Parameter names need not to be specified if the order is kept.

settings = RunBeamTiltAutoFocusSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA, 2, FocusMethod.STAGE_Z, maximum_iterations=10)
 microscope.auto_functions.run_beam_tilt_auto_focus(settings)

See also

RunBeamTiltAutoFocusSettings

acquisition.acquire_camera_image()

optics.defocus

title: auto_functions.run_objective_auto_stigmator
text:
.

Performs automatic defocus and objective astigmatism correction. Available only in TEM mode.

Syntax

run_objective_auto_stigmator(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Most of the parameters in
RunObjectiveAutoStigmatorSettings
 have default values and can be omitted.
 The first three parameters are linked to image acquisition and have the same meaning as the arguments to the

acquire_camera_image()
 function.
 The default values are documented on the
RunObjectiveAutoStigmatorSettings
 page.

For information on supported camera types see members of the
CameraType
 enumeration.
 Running this autofunction with the

FLUCAM
 camera type is not supported.

The screen doesn't have to be retracted before calling this auto function; the acquisition part of the task manages it automatically.
 The chosen detector is inserted automatically as well.

Preconditions and recommendations:

optical_mode
 must be
TEM
.

projector_mode
 must be
IMAGING
.

The microscope is properly aligned. Check the Direct Alignments (especially rotation center) and roughly correct objective astigmatism.

EPU / Auto Functions / Autofocus calibration has been performed.

The magnification calibrations have been performed.

A specimen is loaded which enables the display of Thon rings in the power spectrum of the TEM image.
 This is typically a thin amorphous carbon film, such as Quantifoil, Lacey Carbon, or a Cross Grating sample.

Spot size is 3 or higher.

Beam edge is not visible on Flucam.

Defocus is between -1 Âµm and -3 Âµm.

Magnification is approximately 150kX.

The beam diameter can be narrowed a bit to increase signal strength.

Accurately set the specimen to eucentric height, using the Stage Alpha tilt wobbler.

If the astigmatism cannot be corrected within a specified number of iterations,
 the optical settings are returned to the state before the start of the correction procedure.

Examples

The following example shows how to run objective auto stigmator routine with default parameters:

# Save settings into a variable with all optional settings left as defaults
 settings = RunObjectiveAutoStigmatorSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA)
 # Run the objective auto stigmator routine with created settings
 result = microscope.auto_functions.run_objective_auto_stigmator(settings)

Optional parameters can be added to the structure. Parameter names need not to be specified if the order is kept.

settings = RunObjectiveAutoStigmatorSettings(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 2, 5, tile_size=1024)
 microscope.auto_functions.run_objective_auto_stigmator(settings)

See also

RunObjectiveAutoStigmatorSettings

acquisition.acquire_camera_image()

title: auto_functions.run_opti_stem
text:
.

Runs OptiStem corrections with the specified parameters. Only available in STEM mode.

Syntax

run_opti_stem()
run_opti_stem(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

OptiStem (C1A1 and C1 corrections) is only available on the Titan TEM server v3.15 or Talos TEM server v2.15 and newer.
 OptiStem+ (B2A2 corrections) is only available on the Titan TEM server v3.19 or Talos TEM server v2.19 and newer.

The autofunction can currently be run in three different modes depending on the
method
 member of the settings parameter:

C1A1
 - correction of defocus + two-fold condenser astigmatism.

C1
 - correction of defocus.

B2A2
 - correcting coma B2 and three fold astigmatism A2.

All correction algorithms typically take less than a minute to complete.

All input parameters are optional, and if any are left out, the default values are used instead. Default values are dependent on the system.
 The
cutoff_in_pixels
 and
cutoff_spatial_frequency

can't be set in combination with
B2A2 method
.

Preconditions:

Examples

The following example shows how to run the OptiSTEM routine with the default parameters:

microscope.auto_functions.run_opti_stem()

The following example shows how to run the OptiSTEM routine with optional parameters:

settings = RunOptiStemSettings(method=OptiStemMethod.C1, dwell_time=2e-06, cutoff_in_pixels=5)
 microscope.auto_functions.run_opti_stem(settings)

See also

RunOptiStemSettings

RunOptiStemResults

optics.defocus

title: auto_functions.run_stem_auto_focus
text:
.

Runs a routine to automatically focus in STEM optical mode.

Syntax

run_stem_auto_focus(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Most of the parameters in
RunStemAutoFocusSettings
 have default values and can be omitted.
 The first three parameters are linked to image acquisition and have the same meaning as the arguments to the

acquire_stem_image()
 function.
 The default values are documented on the
RunStemAutoFocusSettings
 page.

The screen doesn't have to be retracted before calling this auto function; the acquisition part of the task manages it automatically.
 The chosen detector is inserted automatically as well.

Preconditions and recommendations:

Examples

The following example shows how to run the autofocus routine with default parameters:

# Switch to STEM optical mode
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM
 # Save settings into a variable with all optional settings left as defaults
 settings = RunStemAutoFocusSettings(DetectorType.HAADF)
 # Run the auto focus routine with the created settings
 result = microscope.auto_functions.run_stem_auto_focus(settings)

Optional parameters can be added to the structure. Parameter names need not to be specified if the order is kept.

settings = RunStemAutoFocusSettings(DetectorType.HAADF, 1024, 1e-5, true, reset_beam_blanker_afterwards=True)
 microscope.auto_functions.run_stem_auto_focus(settings)

See also

RunStemAutoFocusSettings

title: detectors.get_camera_detector
text:
.

Retrieves a camera detector by name.

Syntax

get_camera_detector(detector_name)

Parameters

detector_name

str

The name of the camera. Enumeration
CameraType
 can be used.

Return value

Examples

The following example shows how to create a camera detector object for all available camera detectors:

for camera_name in microscope.detectors.camera_detectors:
 camera = microscope.detectors.get_camera_detector(camera_name)

# print the name of the camera
 print(camera.display_name)

The following example shows how access the properties of a detector and it's methods:

# Get a Ceta camera object
 camera = microscope.detectors.get_camera_detector(CameraType.BM_CETA)
 print(camera.name)

# Insert the camera (if already inserted, do nothing)
 camera.insert()
 print(camera.insertion_state)

# Retract the camera (if already retracted, do nothing)
 camera.retract()
 print(camera.insertion_state)

See also

detectors.camera_detectors

title: detectors.get_eds_detector
text:
.

Retrieves an EDS detector by name.

Syntax

get_eds_detector(detector_name)

Parameters

detector_name

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
EdsDetectorType
 can be used.

Return value

Examples

The following example shows how to create an get an EDS detector object and some of it's properties:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Print detector name
 print(detector.name)

# Print detector display name
 print(detector.display_name)

# Inspect detector state and properties
 print(detector.insertion_state)
 print(detector.dispersions)
 print(detector.shaping_times)

text:
.

detector_name

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
EelsDetectorType

Return value

Examples

The following example shows how get and work with an EELS detector:

# Get the Zebra detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eels_detector(EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA)

# Print detector name
 print(detector.name)

# Print detector display name
 print(detector.display_name)

# Inspect detector state and properties
 print(detector.maximum_bin_count)

Retrieves a scanning detector by name.

get_scanning_detector(detector_name)

detector_name

The name of the detector. Enumeration
DetectorType

The following example shows how to create a scanning detector object for all available scanning detectors:

for detector_name in microscope.detectors.scanning_detectors:

title: detectors.scanning_detectors
text:
.

Returns the list of available scanning detectors on the microscope. Uses values from
DetectorType
.

Data type

[Read only]
 List[str]

Examples

The following example shows how to obtain and work with the BF-S detector and it's first inner segment:

detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)

print(detector.name)
 print(detector.insertion_state)

segment = detector.get_segment(DetectorSegmentType.INNER1)

print(segment.detector_name)
 print(segment.name)
 print(segment.is_enabled)
 print(segment.gain)
 print(segment.offset)

title: optics.aperture_mechanisms
text:
.

The collection of aperture mechanisms on the microscope.

Classes

Properties

C1

[Read only]
 The Condenser 1 aperture mechanism.

C2

[Read only]
 The Condenser 2 aperture mechanism.

C3

[Read only]
 The Condenser 3 aperture mechanism (if present).

objective

[Read only]
 The Objective aperture mechanism.

SA

[Read only]
 The Selected Area aperture mechanism.

Methods

Remarks

Only motorized aperture mechanisms are accessible. GetMechanism can be used to retrieve all supported aperture mechanisms on a given system, however
 the most widely used mechanisms are available in a form of property (the ones present on most systems). The GetMechanism function is intended
 for more rare mechanisms to keep the API clean and it also provides a way to enumerate and perform an action on all available mechanisms.

See also

ApertureMechanism

.

The beam diameter in meters. Only available on systems with three condenser lenses.

Data type

float

Accessing beam diameter is only available in
PARALLEL

illumination_mode
.

Examples

# Set illumination mode to parallel
 microscope.optics.illumination_mode = IlluminationMode.PARALLEL

# Set convergence angle to 3e-8 meters
 microscope.optics.beam_diameter = 3e-8

illumination_mode

title: optics.beam_stopper
text:
.

Provides access to the beam stopper device.

Properties

Methods

Remarks

The beam stopper is a simple needle that can be inserted into the beam to block the central diffraction spot.
 It is used to observe and correct the diffraction pattern.

.

Unblanks the beam. When unblanked, the sample is exposed to the beam.

illumination_mode
.

title: optics.deflectors
text:
.

Provides access to deflector lens.

Properties

beam_shift

The shift of the beam as a 2D vector in meters (x, y).

beam_tilt

The tilt of the beam as a unitless 2D vector (x, y). Ranges from -1 to +1 for both x and y.

gun_shift

The shift of the beam as a unitless 2D vector (x, y). Ranges from -1 to +1 for both x and y.

gun_tilt

The tilt beam in the gun as a unitless 2D vector (x, y). Ranges from -1 to +1 for both x and y.

image_shift

The shift of the image as a 2D vector in meters (x, y).

image_tilt

The tilt of the image as a 2D vector in radians (x, y), equivalent to diffraction shift.

Methods

title: optics.defocus
text:
.

[The property is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.17]

Data type

float

Remarks

Defocus value of the current
optical_mode
. Changing defocus will also change
focus
 and vice versa.
 Defocus is measured with respect to the origin that can be set by using

.

Examples

# Set defocus value to 8nm
 microscope.optics.defocus = 8e-9

title: optics.illumination_mode
text:
.

The illumination mode of the condenser system. Maps to
IlluminationMode
 enumeration. Only available on systems with three condenser lenses.

Data type

str

Remarks

Some Titan systems have only two condenser lenses and this makes the illumination system similar to Talos.
 On systems with three condenser lenses, lenses C2 or C3 can be switched off.

Examples

# Switch illumination condenser mode into two lens and turn C3 lens off
 microscope.optics.illumination_mode = IlluminationMode.C3_OFF

# Switch illumination condenser mode into probe and angle range to large
 microscope.optics.illumination_mode = IlluminationMode.PROBE_LARGE_ANGLE

# Switch illumination condenser mode back to parallel
 microscope.optics.illumination_mode = IlluminationMode.PARALLEL

See also

IlluminationMode

text:
.

Intensity value (not available in STEM mode).

Data type

float

Remarks

Intensity value is only available in
TEM

optical_mode
.
 The value roughly ranges from 0 to 1, on some systems the minimum value may be negative. Value is clipped when out of range.

Examples

# setting intensity to 0.1
 microscope.optics.intensity = 0.1
 print(microscope.optics.intensity)

# setting intensity to 0.3
 microscope.optics.intensity = 0.3

See also

title: optics.objective_lens_mode
text:
.

The objective lens mode. Maps to enumeration
ObjectiveLensMode
.

Data type

str

Remarks

Preconditions for Lorentz objective lens mode:

The other way to set objective lens mode is to use
set_projector()
 function.

Examples

Following example shows how to set objective lens mode:

# Switch objective lens off
 microscope.optics.objective_lens_mode = ObjectiveLensMode.LM

# Switch objective lens to HM
 microscope.optics.objective_lens_mode = ObjectiveLensMode.HM

title: optics.optical_mode
text:
.

The optical mode of the microscope. Maps to
OpticalMode
 enumeration.

Data type

str

Remarks

Optical mode change triggers setting a few other optical parameters to predefined default states:

Warning:
 predefined default states may have side effects on the optical subsystem.
 Best practice is to set up the optical mode in advance and be aware that changing the optical mode may cause other optical
 parameters (e.g. magnification) to change as well.

Examples

The following code shows how to change optical mode to STEM and then back to TEM:

microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.TEM

See also

OpticalMode enumeration

optics.projector_mode

optics.probe_mode

title: optics.paused_scan_beam_position
text:
.

The position of the beam in the full scan area when the scan is paused. Range: -1 to +1 for x and y.

Data type

Get:
Point
Set:
Point
 | list | tuple

Remarks

This property is only available on systems with STEM.

When setting the value, the coordinates of the given point can be None. That means the value of this axis will remain the same.

Examples

microscope.optics.paused_scan_beam_position = Point(0.2, 0.2)
 microscope.optics.paused_scan_beam_position = [0.5, 0.5] # List is used to modify the position
 microscope.optics.paused_scan_beam_position = (1, 0) # Tuple is used to modify the position
 microscope.optics.paused_scan_beam_position = Point(1.1, 0.5) # Error: value out of range!
 microscope.optics.paused_scan_beam_position = Point(0.5) # Set X to 0.5, keep Y as is
 microscope.optics.paused_scan_beam_position = Point(y=0.7) # Set Y to 0.7, keep X as is

See also

optics.optical_mode

.

# Set probe mode to nano probe
 microscope.optics.probe_mode = ProbeMode.NANO_PROBE

# Set projector mode to imaging

Resets the current
defocus

 Use it when the image is properly focused to adjust the defocus scale.

# Set defocus value to 8nm

# Reset defocus to zero
 microscope.reset_defocus()

# Defocus value is now zero
 print(microscope.optics.defocus)

title: optics.set_projector
text:
.

Sets the projector to magnification or camera length using information encoded in a text label.

Syntax

set_projector(label)

Parameters

Remarks

This function allows you to set several optical parameters at once. It can change the magnification, camera length,
 objective lens mode and/or projector mode.

Properties

available_values
 on classes

camera_length
 and

magnification
 can be used to get the list of valid values.

Label must contain three parts separated by spaces:

Projector mode identification:

Magnification modes:
Mh, Mi, SA, LM, Ltz SA, Ltz Mh
.

Camera length modes:
D, LAD, Ltz D
.

Camera length value / magnification value: nominal values are rounded.
 See
MagnificationData.label
 or

CameraLengthData.label
.

Unit:

Camera length units:
m
 (meter) for values > 1. For other values
mm
.

Magnification units:
Mx
 for values >= 1,000,000.
kx
 for values >= 100,000. For other values
x
.

Examples

Example of switching between different objective lens modes and magnifications:

# Set objective lens mode to HM and magnification to 4400 x
 microscope.optics.set_projector("SA 4400 x")

# Set objective lens mode to LM and magnification to 320 x
 microscope.optics.set_projector("LM 320 x")

# Set objective lens mode to Lorentz and magnification to 28500 x
 microscope.optics.set_projector("Ltz Mh 28500 x")

Example of switching between different projector modes:

# Set projector mode to imaging
 microscope.optics.set_projector("Mh 1.05 Mx")

# Set projector mode to diffraction
 microscope.optics.set_projector("D 470 mm")

Example of using magnification and camera length available values as parameters:

# Set projector to the first available magnification
 first_magnification = self.optics.magnification.available_values[0].label
 microscope.optics.set_projector(first_magnification)

# Set projector to the first available camera length
 first_camera_length = self.optics.camera_length.available_values[0].label
 microscope.optics.set_projector(first_camera_length)

See also

optics.magnification

optics.camera_length

optics.projector_mode

title: analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum
text:
..

Acquires a single EDS spectrum.

Syntax

acquire_spectrum(settings)

Parameters

Return value

AdornedSpectrum

The object containing both the EDS spectrum data and metadata describing the system state.

Remarks

The single spectrum acquisition only contains spectral data (1D array of energy values), no images are acquired.
 Information on which EDS segments were enabled during the acquisition can be found in the custom section of the spectrum metadata.

Examples

The following example shows EDS acquisition with the Super-X detector:

# Get the EDS detector object
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Configure the EDS acquisition
 settings = EdsAcquisitionSettings()
 settings.eds_detector = eds_detector.name
 settings.dispersion = eds_detector.dispersions[0]
 settings.shaping_time = eds_detector.shaping_times[0]
 settings.exposure_time = 3e-3
 settings.exposure_time_type = ExposureTimeType.REAL_TIME

spectrum = microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum(settings)

The next example shows the usage of detector segments:

# Get the EDS detector object
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Configure the EDS acquisition - same as in previous example
 settings = EdsAcquisitionSettings()
 # ...

# Configure the detector segments, enable first two segments only
 eds_detector.set_enabled_segments([EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1, EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT2])
 settings.detector_segments = eds_detector.get_enabled_segments()

# There is still only one spectrum result, but it was captured with only two segments
 spectrum = microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum(settings)

See also

eels.acquire_spectra()

EdsDetectorType

detectors.get_eds_detector

detectors.eds_detectors

title: analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum_image
text:
..

Acquires EDS spectrum image.

Syntax

acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Spectrum image acquisition is
not
 available in offline mode.

File representation

The acquired handle is associated with a file on the MPC disk. The handle is valid only for a limited amount of time.
 In the AutoScript startup sequence, the acquired files are checked and all files older than 24 hours are deleted.

The
save()
 method can be used to download the acquired
 data to the client. This method saves the spectrum image in a Velox EMD format.
 Information on the compatibility of the EMD file format can be found on the Extras/EMD file format page in the reference manual.

File contents

The data is hierarchically structured and uses the binary data format
HDF5
. The Python package h5py can be used to read the
 file directly. Alternatively, the Python package hyperspy or the Velox application can be used to read the file and/or further
 analyze the data.

The data is organized as follows:

Compressed spectrum cube + metadata

Acquired EDS events are compressed into a single cube using ThermoFisher's proprietary compression algorithm.
 Only Velox can be used to read and analyze the cube. Metadata have the same structrure as

AdornedImageMetadata
 but are stored in JSON format.

Information on which EDS segments were enabled during the acquisition can be found in the custom section of the cube metadata.

STEM images + metadata

All STEM frames are stored with the corresponding metadata. Metadata have the same structrure as

AdornedImageMetadata
 but are stored in JSON format.

A STEM detector can be specified either through a detector type (using
scanning_detectors

parameter) or through a list of segments (using
scanning_detector_segments

parameter). While it is possible to combine these two settings, it's important to note that a detector cannot be simultaneously defined by
 both its segment and its type. Each detector and segment individually capture an image.

EDS event streams + metadata

The EDS event stream has the form of (usually) uint16 values. Each value represents a number of counts detected for a particular pixel.
 The maximum value of the data type (usually 65535) is referred as gate pulse and signifies a change to the next pixel.
 Most multi-segment detectors collect a separate stream for each segment of the detector. Each frame of the event stream contains
 the corresponding metadata. Metadata have the same structrure as
AdornedImageMetadata

but are stored in JSON format.

Saving the (uncompressed) EDS event stream takes up a lot of memory. Setting the value of
save_eds_event_stream

setting deactivates saving.

Performance and limitations

To minimize acquisition time, it is recommended to restrict the scan region to a maximum of either 512x512 or 1024x1024 pixels.
 In our laboratory testing, we successfully acquired 500 frames without any data loss or signs of frame number limitations
 caused by processing bottlenecks. It appears that the only constraint on the number of frames is the resulting file size.

Examples

The following example shows EDS spectrum image acquisition with Super-X and HAADF detectors:

# Get the EDS detector object
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

title: analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum_image
text:
t appears that the only constraint on the number of frames is the resulting file size.

Examples

The following example shows EDS spectrum image acquisition with Super-X and HAADF detectors:

# Get the EDS detector object
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)
# Configure the EDS spectrum image acquisition
 settings = EdsSpectrumImageSettings(eds_detector=eds_detector.name,
 dispersion=eds_detector.dispersions[0],
 shaping_time=eds_detector.shaping_times[0],
 dwell_time=4e-6,
 size=ImageSize.PRESET_256,
 scanning_detectors=[DetectorType.HAADF])

# Acquire the spectrum image
 eds_spectrum_image = microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

# Save the spectrum image to disk (the object is just a handle for the data, we need to transfer it to the client)
 eds_spectrum_image.save(r"C:\temp\spectrum_image.emd")

The next example shows the use of EDS detector segments:

# Get the EDS detector object
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Configure the spectrum image acquisition - same as in previous example
 settings = EdsSpectrumImageSettings()
 # ...

# Configure the detector segments, enable first two segments only
 eds_detector.set_enabled_segments([EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1, EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT2])
 settings.eds_detector_segments = eds_detector.get_enabled_segments()

# Acquire the spectrum image
 eds_spectrum_image = microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

The next example shows the use of STEM detector segments (two detectors combined) and a rectangular region:

# Get the EDS detector object
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.ULTRA_X)

# Get the BF-S detector and select inner ring segments
 bf_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 bf_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

# Get the DF-S detector and select outer ring segments
 df_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 df_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING)

# Combine enabled segments
 segments = df_s.get_enabled_segments() + bf_s.get_enabled_segments()

# Configure the rectangle region (75x100 pixels)
 region = Region(coordinate_system=RegionCoordinateSystem.PIXELS, rectangle=[0, 0, 75, 100])

# Configure the EDS spectrum image acquisition
 settings = EdsSpectrumImageSettings(eds_detector=eds_detector.name,
 dispersion=eds_detector.dispersions[0],
 shaping_time=eds_detector.shaping_times[0],
 dwell_time=10e-6,
 region=region,
 scanning_detector_segments=segments)

# Acquire the spectrum image - the resulting file contains 8 STEM images (1 per segment of the two detectors)
 # Each STEM image has a size of 75x100 pixels
 eds_spectrum_image = microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

See also

Scanning

eels.acquire_spectrum_image()

eds.acquire_spectrum()

EdsDetectorType

detectors.get_eds_detector

detectors.eds_detectors

spectrum_image_history

title: analysis.eels.acquire_spectra
text:
..

Acquires single or multiple EELS spectra.

Syntax

acquire_spectra(settings)

Parameters

Return value

List[
AdornedSpectrum
]

List of objects containing both the EELS spectrum data and metadata describing the system state.

Remarks

The function acquires EELS (Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy) spectra from the microscope.
 To acquire the spectra,
EelsExposureSettings
 must be provided.
 Each exposure setting will output a spectrum, which is a 1D array of intensity values.

The function will return an error if the system does not contain an EELS strip detector.

Examples

The following example demonstrates how to acquire multiple EELS spectra with the Zebra detector and plot the raw pixel counts:

from matplotlib import pyplot as plot

# EELS acquisition settings with two different exposures
 settings = EelsAcquisitionSettings(
 eels_detector=EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA,
 eels_exposure_settings=[
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10e-3, drift_tube_energy_offset=16),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10e-3, drift_tube_energy_offset=36)
 ])

# Run the acquisition
 spectra = microscope.analysis.eels.acquire_spectra(settings)

# Plot each acquired spectrum
 for spectrum in spectra:
 plot.plot(spectrum.data)
 plot.show()

Results:

The next example shows how to read EELS related metadata:

# EELS acquisition settings with a single exposure
 settings = EelsAcquisitionSettings(
 eels_detector=EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA,
 eels_exposure_settings=[
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=1)
 ])

# Run the acquisition and collect the first (and only) spectrum
 spectrum = microscope.analysis.eels.acquire_spectra(settings)[0]

# Find first metadata custom property collection with an empty scope
 custom_properties = [property_list for property_list in spectrum.metadata.custom_properties
 if property_list.scope == ""][0].properties

# Find all EELS related custom properties
 eels_custom_properties = [custom_property for custom_property in custom_properties
 if custom_property.name.startswith("Detectors[Eels")]

# Print the found properties
 for custom_property in eels_custom_properties:
 print(f"{custom_property.name}: {custom_property.value}")

See also

acquire_spectrum()

EelsDetectorType

detectors.get_eels_detector

detectors.eels_detectors

title: analysis.eels.acquire_spectrum_image
text:
..

Acquires EELS spectrum image.

Syntax

acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Spectrum image acquisition is
not
 available in offline mode.

File representation

The acquired handle is associated with a file on the MPC disk. The handle is only valid for a limited time.
 During the AutoScript startup sequence, the acquired files are checked, and all files older than 24 hours are deleted.

The
save()
 method can be used to download the acquired
 data to the client. This method saves the spectrum image in a Velox EMD format.
 Information on the compatibility of the EMD file format can be found on the Extras/EMD file format page in the reference manual.

File contents

The data is hierarchically structured and uses the binary data format
HDF5
. The Python package h5py can be used to read the
 file directly. Alternatively, the Python package hyperspy or the Velox application can be used to read the file and/or further
 analyze the data.

The data is organized as follows:

EELS spectrum image + Acquisition metadata + Metadata

Acquired spectra are saved into a cube with dimensions of (width x bin count x height). There is one cube per exposure setting.
 Acquisition metadata is a simple JSON object with information about the acquisition (dispersion, offset, etc.).
 There is one acquisition metadata object per scan line of the image (eg. image with dimensions of 10x10 will have 10 acquisition metadata objects).
 Metadata have the same structrure as
AdornedImageMetadata

but are stored in JSON format. There is one metadata object per cube.

STEM images + metadata

All STEM frames are stored with the corresponding metadata. Metadata have the same structrure as

AdornedImageMetadata
 but are stored in JSON format.

A STEM detector can be specified either through a detector type (using
scanning_detectors

parameter) or through a list of segments (using
scanning_detector_segments

parameter). While it is possible to combine these two settings, it's important to note that a detector cannot be simultaneously defined by
 both its segment and its type. Each detector and segment individually capture an image.

Performance and limitations

This iteration of the SI acquisition is considered to be a minimum viable product. We will continue to iterate on it and add more features in the future.
 If you have any suggestions or requests, please let us know (see the
support
 page
 for contact info).

To minimize acquisition time, it is recommended to restrict the scan region to a maximum of 512x512 pixels. Keep in mind that the stability of the acquisition
 may not be optimal for larger regions. Data loss cancels the data saving in order to avoid corrupted files. If such a situation occurs, the acquisition will be
 stopped and an error will be raised. The function
spectrum_image_history

can be used to retrieve the incomplete file.

The maximum number of exposure settings is detector dependent. The dwell time must be higher than the sum of exposure times (plus the
 necessary overhead depending on the number of spectra and HW limitations).

Examples

The following example shows EELS spectrum image acquisition with Zebra and HAADF detectors:

title: analysis.eels.acquire_spectrum_image
text:
number of exposure settings is detector dependent. The dwell time must be higher than the sum of exposure times (plus the
 necessary overhead depending on the number of spectra and HW limitations).

Examples

The following example shows EELS spectrum image acquisition with Zebra and HAADF detectors:
# Configure the EELS spectrum image acquisition
 # The result will contain 3 spectrum cubes (one for each exposure setting) and 1 STEM image (HAADF)
 settings = EelsSpectrumImageSettings()
 settings.eels_detector = EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA
 settings.eels_exposure_settings = [
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10e-3, drift_tube_energy_offset=20),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10e-3, drift_tube_energy_offset=40),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10e-3, drift_tube_energy_offset=60)]
 settings.dwell_time = 35e-3
 settings.size = ImageSize.PRESET_512
 settings.scanning_detectors = [DetectorType.HAADF]

# Acquire the spectrum image
 eels_spectrum_image = microscope.analysis.eels.acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

# Save the spectrum image to disk (the object is just a handle for the data, we need to transfer it to the client)
 eels_spectrum_image.save(r"C:\temp\spectrum_image.emd")

The next example shows the use of STEM detector segments (two detectors combined) and a rectangular region:

# Get the BF-S detector and select inner ring segments
 bf_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 bf_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

# Get the DF-S detector and select outer ring segments
 df_s = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.DF_S)
 df_s.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.OUTER_RING)

# Combine enabled segments
 segments = df_s.get_enabled_segments() + bf_s.get_enabled_segments()

# Configure the rectangle region (75x100 pixels)
 region = Region(coordinate_system=RegionCoordinateSystem.PIXELS, rectangle=[0, 0, 75, 100])

# Configure the EELS spectrum image acquisition
 settings = EelsSpectrumImageSettings()
 settings.eels_detector = EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA
 settings.eels_exposure_settings = [EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10e-3, drift_tube_energy_offset=20)]
 settings.dwell_time = 20e-3
 #settings.region = region
 settings.scanning_detector_segments = segments

# Acquire the spectrum image - the resulting file contains 8 STEM images (1 per segment of the two detectors)
 # Each STEM image has a size of 75x100 pixels
 eels_spectrum_image = microscope.analysis.eels.acquire_spectrum_image(settings)

See also

Scanning

title: optics.aperture_mechanisms.get_available
text:
..

Retrieves a list of IDs of currently available aperture mechanisms. Uses values from
ApertureMechanismType
.

Syntax

get_available()

Return value

List[str]

List of available aperture mechanism types.

Remarks

The method returns a list of IDs (types) of currently available motorized aperture mechanisms.
 The IDs are strings that can be used to retrieve specific aperture mechanisms using the
get_mechanism()
 method.

Examples

for mechanism_type in microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.get_available():
 mechanism = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.get_mechanism(mechanism_type)

# Enable aperture mechanism and inspect its state
 mechanism.enable()
 print(f"{mechanism_type} enabled: {mechanism.is_enabled}.")

# Disable aperture mechanism and inspect its state again
 mechanism.disable()
 print(f"{mechanism_type} enabled: {mechanism.is_enabled}.")

See also

get_mechanism()

title: optics.aperture_mechanisms.get_mechanism

mechanism_type

 If

 Only motorized aperture mechanisms are supported.
