title: optics.blanker.beam_modulator
text:
..

Provides pulse width modulation control over the electron beam.

Classes

frequency

The frequency of the modulation in Hz.

Properties

duty_cycle

A fraction of one period in which a signal is active. Ranges between values larger than 0 but less than 1.

is_modulation_on

[Read only]
 True when pulse width modulation is running.

Methods

Remarks

The beam modulator controls electron beam current by adjusting beam pulses generated by a high-speed NanoPulser blanker. The

frequency
 and

duty_cycle
 parameters can
 be set before starting the modulation or changed while the modulation is running.

Beam modulation is stopped and its parameters reset back to default

even without explicitly calling

stop_modulation()

in 30s after script after script completion to ensure the system returns to its default state.

The frequency and duty cycle values may be set independently of each other, but they have to adhere to the following rules:

The chosen frequency has to inside the
frequency_limits

and the duty cycle has to be greater than 0 and less than 1.

Ratio of frequency over duty cycle (the pulse width) has to be greater than minimal pulse step legth.

Pulse width has to be greater than the minimal pulse step length (10 ns for NanoPulser).

The sum of the pulse width and the minimal pulse step length has to be less than the pulse period.

It is recommended that the modulation be stopped by calling

stop_modulation()

or by exiting the context manager before exiting the script.

Examples

The first example shows how beam_regulator_context can be used to reset the settings back to default after the acquisition:

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator
 with beam_modulator_context(beam_modulator, duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6):
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1)

The next example shows how the beam modulator parameters can be modified while beam modulation is active:

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator
 # start modulation with the given duty cycle and frequency
 with beam_modulator_context(beam_modulator, duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6):
 # Change the parameters while modulation is running
 beam_modulator.frequency.value = 1.1e6
 beam_modulator.duty_cycle = 0.7

The next example shows disabling the beam modulator explicitly without using the context manager:

# Start beam pulse width modulation with the given duty cycle and frequency
 beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator
 beam_modulator.start_modulation(duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6)

# Run acquisition with beam modulator enabled
 iamge = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1)

# Stop beam pulse width modulation
 beam_modulator.stop_modulation()

The next example shows how modulation parameters can be changed before starting the modulation:

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator

# Set the parameters before starting the modulation
 beam_modulator.duty_cycle = 0.2
 beam_modulator.frequency.value = 1e6

# Start beam pulse width modulation with the given duty cycle and frequency
 beam_modulator.start_modulation()
 print(beam_modulator.is_modulation_on) # True

# Stop modulation
 beam_modulator.stop_modulation()
 print(beam_modulator.is_modulation_on) # False

See also

beam_modulator_context()

title: optics.blanker.blank

..

Blanks the beam. When blanked, the sample is not exposed to the beam.

blank()

Remarks

Manually blanking the beam using the blank function overrides the auto beam blank
mode

 To restore automatic beam blanking the beam blank mode should be explicitly set again.

optics.blanker.auto_beam_blank.mode.value = AutoBeamBlankMode.BLANK_WHEN_IDLE

auto_beam_blank.mode

title: optics.blanker.unblank
text:

Unblanks the beam. When unblanked, the sample is exposed to the beam.

Remarks

Manually unblanking the beam using the unblank function overrides the auto beam blank
mode

 and will interfere with the automated blanking process.
 To restore automatic blanking the auto beam blank mode should be set again explicitly.

optics.blanker.auto_beam_blank.mode.value = AutoBeamBlankMode.BLANK_WHEN_IDLE

See also

auto_beam_blank.mode

title: optics.camera_length.increase
text:
..

Increases the camera length by steps (may be negative, will be clipped if necessary).

Syntax

increase(steps)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

The method is only available in
DIFFRACTION
.

Increase function iterates over
available_values
 collection. If the value is larger it gets clipped and the function sets the last possible value.
 Negative values are supported as well and clipping works the same way.

Examples

Index clipping is explained on following example:

# Set the last available camera length value
 microscope.camera_length.value = microscope.camera_length.available_values[-1]

# Increasing the camera length does nothing, because the current camera length
 # is the last possible value
 microscope.camera_length.increase(1)
 microscope.camera_length.increase(100)

# Negative steps value can be used to set the second-to-last value
 microscope.camera_length.increase(-1)

# Set the first available camera length value
 microscope.camera_length.value = microscope.camera_length.available_values[0]

# Decreasing the camera length does nothing, because the current camera length
 # is the first possible value
 microscope.camera_length.increase(-1)
 microscope.camera_length.increase(-100)

See also

optics.projector_mode

title: optics.deflectors.beam_shift
text:
..

The shift of the beam as a 2D vector in meters (x, y).

Data type

Get:
Point
Set:
Point
 | list | tuple

Remarks

The beam shift is a low level value representing the pure X and Y values in terms of coils.
 It is relative to the origin stored at the time of alignment,
 and no rotation correction is applied to it. In
STEM
,
 the rotation should be constant for a given STEM rotation.
 For navigation in the specimen space, see

move_to_pixel()
 function.

When setting the value, the coordinates of the given point can be None. That means the value of this axis
 will remain the same.

Examples

# Set beam shift to a new value
 microscope.optics.deflectors.beam_shift = Point(8e-6, 9e-6)

# Set beam shift to a new value with a list
 microscope.optics.deflectors.beam_shift = [8e-6, 9e-6]

# Set beam shift to a new value with a tuple
 microscope.optics.deflectors.beam_shift = (8e-6, 9e-6)

# Set beam shift to a new y value, leave x value as is
 microscope.optics.deflectors.beam_shift = Point(y=8e-6)

# Set beam tilt to a new y value, leave x value as is

title: optics.focusing.stem
text:
..

Focus control in the STEM optical mode.

Classes

intensity

Focus control of the condenser lens.

objective

Focus control of the objective lens. This is the default focus control mode in most applications.

Remarks

In STEM there are two different types of focus control: intensity and objective.

The intensity focus control is the default focus control mode in most applications, it controls the focus by changing
 the excitation of the condenser lens while objective focus remains fixed.
 Simply use intensity focus control when finer tuning is not required as this mode is the default in most applications.

Objective focus control changes the excitation of the objective lens while the intensity focus remains fixed. The
 objective focus control is used for finer focusing steps in higher magnifications and it is not available in LM mode.

The defocus value shown in TEM UI is a combination of the defocus values of the condenser and objective lenses and can be
 obtained by adding the values together.

title: optics.blanker.auto_beam_blank.mode
text:
...

Controls the auto beam blank mode.

Properties

Methods

Remarks

Default mode

Default auto beam blank mode differs based on the system's hardware configuration.

Auto beam blank mode is reset back to default

even without explicitly calling

reset_to_default()

in under 30s after script after script completion.

Mode is a system-wide setting of the auto beam blanker that controls blanking behavior in multiple scenarios including before and after an image acquisition.
 It can be set to one of three modes.
 See
AutoBeamBlankMode
 enumeration for more details.

Autofunctions
 may blank or unblank the beam irrespective of the
 configured auto beam blank mode value.

See also

auto_beam_blank_mode_context

reset_to_default()

AutoBeamBlankMode

title: optics.blanker.beam_modulator.start_modulation
text:
...

Starts the beam modulation.

Syntax

start_modulation()
start_modulation(duty_cycle)
start_modulation(duty_cycle, frequency)

Parameters

duty_cycle

float

frequency

float

Remarks

Calling start_modulation() without parameters starts the modulation with current modulation settings,
 when one parameter is provided modulation starts with the given modified duty cycle and current (or default on the first run) frequency.
 Duplicate start_modulation() calls have no effect.
 To adjust settings of a running modulation, use the properties

duty_cycle
 and

frequency.value
.

Calling start_modulation(duty_cycle) when modulation is already running changes the given parameter of the modulation.

See also

duty_cycle

frequency.value

is_modulation_on

stop_modulation()

title: optics.blanker.beam_modulator.stop_modulation
text:
...

Aborts beam modulation.

Syntax

stop_modulation()

Remarks

Calling stop_modulation() when modulation is not running or multiple times consecutively has no effect.

This method stops the beam pulse width modulation. This method is called implicitly in under 30 seconds after script execution finishes.

See also

start_modulation()

title: optics.blanker.auto_beam_blank.mode.reset_to_default
text:
....

Resets the Auto Beam Blank mode to its default value.

Syntax

reset_to_default()

Remarks

Auto beam blank mode is reset back to default

even without explicitly calling reset_to_default()

in under 30s after script after script completion.

The default mode differs based on system hardware configuration.

Examples

Calling reset to default restores the default mode.

beam_blank_mode = microscope.optics.blanker.auto_beam_blank.mode

beam_blank_mode.value = AutoBeamBlankMode.OFF
 print(beam_blank_mode.value) # OFF

beam_blank_mode.reset_to_default()
 print(beam_blank_mode.value) # BLANK_WHEN_IDLETEM

Reset to default is called implicitly when exiting the with block of the

auto_beam_blank_mode_context
 context manager.

See also

auto_beam_blank_mode_context

title: optics.blanker.beam_modulator.frequency.limits
text:
....

The permissible frequency range of the modulation in Hz.

Data type

[Read only]

Limits

Remarks

If a frequency value lays inside the limits, it may not be valid as the combination of frequency and duty_cycle parameters have to adhere to the following rules:

The ratio of frequency over duty cycle (the pulse width) has to be greater than minimal pulse step legth.

The pulse width pw = duty_cycle / frequency

Has to be greater than the minimal pulse step length (10 ns for NanoPulser).

The sum of the pulse width and the minimal pulse step length has to be less than the period of the modulation.

title: optics.energy_filter.energy_shift.value
text:

 Defocus is measured with respect to the origin that can be set by using

title: optics.focusing.tem.reset_defocus
text:
...

Resets defocus to 0 (and does not change focus).

Syntax

reset_defocus()

Remarks

Resets the current
defocus
 to zero. This does not change the
focus
 value (the focusing lens current).
 Use it when the image is properly focused to adjust the defocus scale.

Examples

# Set defocus value to 8nm
 microscope.optics.focusing.tem.defocus = 8e-9

# Reset defocus to zero
 microscope.optics.focusing.tem.reset_defocus()

# Defocus value is now zero
 print(microscope.optics.focusing.tem.defocus)

See also

focus

title: optics.focusing.stem.intensity.defocus
text:
....

Defocus value - offset from the condenser focus value (in meters).

Data type

float

Remarks

The total defocus is equal to the sum of objective and intensity defocus.

Examples

# Prepare optics
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM
 microscope.optics.objective_lens_mode = ObjectiveLensMode.HM

# Set defocus
 microscope.optics.focusing.stem.intensity.defocus = 5e-9
 microscope.optics.focusing.stem.objective.defocus = 6e-9

# Print defocus values
 intensity_defocus = microscope.optics.focusing.stem.intensity.defocus
 objective_defocus = microscope.optics.focusing.stem.objective.defocus
 print(f"Intensity defocus: {intensity_defocus}")
 print(f"Objective defocus: {objective_defocus}")
 print(f"Total defocus: {intensity_defocus + objective_defocus}")

title: optics.focusing.stem.intensity.focus
text:
....

Focus value of the condenser lens (in meters).

Data type

Remarks

# Prepare optics
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM
 microscope.optics.objective_lens_mode = ObjectiveLensMode.HM

# Set the focus
 microscope.optics.focusing.stem.intensity.focus = 5e-9
 microscope.optics.focusing.stem.objective.focus = 6e-9

# print focus values

 objective_focus = microscope.optics.focusing.stem.objective.focus
 print(f"Intensity focus: {intensity_focus}")
 print(f"Objective focus: {objective_focus}")
 print(f"Total focus: {intensity_focus + objective_focus}")

title: optics.focusing.stem.intensity.reset_defocus
text:
....

Resets condenser defocus to 0 (and does not change condenser focus).

Syntax

reset_defocus()

Remarks

Intensity defocus can be thought of as a relative offset from the focus plane of the condenser lens. When you reset the
 defocus, this offset is cleared, bringing it back to zero. This means that the current position of the condenser
 lens's focal plane is now considered the new reference point for any future offsets. The total defocus is the sum of the
 objective defocus and the intensity defocus.

Examples

# Reset defocus to zero for both intensity and objective defocus and print their values
 microscope.optics.focusing.stem.intensity.reset_defocus()
 microscope.optics.focusing.stem.objective.reset_defocus()

intensity_focus = microscope.optics.focusing.stem.intensity.focus
 objective_focus = microscope.optics.focusing.stem.objective.focus

print(f"Intensity defocus: {intensity_focus}")
 print(f"Objective defocus: {objective_focus}")
 print(f"Total defocus: {intensity_focus + objective_focus}")

text:

# Set defocus

Objective defocus can be thought of as a relative offset from the focus plane of the objective lens. When you reset the

 lens's focal plane is now considered the new reference point for any future offsets. The total defocus is the sum of the
 objective defocus and the intensity defocus.

Examples

title: service.autoscript.client
text:
..

Provides service information regarding the AutoScript client.

Properties

is_pause_requested

[Read only]
 Returns true if a pause of the currently executing script was requested.

is_stop_requested

[Read only]
 Returns true if a graceful stop of the currently executing script was requested.

version

[Read only]
 Returns the AutoScript client version.

Methods

check_pause_requested()

Checks whether a pause of the currently executing script has been requested. If so, waits until the resume is requested.

check_stop_requested()

Checks whether a graceful stop of the currently executing script has been requested. If so, raises KeyboardInterrupt exception.

title: service.autoscript.server
text:
..

Provides service information regarding the AutoScript server.

Properties

is_offline

[Read only]
 Tells whether the AutoScript server is running in the simulation (offline) mode.

version

[Read only]
 Returns the AutoScript server version.

title: service.offline.reset_image
text:
..

Resets the image source in the offline simulator back to the default image.

Syntax

reset_image()

Examples

# Load an image from disk and set it as a new simulation source
 microscope.service.offline.set_image(AdornedImage.load(r"C:\image.tiff"))

# Subsequent acquisitions will return the loaded image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1.0)

# Reset the image back to defaults
 microscope.service.offline.reset_image()

# Subsequent acquisitions will return the default simulated image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1.0)

See also

acquisition

service.autoscript.server.is_offline

service.offline.set_image()

title: service.offline.set_image
text:
..

Uploads an image into the offline simulator. AutoScript will return this image in all subsequent image acquisitions.

Syntax

set_image(image)

Parameters

image

AdornedImage

The image to set as the new source for simulated image acquisitions.

Remarks

The image will be resized to match the size specified in acquisition function parameters, but
 image metadata will not reflect this resizing.

Examples

# Load an image from disk, check its size and upload it to the simulator
 loaded_image = AdornedImage.load(r"C:\image.tiff")
 print(loaded_image.width) # 1024
 print(loaded_image.height) # 1024
 microscope.service.offline.set_image(loaded_image)

# Required size is the same, the simulator will provide the original image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1.0)

# Required size differs, the simulator will resize the image to 2048x2048
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 2048, 1.0)

See also

acquisition

service.autoscript.server.is_offline

service.offline.reset_image()

title: service.autoscript.client.check_pause_requested
text:
...

Checks whether a pause of the currently executing script has been requested. If so, waits until the resume is requested.

Syntax

check_pause_requested()

Remarks

The pause request can be created in two places -
AutoScript Runner
 or
PyCharm editor

Once the script execution is paused it is possible to resume it by creating a resume request.

If
check_pause_requested()
 is called but no pause request is created, the script will execute without pausing.

See also

User guide: Pause/Stop script execution

AutoScript Runner

PyCharm editor

title: service.autoscript.client.check_stop_requested
text:
...

Checks whether a graceful stop of the currently executing script has been requested. If so, raises KeyboardInterrupt exception.

Syntax

check_stop_requested()

Remarks

This function allows the user to specify the exact time and conditions that must be met for gracefully stopping the script execution.

The stop request can be created in two places -
AutoScript Runner
 or
PyCharm editor

If the stop request is made before the script executes
check_stop_requested()
, the execution of the script is stopped.

If
check_stop_requested()
 is called but no stop request is created the script will not stop on this line.

See also

User guide: Pause/Stop script execution

AutoScript Runner

PyCharm editor

title: specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits
text:
..

Returns limits of a piezo stage axis in meters or radians.

Syntax

get_axis_limits(axis)

Parameters

axis

str

The axis name. Enumeration
StageAxis
 can be used.

Return value

Limits

The Limits object containing limits of the specified piezo stage axis.

Remarks

Only one axis can be specified at a time. The name of the axis is case insensitive, i.e.

'x'
,
'X'
,

'StageAxis.X'
 are all allowed.

Examples

# Get limits for x axis
 limits = microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits(StageAxis.X)

# Print min and max values for X axis
 print(f"min: {limits.min}, max: {limits.max}")

title: specimen.piezo_stage.is_moving
text:
..

Returns true if the piezo stage is currently moving (jogging velocity is non-zero), false otherwise.

Data type

[Read only]
 bool

Remarks

The value is updated only every 200ms and is cached in the meantime.

Examples

The following example shows the use of
is_moving
 function in a simple waiting loop:

import time

# Start jogging with X axis
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(2e-6))

while microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.is_moving:
 # Sleep for half a second
 time.sleep(0.5)

# The piezo stage is no longer moving if the loop ended
 print("Jogging finished")

See also

specimen.piezo_stage.position

specimen.piezo_stage.jogging_velocity

specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging()

title: specimen.piezo_stage.relative_move
text:
..

Moves the piezo stage relatively to the current position.

Syntax

relative_move(relative_position)
relative_move(relative_position, max_velocity)

Parameters

relative_position

StagePosition
 | list | tuple

The delta position by which the piezo stage should move.

max_velocity

StageVelocity
 | list | tuple

Maximum velocity of the relative move, default value is 2e-6 m/s.

Remarks

Axes with value
None
 will not be affected by the move. The function checks the limits of all affected axes before moving.
 Use
get_axis_limits()
 function to get the limits. If the velocity is specified,
 the dimensions of the specified velocity and the position must match (i.e. if the position specifies the X and Y axes, the velocity must also specify the X and Y axes).

Unlike
start_jogging()
, the relative move function is not asynchronous and the function is not finished until the movement is complete.

Examples

The next example shows relative move with and without specified velocity:

# Relative move with default velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.relative_move(StagePosition(1e-6, 1e-6, 0.5e-6))

# Print the changed position
 print(microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.position)

# Relative move with specified velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.relative_move(StagePosition(1e-6, 1e-6, 0.5e-6), StageVelocity(1e-6, 1e-6, 1e-6))

# Print the changed position
 print(microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.position)

# A list or tuple can be used to specify piezo stage position or velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.relative_move([1e-6, 1e-6, 0.5e-6], (1e-6, 1e-6, 1e-6))

See also

specimen.piezo_stage.position

specimen.piezo_stage.reset_position()

specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits()

title: specimen.piezo_stage.reset_position
text:
..

Resets the piezo stage to the specified position while compensating the stage position at the same time.

Syntax

reset_position()
reset_position(reset_position)
reset_position(reset_position, max_velocity)

Parameters

reset_position

StagePosition
 | list | tuple

The piezo stage reset position coordinates. Default value is the center of the stage.

max_velocity

StageVelocity
 | list | tuple

Maximum velocity of the reset move, default value is 2e-6 m/s.

Remarks

The reset moves the piezo stage to the specified position while the corresponding stage axis remains in closed loop.
 This will cause the image to "wobble" as the stage attempts to compensate for the piezo movement.
 After the reset is complete, the specimen should be moved only minimally while the piezo axis has assumed a new position.
 If multiple axes are specified, the resets are performed sequentially.
 Unlike
start_jogging()
, the reset position function is not asynchronous and the function is not finished until the reset is complete.

The specified velocity may affect the accuracy of the reset movement. Tests have shown that a speed of 2Âµm/s (2e-6 m/s) is a fairly good default.
 Lower velocities may result in more accurate motion (and vice versa). The maximum speed is 100Âµs/s, it corresponds to the maximum speed of the stage.

Axes with value
None
 will not be affected by the reset. The function checks the limits of all affected axes before moving.
 Use
get_axis_limits()
 function to get the limits. If the velocity is specified,
 the dimensions of the specified velocity and the position must match (i.e. if the position specifies the X and Y axes, the velocity must also specify the X and Y axes).

The default position is in the center of the stage, i.e. each available axis is calculated as follows:

(axis_limits.min + axis_limits.max) / 2
.

Examples

The following example shows how to reset the piezo stage to minimal value on each axis:

# Fetch limits of each axis
 x_limits = microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits(StageAxis.X)
 y_limits = microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits(StageAxis.Y)
 z_limits = microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits(StageAxis.Z)

# Reset piezo stage position to minimal values with default velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.reset_position(StagePosition(x_limits.min, y_limits.min, z_limits.min))

The next example shows how the reset velocity can be specified:

# Reset piezo stage position with non-default velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.reset_position(StagePosition(x=1e-6, y=1e-6), StageVelocity(x=1e-5, y=1e-5))

# A list or tuple can be used to specify piezo stage position or velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.reset_position([1e-6, 1e-6], (1e-5, 1e-5))

See also

specimen.piezo_stage.position

specimen.piezo_stage.relative_move()

specimen.piezo_stage.get_axis_limits()

title: specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging
text:
..

Starts jogging at a given velocity. This function is asynchronous and returns immediately.

Syntax

start_jogging(jogging_velocity)

Parameters

jogging_velocity

StageVelocity
 | list | tuple

The velocity of the piezo stage movement.

Remarks

The jogging vector can be set up in a single
start_jogging
 call, or in multiple consecutive
 calls (e.g., one call per axis). If the jogging velocity is specified more than once for a single axis, the value is reset and
 only the last velocity is used.

Calling
reset_position()
 or

relative_move()
 stops the
 current jogging process on affected axes.
 The jog can also be explicitly stopped by calling

stop()
.
 If the jogging is not stopped, it will be aborted after it reaches the end of the stage. In this case no error will be raised.

Examples

The following example creates a simple jogging job with a given velocity vector:

import time

# Start jogging with X, Y axes
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=2e-6, y=4e-6))

while microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.is_moving:
 # Sleep for 0.25s
 time.sleep(0.25)

# Print current velocity and position
 print(microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.jogging_velocity)
 print(microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.position)

# The piezo stage is no longer moving if the loop ended
 print("Jogging finished")

The next example shows that jogging velocity could be specified multiple times:

# Start jogging with X axis
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=2e-6))

# Start jogging with Y axis, the X axis jogging is still going
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(y=4e-6))

# Reset X axis velocity with a new value
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=3e-6))

A list or tuple can be used to specify piezo stage velocity:

# Use a list to specify the velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging([2e-6])

# Use a tuple to specify the velocity
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging((2e-6, 4e-6))

See also

specimen.piezo_stage.jogging_velocity

specimen.piezo_stage.is_moving

specimen.piezo_stage.stop()

specimen.stage.start_jogging()

title: specimen.piezo_stage.stop
text:
..

Stops all movement on all axes.

Syntax

stop()

Examples

The following example shows the use of
stop()
 function to timeout a waiting loop:

import time

# Start jogging with Y axis
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(y=2e-6))

# Declare timeout and loop_tick in seconds
 timeout = 10
 loop_tick = 0.5

while microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.is_moving:
 # Sleep for the duration of the loop_tick, decrement timeout value
 time.sleep(loop_tick)
 timeout -= loop_tick

# If the timeout is reached, stop the jogging - it will end the loop
 if timeout <= 0:
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.stop()

# The piezo stage is no longer moving if the loop ended
 print("Jogging finished")

See also

specimen.piezo_stage.jogging_velocity

specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging()

specimen.stage.stop_jogging()

title: specimen.stage.absolute_move
text:
..

Moves the stage to a new position.

Syntax

absolute_move(position)

Parameters

position

StagePosition
 | list | tuple

The absolute position to which the stage should move.

Remarks

Axes with value
None
 will not be affected by the move.
 The stage must be in a ready state for the move to be successful. If the stage is being manipulated
 by another application or process, or the stage is currently jogging, the error message 'Stage not ready after X ms' is returned.
 Property
is_moving
 can be checked to
 make sure that the stage is not busy.

The function checks the limits of all affected axes before moving. You can use the

get_axis_limits()

function to get the limits.

Examples

Absolute move can move in one axis:

# Move X to 250 micrometers, do not move other axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(StagePosition(x=250e-6))

It can also move multiple axes in a single statement:

# Move X to 250 micrometers, Y to 300 micrometers and Z to 200 micrometers, do not move other axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(StagePosition(x=250e-6, y=300e-6, z=200e-6))

Tilt axes use radians,
math.radians()
 function helps to convert from degrees:

import math

# Move alpha tilt to 30 degrees and beta tilt to 5 degrees
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(StagePosition(a=math.radians(30), b=math.radians(5)))

Not all holders support all axes. When a given
StagePosition

contains unsupported axis, an error is returned:

print(microscope.specimen.stage.get_holder_type()) # SingleTilt

# Error: Selected specimen holder doesn't have beta axis.
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(StagePosition(b=math.radians(5)))

A list or tuple can be used to specify the stage position:

# Use a list to move X, Y, Z axes to the given coordinates
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move([250e-6, 300e-6, 200e-6])

# Use a tuple to move all axes to the given coordinates
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move((250e-6, 300e-6, 200e-6, math.radians(30), math.radians(5)))

See also

StagePosition

specimen.stage.absolute_move_safe()

speciment.stage.relative_move()

title: specimen.stage.get_axis_limits
text:
..

Returns limits of a stage axis in meters or radians.

Syntax

get_axis_limits(axis)

Parameters

axis

str

The axis name. Enumeration
StageAxis
 can be used.

Return value

Limits

The Limits object containing limits of the specified stage axis.

Remarks

Only one axis can be specified at a time. The name of the axis is case insensitive, i.e.

'x'
,
'X'
,

'StageAxis.X'
 are all allowed.

Examples

# Get limits for Y axis
 limits = microscope.specimen.stage.get_axis_limits(StageAxis.Y)

# Print min and max values for Y axis
 print(f"min: {limits.min}, max: {limits.max}")

title: specimen.stage.is_moving
text:
..

Returns true if the stage is currently moving, jogging, or wobbling. False otherwise.

Data type

[Read only]
 bool

Examples

import time

# Start jogging with X, Y axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=2.4e-10, y=4e-10))

# Print stage position each second until the stage stops moving
 while microscope.specimen.stage.is_moving:
 print(microscope.specimen.stage.position)
 time.sleep(1)

See also

specimen.stage.start_jogging()

specimen.stage.stop_jogging()

title: specimen.stage.move_to_pixel
text:
..

Centers the specified image point in the field of view.

Syntax

move_to_pixel(image_point, detector)
move_to_pixel(image_point, detector, settings)

Parameters

image_point

Point
 | list | tuple

Point coordinates in pixels.

detector

str

The name of the detector. Enumeration
CameraType
 or
DetectorType
 can be used.

settings

MoveToPixelSettings

Structure for additional setting parameters. All settings are default if not specified.

Remarks

The origin of the pixel coordinate system is in the upper left corner of the image.
 The pixel position does not have to be limited to the size of the image, it can also
 be outside the field of view or even be negative.

Several parameters needed for the pixel transformation are fetched from the current state of the system:

optical_mode
,
is_eftem_on
,
acceleration_voltage
,
illumination_mode
,
objective_lens_mode
,

probe_mode
,
projector_mode
,
camera_length
 or
magnification
.
 It is recommended to use scanning detectors only in
STEM

- otherwise the required calibrations might be missing.

By default, AutoScript assumes the maximum possible size of the image. In the case of STEM, this is the maximum scanning resolution
 of the system. In TEM, this value depends on the camera used; it is the maximum resolution of the camera. This may lead to incorrect
 transformations if the size is not properly specified.

Stage safety

Move to pixel uses safe stage moves by default, but in some cases it is needed to use unsafe moves instead. Parameter

use_safe_stage_moves
 can be used to override
 this behavior. It is recommended to use this option with caution.

Supported optical modes

Stage moves are supported only in
TEM
 +
IMAGING
 and

STEM
 +
DIFFRACTION
 mode combinations.
 The following table shows how the optical transformations are determined:

Examples

The first example shows move to pixel with any method in STEM optical mode:

# Set optical mode to STEM and diffraction
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM

# Set camera length to the largest value
 microscope.optics.camera_length.value = microscope.optics.camera_length.available_values[-1]

print(f"Stage position before: {microscope.specimen.stage.position}")
 print(f"Beam shift before: {microscope.optics.deflectors.beam_shift}")

# Move to the right by 20 pixels on the X axis (2068 - 4096 / 2 = 20 pixels)
 microscope.specimen.stage.move_to_pixel(Point(2068, 2048), DetectorType.HAADF,
 MoveToPixelSettings(method=MoveToPixelMethod.ANY))

print(f"Stage position after: {microscope.specimen.stage.position}")
 print(f"Beam shift after: {microscope.optics.deflectors.beam_shift}")

The next example shows move to pixel with optics method in TEM optical mode:

# Set optical mode to TEM
 microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.TEM

print(f"Image shift before: {microscope.optics.deflectors.image_shift}")

# Center image point [1024, 1024] - bottom right corner since the size of the image is also 1024
 microscope.specimen.stage.move_to_pixel(Point(1024, 1024), CameraType.BM_CETA,
 MoveToPixelSettings(image_size=1024, method=MoveToPixelMethod.OPTICS))

print(f"Image shift after: {microscope.optics.deflectors.image_shift}")

The next example shows that move to pixel can also be called without additional settings (all settings are default in this case):

print(f"Stage position before: {microscope.specimen.stage.position}")

title: specimen.stage.move_to_pixel
text:
oveToPixelMethod.OPTICS))

print(f"Image shift after: {microscope.optics.deflectors.image_shift}")

The next example shows that move to pixel can also be called without additional settings (all settings are default in this case):

print(f"Stage position before: {microscope.specimen.stage.position}")
# Center image point [1024, 1024]
 microscope.specimen.stage.move_to_pixel(Point(1024, 1024), CameraType.BM_CETA)

print(f"Stage position after: {microscope.specimen.stage.position}")

The next example shows that a list or a tuple can be used instead of point:

# Use a list to specify the move to pixel point
 microscope.specimen.stage.move_to_pixel([1024, 1024], CameraType.BM_CETA)

# Use a tuple to specify the move to pixel point
 microscope.specimen.stage.move_to_pixel((1024, 1024), CameraType.BM_CETA)

See also

optics.optical_mode

optics.deflectors.image_shift

optics.deflectors.beam_shift

MoveToPixelMethod

title: specimen.stage.position
text:
..

Returns the stage position (X, Y, Z) in meters, A and B in radians.

Data type

[Read only]

StagePosition

Examples

The following example shows how to obtain all the axes of the stage position:

position = microscope.specimen.stage.position

print("X:", position.x)
 print("Y:", position.y)
 print("Z:", position.z)

print("A:", position.a)
 print("B:", position.b) # None for single tilt holders

title: specimen.stage.relative_move
text:
..

Moves the stage relatively to the current stage position.

Syntax

relative_move(relative_position)

Parameters

relative_position

StagePosition
 | list | tuple

The delta position by which the stage should move.

Remarks

Axes with value
None
 will not be affected by the move.
 The stage must be in a ready state for the move to be successful. If the stage is being manipulated
 by another application or process, or the stage is currently jogging, the error message 'Stage not ready after X ms' is returned.
 Property
is_moving
 can be checked to
 make sure that the stage is not busy.

The function checks the limits of all affected axes before moving. You can use the

get_axis_limits()

function to get the limits.

Examples

Relative move moves the axis by addition. The following example moves x axis by 200 micrometers in two steps:

print(microscope.specimen.stage.position) # StagePosition(x=0, y=0, z=0, a=0)

# Step one, move by 100 micrometers in X
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move(StagePosition(x=100e-6))
 print(microscope.specimen.stage.position) # StagePosition(x=100e-6, y=0, z=0, a=0)

# Step two, move by 100 micrometers in X
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move(StagePosition(x=100e-6))
 print(microscope.specimen.stage.position) # StagePosition(x=200e-6, y=0, z=0, a=0)

Relative move can also move multiple axes at the same time. Tilt axes use radians,

math.radians()
 function helps to convert from degrees:

import math

# Move X, Y, Z by 100 micrometers and alpha and beta tilt by 5 degrees
 delta_position = StagePosition(x=100e-6, y=100e-6, z=100e-6, a=math.radians(5), b=math.radians(5))
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move(delta_position)

Not all holders support all axes. When a given
StagePosition

contains unsupported axes, an error is returned:

print(microscope.specimen.stage.get_holder_type()) # SingleTilt

# Error: Selected specimen holder doesn't have beta axis.
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move(StagePosition(b=math.radians(5)))

A list or tuple can be used to specify the stage position:

# Use a list to move X, Y, Z axes by the given coordinates
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move([100e-6, 100e-6, 100e-6])

# Use a tuple to move all axes by the given coordinates
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move((100e-6, 100e-6, 100e-6, math.radians(2), math.radians(2)))

See also

StagePosition

specimen.stage.relative_move_safe()

specimen.stage.absolute_move()

title: specimen.stage.relative_move_safe
text:
..

Moves the stage relatively to the current stage position. To avoid pole touches the tilt is first set to zero.

Syntax

relative_move_safe(relative_position)

Parameters

relative_position

StagePosition
 | list | tuple

The delta position by which the stage should move.

Remarks

Axes with value
None
 will not be affected by the move.
 The stage must be in a ready state for the move to be successful. If the stage is being manipulated
 by another application or process, or the stage is currently jogging, the error message 'Stage not ready after X ms' is returned.
 Property
is_moving
 can be checked to
 make sure that the stage is not busy.

The function checks the limits of all affected axes before moving. You can use the

get_axis_limits()

function to get the limits.

Examples

Relative move moves the axis by addition. The following example moves x axis by 200 micrometers safely in two steps:

print(microscope.specimen.stage.position) # StagePosition(x=0, y=0, z=0, a=0)

# Step one, move by 100 micrometers in X
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move_safe(StagePosition(x=100e-6))
 print(microscope.specimen.stage.position) # StagePosition(x=100e-6, y=0, z=0, a=0)

# Step two, move by 100 micrometers in X
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move_safe(StagePosition(x=100e-6))
 print(microscope.specimen.stage.position) # StagePosition(x=200e-6, y=0, z=0, a=0)

Relative move can also move multiple axes at the same time. Tilt axes use radians,

math.radians()
 function helps to convert from degrees:

import math

# Move X, Y, Z by 100 micrometers and alpha and beta tilt by 5 degrees safely
 delta_position = StagePosition(x=100e-6, y=100e-6, z=100e-6, a=math.radians(5), b=math.radians(5))
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move_safe(delta_position)

A list or tuple can be used to specify the stage position:

# Use a list to move X axis by the given coordinates
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move_safe([100e-6])

# Use a tuple to move X, Y, Z axes by the given coordinates
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move_safe((100e-6, 100e-6, 100e-6))

See also

StagePosition

title: specimen.stage.start_jogging
text:
..

Starts jogging at a given velocity. This function is asynchronous and returns immediately.

Syntax

start_jogging(jogging_velocity)

Parameters

jogging_velocity

StageVelocity
 | list | tuple

The velocity of the stage movement.

Remarks

The jogging vector can be set up in a single
start_jogging
 call, or in multiple consecutive
 calls (e.g., one call per axis). If the jogging velocity is specified more than once for a single axis, the value is reset and
 only the last velocity is used.

While the stage is jogging, it cannot be manipulated by other moves. The jog needs to finish or be stopped first
 (see
stop_jogging()
).
 No errors are raised if the jog is finished by reaching the end of the stage.

Examples

The following example creates a simple jog with a given velocity vector and terminates it after a specified time has elapsed:

import time

# Start jogging with X, Y axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=2.4e-10, y=4e-10))

print(microscope.specimen.stage.is_moving) # True

# Sleep for 10 seconds
 time.sleep(10)

# Stop jogging on all axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.stop_jogging()

print(microscope.specimen.stage.is_moving) # False

The next example shows that jogging velocity could be specified multiple times:

# Start jogging with X axis
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=2e-10))

# Start jogging with Y axis, the X axis jogging is still going
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(y=4e-10))

# Reset X axis velocity with a new value
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=3e-10))

A list or tuple can be used to specify the stage velocity:

# Use a list to set the velocity on the X axis
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging([1e-10])

# Use a tuple to set the velocity on the X, Y, Z axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging((1e-10, 1e-10, 1e-10))

See also

specimen.stage.stop_jogging()

specimen.stage.is_moving

specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging()

title: specimen.stage.stop_jogging
text:
..

Stops jogging on all axes.

Syntax

stop_jogging()

Remarks

The function stops all jogs currently running. If no axis is jogging, the function does nothing.
 The function does not stop other stage moves
 (
absolute_move()
,

relative_move()
, etc.).

Examples

The following example creates a simple jog with a given velocity vector and terminates it after a specified time has elapsed:

import time

# Start jogging with Z axis
 microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(z=2e-5))

print(microscope.specimen.stage.is_moving) # True

# Sleep for 10 seconds
 time.sleep(10)

# Stop jogging on all axes
 microscope.specimen.stage.stop_jogging()

print(microscope.specimen.stage.is_moving) # False

See also

specimen.stage.start_jogging()

specimen.stage.is_moving

specimen.piezo_stage.stop()

title: analysis
text:
Provides functions for chemical microanalysis of the sample.

Classes

eds

Provides functions for chemical microanalysis of the sample using an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) detector.

eels

Provides functions for chemical microanalysis of the sample using an electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) detector.

Properties

title: auto_functions
text:
Enables execution of the microscope autofunctions.

Methods

Remarks

Functions in this group on AutoScript API are considered experimental.

The function signatures are not guaranteed to be stable across AutoScript product versions.
 Behavior of the functions may vary depending on TEM system type and server software version.
 Both function signatures and behavior may evolve as new, optimized and more robust autofunctions are developed.

Each autofunction is designed to operate under specific optical conditions and with specific sample types.
 The functions may fail under other conditions or with other samples.
 For troubleshooting purposes each autofunction provides a return value that contains diagnostic information.

Autofunctions do not respect the configured auto beam blank
mode
,
 may manipulate the blanker manually and not return to the initial state which may therefore expose the sample for longer periods of time.
 Some autofunction's preconditions require the beam to be unblanked in which case the auto beam blank has to be set to

OFF
.

See also

auto_beam_blank.mode

title: TemMicroscopeClient.connect
text:
.

Connects the AutoScript client to the AutoScript server.

Syntax

connect()
connect(host, port)

Remarks

Repeated connections are not allowed. To connect to another host, the
disconect
 function must be called first.

Examples

The following code snippet shows how to initialize
TemMicroscopeClient
 and connect it to a running
 instance of the AutoScript server.

Calling the connect method without parameters will use the default microscope computer address of
192.168.0.1
.

# Create TemMicroscopeClient and connect it to the server running at 192.168.0.1
 microscope = TemMicroscopeClient()
 microscope.connect()

A custom IP address can be provided to the connect method:

# Connect to the server with a custom IP address of 10.140.15.1
 microscope.connect("10.140.15.1")

Custom host names are also supported:

# Connect to the server running at a computer with the hostname "TALOS":
 microscope.connect("TALOS")

If the server is running on a non-standard port, it must be specified:

# Connect to the server at IP address 10.140.15.1 and port number 6500
 microscope.connect("10.140.15.1", 6500)

The Connect method also accepts arrays of host addresses:

# Connect to the server at address 10.140.15.1. If the connection fails, try localhost and 192.168.0.1 consecutively.
 microscope.connect(["10.140.15.1", "localhost", "192.168.0.1"])

Each IP address in the array can also have its own port number (lengths of both arrays must be equal):

# Connect to the server at address 10.140.15.1:7500. If the connection fails, try localhost:4000
 microscope.connect(["10.140.15.1", "localhost"], [7500, 4000])

See also

disconnect()
.

title: detectors
text:
Exposes the detectors that are available and can be controlled by scripting.

Classes

screen

The main fluorescent screen of the microscope.

Properties

Methods

Examples

Acquire an image from all cameras on the microscope and save the images:

for camera in microscope.detectors.camera_detectors:
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(camera, 1024, 1e-3)
 image.save("C:/test/" + camera)

title: TemMicroscopeClient.disconnect
text:
.

Disconnects the AutoScript client from the AutoScript server.

See also

title: optics
text:
The microscope optical settings.

Classes

acceleration_voltage

Provides access to electron beam acceleration voltage.

aperture_mechanisms

The collection of aperture mechanisms on the microscope.

beam_stopper

Provides access to the beam stopper device.

blanker

Blanker group contains controls responsible for controlling the electron beam.

camera_length

Provides access to the camera lengths of the microscope.

deflectors

Provides access to deflector lens.

energy_filter

Provides access to energy filter (imaging filter) settings.

focusing

Allows you to control the focusing mechanisms of the microscope.

lenses

Provides a direct access to the lenses of the microscope.

magnification

Provides access to the TEM magnifications of the microscope.

monochromator

Provides access to the monochromator.

stigmators

Provides access to stigmators.

Properties

beam_diameter

The beam diameter in meters. Only available on systems with three condenser lenses.

convergence_angle

The beam convergence angle in radians. Only available on systems with three condenser lenses.

defocus

Defocus value is focus with an offset (in meters).
[The property is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.17]

focus

Focus value of the main imaging lens (in meters).
[The property is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.17]

illumination_mode

The illumination mode of the condenser system. Maps to
IlluminationMode
 enumeration. Only available on systems with three condenser lenses.

intensity

Intensity value (not available in STEM mode).

is_accelerator_on

[Read only]
 Returns true if the high voltage accelerator is on.

is_beam_blanked

[Read only]
 Returns true when the beam blanker is active.
[The property is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.21]

is_eftem_on

The EFTEM (Energy Filtered TEM) mode.

is_holography_mode_on

The holography mode.

is_xl_mode_on

The X Lens mode.

objective_lens_mode

The objective lens mode. Maps to enumeration
ObjectiveLensMode
.

optical_mode

The optical mode of the microscope. Maps to
OpticalMode
 enumeration.

paused_scan_beam_position

The position of the beam in the full scan area when the scan is paused. Range: -1 to +1 for x and y.

probe_mode

The probe mode of the condenser system. Maps to
ProbeMode
 enumeration.

projector_mode

The mode of the projector. Maps to
ProjectorMode
 enumeration.

scan_field_of_view

The field of view of the scan in meters. Applicable only in STEM mode.

scan_rotation

The rotation of the scan in radians. Applicable only in STEM mode.

spot_size_index

Index of currently selected spot size.

Methods

blank()

Blanks the beam. When blanked, the sample is not exposed to the beam.
[The method is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.21]

reset_defocus()

[The method is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.17]

set_projector()

Sets the projector to magnification or camera length using information encoded in a text label.

unblank()

Unblanks the beam. When unblanked, the sample is exposed to the beam.
[The method is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.21]

title: service
text:
Provides information and utilities regarding AutoScript.

Classes

autoscript

Provides service information regarding the AutoScript product.

offline

Additional AutoScript offline functionality.

system

Provides service information regarding the microscope system.

title: specimen
text:
Enables control and provides the status of sample manipulation devices.

Classes

piezo_stage

Provides piezo stage manipulation functionality.

stage

Provides access to the microscope stage (CompuStage or SmartStage).

title: TemMicroscopeClient
text:
Methods

connect()

This method connects the AutoScript client to the AutoScript server.

disconnect()

This method disconnects the AutoScript client from the AutoScript server.

Properties

server_host

[Read only]
 Returns the hostname of the AutoScript server to which the AutoScript client is currently connected.

Remarks

This is the top-level class of the
autoscript_tem_microscope_client
 package.
 It provides a wide range of functionality through its members, which are organized in a
static tree
.
 This page only contains information about functions related to server connectivity.
 The microscope API organized in the
static tree
 is documented separately.

AutoScript TEM Toolkit

AutoScript TEM Toolkit
 is a Python package that provides data processing capabilities
 in selected areas of electron microscopy. This package is a part of the AutoScript software suite.
 For more information, see other parts of this reference manual, in particular the

Microscope API
 package.

The toolkit contains four modules. Image-template matchers can be found in the module
Template matchers
.
 Help for computer vision tasks is provided through the
Vision
 module.
 User interface related functions can be found in the
User interface
 module.
 The
Context managers
 module allows for automatic resource management.

Please explore the following sections to find detailed information:

Returns the set auto beam blank mode to the default value after the with code block terminates by calling

reset_to_default()
.

Syntax

auto_beam_blank_mode_context(mode)

Parameters

mode

Mode

Auto beam blank mode object.

Examples

mode = microscope.optics.blanker.auto_beam_blank.mode

with auto_beam_blank_mode_context(mode, AutoBeamBlankMode.OFF):
 # Auto beam blank set to Off inside the with block
 stem_image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_image(DetectorType.HAADF, 1024, 1e-6)
 ...

# On with block exit reset_to_default() is called, default value is restored.

See also

Context managers

Auto Beam Blank

Start the beam modulation inside the with block by calling

start_modulation()
 and blanks it using

stop_modulation()
 upon exit from the
with
 block.

Syntax

beam_modulator_context(beam_modulator, duty_cycle, frequency)

Parameters

beam_modulator

BeamModulator

Microscope BeamModulator object

duty_cycle

duty_cycle

A fraction of one period in which a signal is active. Ranges from 0 to 1.

frequency

frequency

The frequency of the modulation in Hz.

Examples

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator

# Start beam pulse width modulation with the given duty cycle and frequency
 with beam_modulator_context(beam_modulator, duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6):
 print(beam_modulator.is_modulation_on) # True

# Modulation stopped, stop_modulation() called upon exiting the context manager
 print(beam_modulator.is_modulation_on) # False

See also

Context managers

BeamModulator

Unblanks the beam blanker inside the with block by calling

blanker.unblank()
 and blanks it using

blanker.blank()
 upon exit from the
with
 block.

Syntax

blanker_context(blanker)

Parameters

blanker

Blanker

Microscope blanker object

Examples

# blanked

with blanker_context(microscope.optics.blanker):
 # unblanked
 images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_images_advanced(settings)
 ...

# blanked again

See also

Context managers

Blanker

Context managers

Methods

Remarks

This module provides a set of context managers to automatically manage a given resource using Python's
with
 statement.
 The given resource is managed by automatically calling an initilization function on entry to the
with
 code-block and
 a clean-up function when the
with
 block terminates. The cleanup function is called even if the code inside raises an exception.

Examples

The following example demonstrates context manager syntax on the microscope's beam blanker.

# blanked here

with blanker_context(microscope.optics.blanker): # calls .unblank() here
 # unblanked
 ...

# blanked, .blank() was called

The insert context manager positions the given mechanism inside the microscope by calling

insert()
 and retracts it again by calling
retract()
. The resource is inserted inside
 the context manager - i.e. insert_context.

Syntax

insert_context(insertable)

Parameters

Examples

from autoscript_tem_toolkit.context_managers import insert_context

camera = microscope.detectors.get_camera_detector(CameraType.BM_CETA)
 print(camera.insertion_state)

with insert_context(camera):
 print(camera.insertion_state)
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(camera.name, 1024, 1.0)
 plot.imshow(image.data, cmap='gray')
 plot.show()

print(camera.insertion_state)

See also

Context managers

Retract context

The retract context manager withdraws the given mechanism from the microscope by calling

retract()
 and inserts it again by calling
insert()
.
 The resource is retracted inside the context manager - i.e. retract_context.

Syntax

retract_context(retractable)

Parameters

Examples

from autoscript_tem_toolkit.context_managers import retract_context

slit = microscope.optics.energy_filter.slit
 slit.width.value = microscope.optics.energy_filter.slit.width.limits.min

with retract_context(slit):
 unfiltered_image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1)

filtered_image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 1024, 1)

See also

Context managers

Insert context

class CustomTemplateMatcher(TemplateMatcher):

Opens a pop-up window displaying a plot of the provided image, given as an AdornedImage instance.
 The image is rendered using a grayscale palette.

Syntax

plot_image(image, label)

Parameters

image

AdornedImage

Image to be plotted.

label

[Optional] str

Label of the plot. If None, the label is automatically generated.

Remarks

The plot is interactive and allows the user to zoom in and out, pan, and save the plot as an image file.

Examples

The following example shows how to plot an acquired image with a custom label:

# Acquire a full frame image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, exposure_time=1)

# Display the image
 ui_toolkit.plot_image(image, "BM-CETA full frame image")

Opens a pop-up window displaying a plot where the provided spectra, given as AdornedSpectrum instances, are overlaid in a single figure.

Syntax

plot_spectra(spectra, labels)

Parameters

spectra

List[
AdornedSpectrum
]

Spectra to be plotted.

labels

[Optional] List[str]

Labels of the plots. If None, the labels are automatically generated.

Remarks

The function converts the raw data to primary electron counts and scale and offset corrected intensity values.
 For this conversion to be possible, the spectra have to have valid metadata. If the metadata are not valid, an error is raised.
 The number of labels can't be greater than the number of spectra, if any labels are missing, they are automatically generated.

The plot is interactive and allows the user to zoom in and out, pan, and save the plot as an image file.

Examples

The following example shows how to plot acquired EDS spectra with custom labels:

# Get the first EDS detector
 eds_detector_name = microscope.detectors.eds_detectors[0]
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(eds_detector_name)

spectra = []
 labels = []

# Acquire three spectra with different dispersions and shaping times
 for i in range(3):
 # Configure the acquisition
 settings = EdsAcquisitionSettings()
 settings.eds_detector = eds_detector_name
 settings.dispersion = eds_detector.dispersions[i]
 settings.shaping_time = eds_detector.shaping_times[i]
 settings.exposure_time = 3e-3
 settings.exposure_time_type = ExposureTimeType.LIVE_TIME

# Run the spectrum acquisition
 spectra.append(microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum(settings))
 labels.append(f"EDS spectrum {i + 1}")

# Plot the spectra
 ui_toolkit.plot_spectra(spectra, labels)

The next example shows how to plot acquired EELS spectra:

# EELS acquisition settings with multiple exposures
 settings = EelsAcquisitionSettings(
 eels_detector=EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA,
 eels_exposure_settings=[
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=1),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=5),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10)
 ])

# Run the acquisition
 spectra = microscope.analysis.eels.acquire_spectra(settings)

# Plot the spectra with default labels
 ui_toolkit.plot_spectra(spectra)

See also

plot_image()

plot_images()

plot_spectrum()

Adds a scale bar to the lower right corner of the image.

Syntax

add_scale_bar(image)

Parameters

image

AdornedImage

Image to which a scale bar is to be added.

Return value

Remarks

All combinations of encoding and bit depth valid for AdornedImage are supported.
 The input image has minimum size of 256x256 pixels. The image must also contain valid pixel size metadata:

image.metadata.binary_result.pixel_size
. Unit and prefix power are not required.
 If empty, a meter to the power of one is assumed.
 The scale bar is calculated for the horizontal axis (this is relevant if the pixel size is not a square).

The scale bar function returns a copy of the image, the original object is not changed. Note that when adding a
 scale bar to an image with low contrast, the result may appear darker due to the histogram shift.
 The contrast issue can be solved by stretching the histogram of the image before adding the scale bar.

The following figure shows a visual example of the scale bar in an RGB image:

Examples

The following example shows how to add a scale bar to an image and save it to disk as a png file:

# Acquire a full frame image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)

# Add a scale bar to the image
 image_with_scale_bar = vision_toolkit.add_scale_bar(image)

# Save the image to disk
 image_with_scale_bar.save(r"C:\ceta_image.png")

The next example shows how to add a scale bar to a low contrast image with histogram stretching:

# Stretch the histogram of the image - with outlier filtering
 stretched_image = vision_toolkit.stretch_histogram(low_contrast_image)

# Add a scale bar to the image
 image_with_scale_bar = vision_toolkit.add_scale_bar(stretched_image)

# Save the image to disk
 image_with_scale_bar.save(r"C:\low_contrast_image.png")

See also

stretch_histogram
.

Averages the pixel values of multiple images.

Syntax

average_images(images)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

The images must have the same dimensions, encoding, and bit depth. Only grayscale images are supported. Each pixel that exceeds
 the maximum value of the data type is set to the maximum value.

The given images are not modified. The result is a new image with the same dimensions, encoding, and bit depth as the input images.
 The result doesn't contain any metadata.

Examples

The following example shows how to create average image from the STEM segment ring:

# Configure the BF-S detector and enable the whole inner ring (4 segments)
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector(DetectorType.BF_S)
 detector.set_enabled_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)
 segments = detector.get_enabled_segments()

# Run the acquisition and average the recieved images
 inner_ring_images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_segment_images(segments, ImageSize.PRESET_512, 1e-6)
 inner_ring_average = vision_toolkit.average_images(inner_ring_images)

# Show the result
 pyplot.imshow(inner_ring_average.data, cmap="gray")
 pyplot.show()

Cuts out a portion of an image according to the specified target area definition.

Syntax

cut_image(image, [top_left, bottom_right, center, size, relative_center, relative_size])

Parameters

image

AdornedImage
 or
numpy.ndarray

Image to cut out a part from.

top_left

Point
 or a point-like object.

Top left point of the cut area, in pixels.

bottom_right

Point
 or a point-like object.

Bottom right point of the cut area, in pixels.

center

Point
 or a point-like object.

Center of the cut area, in pixels.

size

Point
 or a point-like object.

Size of the cut area, in pixels.

relative_center

Point
 or a point-like object.

Center of the cut area, in relative coordinates in the range [0, 1].

relative_size

Point
 or a point-like object.

Size of the cut area, in relative coordinates in the range [0, 1].

Return value

AdornedImage
 or
numpy.ndarray

Cut taken from the image in the same format as the input image.

Remarks

Please note that only the following combinations of parameters are valid: top left and bottom right, center and size, or relative center and relative size.

The method can accept both
AdornedImage
 and
numpy.ndarray
 for
image
 parameter.
 The cut is then provided in the same form.

Examples

The following example shows cutting the image with various parameter combinations:

# Acquire a full frame image and prepare a feature template
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)

# Cutting the image with the top left and bottom right parameters
 # The result is a top left quarter of the image
 cut_result = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, top_left=Point(0, 0), bottom_right=Point(2048, 2048))

# Cutting the image with the center and size parameters
 # The result is a 100x100 px crop centered around the [256, 256] coordinates
 cut_result = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, center=Point(256, 256), size=Point(100, 100))

# Cutting the image with the relative center and relative size parameters
 # The result is a half of the image taken from the center
 cut_result = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, relative_center=Point(.5, .5), relative_size=Point(.5, .5))

This class contains various information about a feature located in an image. It is a result type of
locate_feature()
 method.

Methods

print_all_information()

This method prints all available information in a well-formatted, human-readable manner.

Properties

confidence

Level of confidence with which the feature was located in range between [0, 1] corresponding to 0% - 100%.

center_in_pixels

Coordinates of the center of the feature in the original image, in pixels.

center_in_meters

Coordinates of the center of the feature in the original image, in meters. For more information on coordinate system, see the notes below.

shift_in_pixels

Shift of feature from its original position, in pixels. See the notes below for more information.

shift_in_meters

Shift of feature from its original position, in meters. See the notes below for more information.

Remarks

This module uses the
template_matchers
 module for
image template matching

Examples

Import vision package from AutoScript Toolkit:

import autoscript_tem_toolkit.vision as vision_toolkit

Finds the position of the specified template image in an image.

Syntax

locate_feature(searched_image, feature_template, [template_matcher, original_feature_center])

Parameters

searched_image

AdornedImage

Image to be searched for feature.

feature_template

AdornedImage

Template of the feature to be located.

template_matcher

TemplateMatcher

Template matcher to be used when matching template against the searched image. See the Remarks section for more information.

original_feature_center

Point
 or a point-like object.

Center of the original feature location, in pixels. The information is used for shift calculation.

Return value

Remarks

The optional
template_matcher
 parameter can provide an object derived from the

TemplateMatcher
 class.
 If not provided, the default template matcher
OpencvTemplateMatcher
 is used.
 For more information, see the documentation for the
Template matchers
 module.

The optional
original_feature_center
 parameter serves as input for calculating the image shift.
 If provided, the resulting
FeatureLocation

structure will contain the feature shift data. When not provided, only the current feature position is returned.

The result contains properties in meters (
center_in_meters
,
shift_in_meters
)
 only if the given image contains pixel size metadata.

Examples

The following example shows how to use the locate feature functionality with various template matchers:

# Acquire a full frame image and prepare a feature template
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)
 template = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, relative_center=[0.40, 0.40], relative_size=[0.20, 0.20])

# Locate the feature in the original image using the default (OpenCV based) template matcher
 opencv_location = vision_toolkit.locate_feature(image, template)

# Locate the feature in the original image using the Histogram of Gradients template matcher
 hog_location = vision_toolkit.locate_feature(image, template, HogMatcher(microscope))

# Inspect the results
 opencv_location.print_all_information()
 hog_location.print_all_information()

# Plot the results using the plot_match function
 ui_toolkit.plot_match(image, template, opencv_location.center_in_pixels)
 ui_toolkit.plot_match(image, template, hog_location.center_in_pixels)

Opens a pop-up window displaying a plot where the provided spectra, given as AdornedSpectrum instances, are overlaid in a single figure.

[The method is deprecated and will be removed in version 1.19]

Syntax

plot_spectra(spectra, labels)

Parameters

spectra

List[
AdornedSpectrum
]

Spectra to be plotted.

labels

[Optional] List[str]

Labels of the plots. If None, the labels are automatically generated.

Remarks

This method has been moved to the user_interface module.

The function converts the raw data to primary electron counts and scale and offset corrected intensity values.
 For this conversion to be possible, the spectra have to have valid metadata. If the metadata are not valid, an error is raised.
 The number of labels can't be greater than the number of spectra, if any labels are missing, they are automatically generated.

The plot is interactive and allows the user to zoom in and out, pan, and save the plot as an image file.

Examples

The following example shows how to plot acquired EDS spectra with custom labels:

# Get the first EDS detector
 eds_detector_name = microscope.detectors.eds_detectors[0]
 eds_detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(eds_detector_name)

spectra = []
 labels = []

# Acquire three spectra with different dispersions and shaping times
 for i in range(3):
 # Configure the acquisition
 settings = EdsAcquisitionSettings()
 settings.eds_detector = eds_detector_name
 settings.dispersion = eds_detector.dispersions[i]
 settings.shaping_time = eds_detector.shaping_times[i]
 settings.exposure_time = 3e-3
 settings.exposure_time_type = ExposureTimeType.LIVE_TIME

# Run the spectrum acquisition
 spectra.append(microscope.analysis.eds.acquire_spectrum(settings))
 labels.append(f"EDS spectrum {i + 1}")

# Plot the spectra
 vision_toolkit.plot_spectra(spectra, labels)

The next example shows how to plot acquired EELS spectra:

# EELS acquisition settings with multiple exposures
 settings = EelsAcquisitionSettings(
 eels_detector=EelsDetectorType.ZEBRA,
 eels_exposure_settings=[
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=1),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=5),
 EelsExposureSettings(exposure_time=10)
 ])

# Run the acquisition
 spectra = microscope.analysis.eels.acquire_spectra(settings)

# Plot the spectra with default labels
 vision_toolkit.plot_spectra(spectra)

Normalizes and stretches the histogram of the given grayscale image. Removes outliers if the threshold is provided.

Syntax

stretch_histogram(image, [outlier_threshold])

Parameters

image

AdornedImage

Input image.

outlier_threshold

float

Threshold for outlier filtering. The value must be in (0.5, 1) interval. If None, no filtering is used.
 Default value is 0.999.

Return value

Remarks

The histogram is stretched to cover the entire range of the bit depth. Images with signed data types are stretched
 to the negative values. Non-grey scale images are not supported. The function returns a copy of the image, the original
 object is not changed.

The outlier filtering algorithm calculates the histogram of the image. For each bin of the histogram, it calculates the ratio
 of the counts to the total number of pixels. The ratios are then cumulatively summed from the both sides of the histogram.
 After the threshold is reached, the algorithm stops and a new minimum/maximum is found.

Examples

The following example shows how to stretch the histogram of an image and save it to disk as a bmp file:

# Acquire a full frame image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)

# Stretch the histogram of the image without outlier filering
 stretched_image = vision_toolkit.stretch_histogram(image, outlier_threshold=None)

# Save the image to disk
 stretched_image.save(r"C:\ceta_image.bmp")

# Stretch the histogram of the image with outlier filering
 stretched_image = vision_toolkit.stretch_histogram(image)

# Save the image to disk
 stretched_image.save(r"C:\ceta_filtered_image.bmp")

AutoScript introduction

The chapters listed below offer insights into key AutoScript concepts. We recommend reviewing all chapters before
 writing your first script.

Getting started

API design principles

Concurrency

Acquisition overhead

This page documents the operational time overhead of the acquisition, i.e., the theoretical time of the acquisition
 compared to the expected time of the acquisition. If you encounter significantly higher differences than the values
 presented here, please contact
support
.

STEM Acquisition

The theoretical acquisition time of the STEM acquisition is the time needed for the microscope to visit each pixel
 (typically
size * size
) of the image and acquire the data for the amount of time specified in the acquisition
 (dwell time). It can thus be calculated as:
theoretical_time = dwell time * number of pixels
.

The actual time must take into account more factors: the movement of the beam between the pixels and the flyback
 (move to the next row of pixels), the settling time of the beam, the time needed for software processing of the data,
 and the time needed for serializing the data. If remote scripting is used (see

installation configurations
), the time
 needed for communication between the Support PC and the Microscope PC must also be considered.

The following measurements were made by ignoring the communication time of the acquisition, as this value is too dependent on the
 network configuration and the load of the network to be considered in a general case.
