API design principles

Design principles of AutoScript

The following design principles provide a clear set of guidelines to ensure the API's usability, stability, and
 consistency:

Easy to use:

The API should be user-friendly while offering powerful functionality.

Minimizing breaking changes:

Changes that could break existing scripts are minimized. Experimental features are marked, indicating a
 higher likelihood of breaking changes (e.g. autofunctions).

SI units are preferred:

Standard International (SI) units are preferred for consistency and clarity.

Consistency:

Similar functionalities should behave in a consistent manner for better user understanding.

Explicit errors instead of silent ones:

When functionality doesn't meet user expectations, raise explicit errors rather than failing silently. For example, if a function is called with an invalid combination of arguments,
 an error should be raised instead of presuming what the user probably intended. This guides the user to use the API correctly instead of guessing.

One exception to this rule is when the user tries to set a state that is already set in the system. In this case, the call is executed without an error, but the system state remains unchanged.

Same API on every type of microscope:

Scripts using the API should be portable across different systems with the same capabilities.

Minimizing internal state:

AutoScript server is designed to have as little internal state as possible since the microscope server
 itself should hold state information. In cases where this is not possible, the state is not shared between different
 clients/scripts, i.e. each client has its own internal state. This reduces the complexity of the entire
 script ecosystem. In most cases, the only places where a changing internal state needs to be taken into account are
 the microscope server and the user script itself.

Reoccurring patterns

The AutoScript API is designed to be consistent. Concepts with similar functionality are modeled in the same way
 and their behavior
 conveys further information about the microscope's internal state.
 The following are some of the recurring patterns in the API:

Value and available values pair

Properties representing a state have a value property and a method returning a collection of available
 values. The value property represents the current state and the available values method returns a
 collection of currently accessible states. An empty collection signifies that no values are accessible
 at the current microscope state and an exception is thrown when the values are inaccessible due to
 missing hardware.

Value and limits pair

Functions that retrieve or adjust continuous values within allowable ranges are usually represented by a
 pair of properties: value and limits. The limits property returns the Limits structure that defines the
 upper and lower value thresholds.

Settings structures

hardware.

Value and limits pair

Functions that retrieve or adjust continuous values within allowable ranges are usually represented by a
 pair of properties: value and limits. The limits property returns the Limits structure that defines the
 upper and lower value thresholds.

Settings structures
Functions that take numerous optional input parameters are designed to accept a single "settings" parameter,
 as an instance of a data class with optional items. This approach allows the settings structures to be easily
 expanded with new items without having to change function signatures.
 The naming convention for the settings structure often mirrors the name of the function for which it is
 intended. For example, RunStemAutoFocusSettings is a settings structure intended for the
 auto_functions.run_stem_auto_focus() function. However, there are exceptions to this convention, where
 the settings structure serves a broader purpose, for instance is utilized for multiple functions.

Synchronicity

By default, functions in the API are designed to be synchronous, meaning they return whenever all effects of the
 action on the microscope hardware and software have subsided. There are some exceptions to this rule, whenever an
 asynchronous version of the function is available, it is usually named with the word
"Start"
 to
 denote the asynchronicity. For example microscope.specimen.stage.start_jogging() starts the jogging process and
 returns control immediately back to the script (without waiting for the jogging to finish).

Breaking change strategy

The following breaking change strategy provides a structured approach to manage intentional changes that could
 impact existing users:

Documentation:

All intentional breaking changes are documented in the Release notes.

Smaller breaking changes:

Smaller changes or fixes are usually documented without additional actions.

Larger breaking changes:

Old functionality is marked as obsolete.

A recommended alternative is provided.

At least four full version releases have to pass before the old feature is removed.

Obsoleted parts of the API are removed.

Changes considered as breaking

Removal or renaming of any part of the API. This includes groups, functions, enums, structures, etc.

Changing the order of function arguments.

Changing the order of arguments in structure initializations.

Removing or changing part of metadata.

Removing support for file formats. Specific image encodings and bit-depth combinations, emd file versions,
 etc.

Upgrading Python version in the pre-installed environment. This usually means a large number of packages is
 upgraded as well.

Changes
not
 considered as breaking

Addition of new optional function argument or structure parameter.

Changing a generic error to a specific one.

Fixing the behavior of a function that resulted in an error.

Addition of a new enumeration value.

Upgrade of a Python package to its newest version in the pre-installed environment.

Exceptions

When a function call encounters an error, an exception is raised in the user code.
 Exceptions originating from the AutoScript server are consistently of the

ApplicationServerException
 type.
 However, exceptions originating from the AutoScript client can vary in type. While
ApiException
 is
 common, sometimes a more specific exception, like
ValueError
 or
IndexError
, is thrown to
 better detail the error.

Regardless of the type, every exception includes a message explaining the error in a human-readable way.

Enumerations

Functions in the AutoScript API intentionally avoid using parameters of enumeration type
 (i.e., classes derived from the Enum class in Python) to describe states, opting instead for simple types like

pe, every exception includes a message explaining the error in a human-readable way.

Enumerations

Functions in the AutoScript API intentionally avoid using parameters of enumeration type
 (i.e., classes derived from the Enum class in Python) to describe states, opting instead for simple types like
int
 or
string
.
 This design choice is made to ensure flexibility in both AutoScript and the underlying software platform release
 cycles. In scenarios where a newer version of the microscope platform introduces new states that are unknown to an older
 version of AutoScript, these new modes can be still provided as parameters to functions as plain strings or integers.

However, AutoScript does define

enumeration classes
,
 which provide named constants to be used in place of strings or integers.
 This approach helps prevent typos and enhances the readability of the code.

# The following lines are equivalent, the latter is preferred
 microscope.optics.lenses.get_lens("C2")
 microscope.optics.lenses.get_lens(LensType.C2)

Concurrency

Support for multiple clients

AutoScript facilitates the simultaneous execution of multiple scripts.
 Technically speaking, the AutoScript server can handle concurrent access from multiple AutoScript clients.

The server employs an
input command queue
 mechanism. When a scripting command is received by the
 server, it is placed in an input queue for processing. All connected clients share this queue,
 effectively serializing their requests on the microscope hardware and preventing potential collisions
 or unwanted interference with executed operations.

While this architecture offers clear advantages, there are also potential complications to consider.
 For example, a long-lasting synchronous command, such as executing a lengthy patterning job,
 can block the input queue for a significant period.

During this time, the AutoScript server will only queue up additional commands without processing them.
 If the calling script needs to maintain control over the microscope while such a lengthy action is in progress,
 it must opt for
asynchronous control
. With such approach, the script initiates the long-lasting
 action asynchronously, immediately freeing the input queue for other commands.

The majority of long-lasting synchronous API functions in the AutoScript API have an asynchronous alternative.
 You can easily identify asynchronous functions by the presence of the word "start" in their names.

Below is an example of an asynchronous command that runs stage jogging:

import time

# Start jogging with X, Y axes
 microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.start_jogging(StageVelocity(x=2e-6, y=4e-6))

while microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.is_moving:
 # Sleep for 0.25s
 time.sleep(0.25)

# Print current velocity and position
 print(microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.jogging_velocity)
 print(microscope.specimen.piezo_stage.position)

# The piezo stage is no longer moving if the loop ended
 print("Jogging finished")

Session resource management

The AutoScript server supports the concept of
session managed resources
.
 The resources' lifetime is bound to a specific client session.
 This is mainly done for resources that have to have a cleanup action performed when they are no longer needed
 (such as when calling stop() or when a session ends without an explicit stop call).

Currently the following resources are session managed:

When a new client tries to modify an existing session managed resource it will take over the ownership of that resource, invalidating access from any previous client.
 All clients can access read only properties of the managed resource, but only one client can modify (set) it at a time.

Below is an example that demonstrates possible side effects when multiple sessions interact with a session managed resource.

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator

# 1.
 beam_modulator.start_modulation(duty_cycle=0.5, frequency=1e6)
 print(beam_modulator.duty_cycle) # 0.5

# 3.
 beam_modulator.stop_modulation()
 print(beam_modulator.is_modulation_on) # !!! True, second client claimed ownership over the resource.

beam_modulator = microscope.optics.blanker.beam_modulator

# 2.
 beam_modulator.start_modulation(duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6)
 print(beam_modulator.duty_cycle) # 0.2

Support for multithreading

The AutoScript client class is designed to be thread-safe, allowing it to be accessed simultaneously
 from multiple threads without the need for any locking mechanism.

beam_modulator.start_modulation(duty_cycle=0.2, frequency=1e6)
 print(beam_modulator.duty_cycle) # 0.2

Support for multithreading

The AutoScript client class is designed to be thread-safe, allowing it to be accessed simultaneously
 from multiple threads without the need for any locking mechanism.
However, as described in the previous chapter, invoking the client object from multiple threads does
 not lead to parallel processing of the commands. Instead, they are still placed in the input queue
 on the server side and processed in series.

About the EMD file format

The EMD file format stands for
E
lectron
M
icroscopy
D
ata and
 is also known as the Velox experiment file. This file contains not only images, but it is a proprietary
 container that can contain the following:

Acquisition results, such as images, spectras, plots, and maps.

Post-processing results.

Experiment log.

The EMD file is based on the open format
HDF5

(
H
iearchic
D
ata
F
ormat Version
5
).
 It is possible to use HDF5 software or libraries to read the EMD files (e.g. h5py package in Python).
 However, it is recommended not to use the libraries to write or modify the EMD files, as this may corrupt
 the file and make it unreadable by Velox or AutoScript. See snippets for examples of how to read EMD files
 with the h5py package.

EMD version support

Backward compatibility

The EMD file format evolves with the new versions of Velox and has its own version. Backward compatibility is achieved by
 converting the files to a newer version. Velox does this automatically by saving the old file version in a new format.
 In AutoScript, a
conversion function

must be called explicitly to convert the file to the new EMD version.

EMD file format version used by this version of AutoScript is
4.3
.

Forward compatibility

Forward compatibility is not supported. This means that older versions of AutoScript and Velox will not be able to open files
 that were saved in the newer versions of both applications.

AutoScript and Velox release cycles

AutoScript and Velox release cycles are synced, and the newest version of AutoScript will always support the files saved by the
 newest version of Velox and vice-versa. The newest versions of both Velox and AutoScript are available

here
.

Getting started

This section will walk you through the process of creating and executing a test project with the AutoScript
 software.

It is assumed that the product has been installed in the recommended

Remote scripting configuration
.

On the Microscope computer:

Start the microscope server.

Prepare the system for TEM image acquisition

The vacuum system and electron beam gun are in an operational state.

Specimen is in a position suitable for imaging.

Check the taskbar tray to ensure that the AutoScript Server icon is blue.

A blue icon indicates that the AutoScript Server is running and that all prerequisites for executing
 scripts are met. If you don't see the icon, launch the AutoScript Server from the Start menu by
 navigating to
Thermo Scientific AutoScript > AutoScript Server
.

On the Support computer

(or more specifically on the computer where the AutoScript Client software is installed.)

Open PyCharm Community Edition.

If PyCharm is started for the first time, then:

Accept the JetBrains Privacy Policy: Tick
I confirmâ¦
 and select

Continue
.

At the data sharing options, select
Don't send
.

In the PyCharm welcome screen, select
New Project
.

In Location, enter the folder name for the new project:
"Test"
. This will also be the name of
 the new project.

Keep the Python interpreter option set to the preselected
"Python 3.11 (AutoScript)"
 option.

Press
Create
.

When creating the first project in PyCharm with the specific interpreter settings,
 it scans Python packages installed with that interpreter. This process is called

indexing
.
 During indexing, the editor's functionality is limited, and scripts cannot be executed.

Wait for the indexing to finish.
 This may take up to 15 minutes.

In the Project panel, right-click on the Test project and select
"New > AutoScript File with
 Examples"
.

Enter the filename for the new script:
"test"
. The script file will be saved as
test.py
.

In the script, locate the function

microscope.connect()

This function, when called with no parameters, will attempt to contact the AutoScript server at the
 default microscope computer IP address 192.168.0.1. If you intend to run the script locally on
 the microscope PC (you are in

Local scripting
 configuration
), modify the command to:

microscope.connect("localhost")

In the Project panel, right-click on
test.py
 and select
Run test
.

After closing the window with the acquired image, the "
Example script finished successfully
"
 appears in the output panel.

Installation configurations

Two essential components of the AutoScript TEM product are
the server
 and
the client
.
 The product installer provides the possibility to install these components in different configurations with respect to the
 typical network architecture of TEM systems.
 The specifics of each configuration are described below.

Remote scripting configuration

This is the preferred and most common installation configuration for systems with a standalone
Support PC
,
 which is connected to the
Microscope PC
 via the Support network.

The AutoScript server component is installed on the Microscope PC and the client is installed on the Support PC
 along with the
Python distribution
 and
PyCharm Editor
.

Python scripts are executed on the Support PC, passing the IP address of the Microscope PC to the
connect()

function on the
TemMicroscopeClient
 object.

The advantage of this configuration is that the Python development environment does not interfere with the rest of
 the microscope software ecosystem on the Microscope PC.

Local scripting configuration

In this configuration, all product components are installed on the
Microscope PC
 and the Python scripts are
 executed from there.

The
TemMicroscopeClient
 object must be connected
 to the locally running server with the hostname "localhost", as described in the
user guide
.

This is not a preferred configuration, it is often used as a workaround when the Support PC is not available on the TEM system.

Offline configuration

In this configuration, all product components are installed on any (non-MPC) computer, such as a personal laptop, and the Offline product license is activated there.
 The offline environment provides a safe environment for development and debugging of scripts without any effects on the real system.

For more information about the offline mode, see the
Offline mode
 page.

Client-only configuration

With this configuration, only the AutoScript TEM client is installed on an arbitrary PC and the server installation is skipped completely.

The client component alone gives you the opportunity to explore the capabilities and "feel" of AutoScript TEM at an elementary level
 without actually being able to run the scripts.

The Python editor will provide standard syntax checks and code completion hints for the API calls.
 Tools for managing the
Python environment
, all documentation and the database of code examples
 (
AutoScript Snippets
) will also be fully functional.

This configuration does not include any form of microscope simulation.
 No product license is required for this installation setup.

Offline mode

If the AutoScript server is installed on a non-MPC computer, it starts in offline mode. In this mode, the server operates disconnected from
 the microscope and forwards all API calls to the built-in TEM simulator. An offline license is required to use AutoScript in offline mode.

An offline AutoScript license cannot be used on an MPC. On an MPC, a non-offline license is required to connect to the microscope.

Offline mode of AutoScript can be installed on any computer that meets the minimum hardware requirements specified in the installation manual.
 Offline mode supports both local and remote
scripting configurations

(i.e., clients can connect to the offline server hosted over a network), although the local configuration is simpler and therefore recommended.

Simplistic modeling

The transmission electron microscope is a complex device.
 The integrated microscope model does not attempt to accurately simulate all of this complexity.
 Most API functions intended to control the state of the microscope function as a simple read/write cache.
 A value written by the property setter is stored and returned when the getter is called.
 This means, for example, that changing the value of beam tilt has no effect on other optical properties.

The state of the simulator is not persisted.
 When AutoScript server is restarted, the simulator is reset to its initial state and the current state is lost.

Image acquisition

Images output from the detectors or cameras are not visually affected by the state of the microscope or acquisition settings.
 Static 16-bit images are provided, but in the correct size and format.
 AutoScript allows you to upload a custom simulation image using the

service.offline.set_image()

function. This can be particularly useful for simulating parts of the workflow that involve image processing.

Image metadata are simulated as well. Images are created with metadata structures that capture the simulated system state.
 However, metadata may be incomplete in some areas, e.g. in camera detector settings.

Auto functions

Offline auto functions are not simulated, except for simple input and/or state checks.
 The result values are filled with zeros.

Offline system properties

Maximum acceleration voltage: 300kV.

Three condenser lens system, C3 aperture is not motorized.

Lorentz mode not supported.

Double tilt stage (x, y, z, a, b).

Cameras: BM-Ceta, BM-Falcon (Falcon 3 EC), Flucam.

STEM available, scanning detectors: BF, DF2, DF4, HAADF, BF-S, DF-S.

Stigmators: condenser, diffraction, objective.

System initial state

Vacuum state is ready.

Specimen holder is set to double tilt.

FEG is operational, acceleration voltage: max value.

Objective lens mode: HM.

Projector mode: Imaging.

Magnification: approximately 50k.

Scanning

In the scanning mode (
STEM
) of the microscope,
 images are acquired by moving a focused beam in a raster pattern across the specimen and collecting
 a signal at each (x,y) pixel coordinate. The signals from all pixels together form the STEM image.

Scan engine

Scan engine is a hardware component that controls the movement and focus of the beam. It synchronizes the detectors and the beam position to ensure the data
 are acquired at the right time. There are several types of synchronizations:

Hardware synchronization: The scan engine is connected to the detector directly.

Software synchronization: The scan engine pauses it operation after each point, line or a frame and the cameras are notified via SW.

Size and region

Size defines the outer boundary of the scan area. It is specified in pixels and is limited by the maximum scan size (which is determined by the license).
 In AutoScript, size can be set with a single integer value that defines the size of the square scan area. The size argument is often optional, and if not set,
 the default value is the maximum scan size. Region defines a scan pattern that can outline the scan area in a more flexible way. Currently, the only supported
 region is the rectangular region. All regions must be positioned inside the scan area and can be defined using relative or absolute coordinates.
