Product components

This section covers the main components of the AutoScript product.
 Explore the chapters below to delve into the details of each component.

AutoScript server

AutoScript client for Python language

AutoScript toolkit for Python language

PyCharm editor

Python 3 distribution

AutoScript tools

Jupyter Notebook

AutoScript TEM Server Control Panel

The AutoScript server is a service running on the microscope computer, responsible for executing scripting
 commands received over the TCP/IP network from Python scripts.
 It is configured to start automatically on startup of the operating system. Its status is indicated by an icon in
 the system tray, displaying the letters "AS".

A blue icon signifies that the server is ready to accept scripting commands, while a gray icon indicates a not-ready
 state. Which may be caused by a lack of proper licensing, inactive microscope server software, or a manually stopped
 AutoScript server.

The
AutoScript Server Control Panel
 provides insights into the server's internal state.
 You can open this panel by either double-clicking the "AS" icon or navigating to

Start > Thermo Scientific AutoScript > AutoScript Server
.

Control Panel context menu

By right-clicking the "AS" icon, you can access a context menu that contains useful links to the reference manual,
 other AutoScript components, and a link that copies the current IP address of the microscope computer to the clipboard.

The Open Log button is only available with an active internal license.

Overview

On the
Overview
 page, a summary of the server's state is displayed, featuring three sections marked
 with green check marks under normal conditions. In the event of an error, a red cross mark appears along with an
 error description.

Licensing

The
Licensing
 page presents a list of active product and feature licenses and tools for managing them.

To apply a product license key, it must first be registered for use on the microscope computer by clicking the

Register
 button
 and entering the key. Subsequently, the key must be activated by pressing the
Activate
 button,
 which opens a popup window requiring user details. Activation data need to be submitted to the online licensing
 server, which requires access to a computer connected to the internet, like a personal laptop.

To apply a feature license key choose the desired feature from the dropdown list and then follow the same procedure
 as for the product license key.

Before uninstalling, the key should be deactivated using the
Deactivate
 button.

Additionally, AutoScript can be activated for a 90-day trial period by clicking the

Activate Trial License
 button.

For more detailed information on licensing procedures, refer to the AutoScript installation manual or
 contact Thermo Fisher Scientific service team.

Networking

The
Networking
 page enables configuration of the TCP/IP port on which the AutoScript server listens
 for incoming scripting commands. While typically unnecessary to change the port under normal circumstances,
 it can be useful in resolving conflicts with other software using the same TCP/IP port on the computer where
 AutoScript client is installed.

To change the port, first, stop the server by pressing
Stop
, enter the new port number,
 and then resume the server by pressing
Start
.

The IP address panel allows for quick copying of the IP address the servers runs on. If there are multiple, the selected one is copied.
 This selection is shared with the tray menu 'Copy IP Address' button and is remembered through server restarts.

AutoScript tools

This section provides an overview of the three utilities bundled with AutoScript, designed to elevate user
 experience.

Choose from the following chapters to delve deeper into each utility:

AutoScript Runner

AutoScript Snippets

AutoScript Package Manager

AutoScript Package Manager

The AutoScript Package Manager is a user interface extension designed for the

Enthought Deployment Manager
 command line tool (EDM).
 It simplifies the management of installed packages, removing the need to interact with EDM's command line interface.

On the left side
(1)
, the tool displays the list of available packages on the Enthought Deployment
 Server along with license information for each package.
 Packages can be filtered according to their license by clicking the License button
(4)

and selecting the desired license types.
 On the right side
(2)
, a list of currently installed packages in the active Python environment is
 displayed, along with version information and a status indicator.
 The status color is green if the package version is the most recent available version.
 The status is orange if a newer version exists on the deployment server.

You can easily add a new package by first selecting it in the left pane and then clicking the
Install
 Selected Version
 button. Similarly, you can update or remove an installed package by selecting it in
 the right pane and clicking the
Update to Latest Version
 or
Uninstall Package

buttons.

Note that installing or updating a Python package resolves the entire chain of dependencies on other packages.
 Therefore, adding or updating a single package may result in adding or updating multiple dependent packages.
 You will be asked to review and approve the list of packages to be added or updated before the changes are applied.

The two search boxes at the top
(3)
 help you quickly navigate to the desired package by removing
 all packages that do not contain the entered text in their name.

Package Manager also provides the capability to create or remove virtual environments using the

Environment
 button
(6)
.
 You can create a new environment with or without AutoScript packages. The drop-down button
(5)

presents a list of all local Python environments. Selecting an environment will activate it within the Package Manager,
 and the right-side pane will be refreshed to display the packages installed in that specific environment.
 Environments can be also deleted, with the exception of the default "AutoScript" environment.

The Package Manager requires an active Internet connection.

For more information about the Package Manager, please refer to the chapters on
package management
 and
environment management
.

AutoScript Runner

AutoScript Runner is a convenient tool designed as a launcher for Python scripts, which can utilize AutoScript API functions
 or work independently. It serves as a preferred option for executing scripts that are already finely tuned and do not require
 further editing.

A typical use case is to open a folder with multiple scripts using the
File/Open Folder
 menu.
 The Runner scans the folder for Python source files and identifies the startup scripts as those that contain AutoScript initialization
 code or the function main(). These scripts are listed in the script selector
(1)
.
 If the script is documented with an introductory comment, this comment is displayed in the upper pane
(2)
 for the selected script.

When you click the
Run
button, the script is executed by a Python interpreter from the selected
 virtual environment
(6)
. You can choose an environment created using the AutoScript Package Manager or
 select your own.

All output is directed to the Output panel
(3)
, which can be expanded or collapsed by clicking the arrow icon
(7)
.
 The status of the script execution is displayed in the status bar
(5)
 at the bottom of the window.

It is also possible to pause or stop a running script
(4)
, provided that the script has implemented regular checks of the control signals
 (see functions

check_pause_requested()
 and

check_pause_requested()
).
 This mechanism allows you to define convenient break points where consistency of collected data and microscope state is ensured.
 If you have inadvertently requested a pause or stop, you can undo the action by clicking the Request button
(4)
 again
 before the script reaches the check method.

If the pause or stop is requested but the check functions are not called by the script, its execution will not be
 affected.

Meaning of icon colors:

- the buttons are disabled, request can not be sent. Either the script is not running or another action has already been requested.

- the buttons are clickable and clicking them will request the corresponding action.

- the corresponding action has been requested. It is possible to cancel the request at this moment by clicking the buttons.

- the script execution has been paused. The script execution resumes by clicking the button.

In the current version of the Runner, it is not possible to read user input from the console.

AutoScript Snippets

AutoScript Snippets is a useful browser that provides access to a database of simple Python code samples,
 showcasing various AutoScript API calls. One of its notable features is the ability to perform full-text
 searches, allowing users to quickly find relevant code snippets based on specific keywords.

In the left pane
(1)
, the code snippets are arranged in categories.
 When you enter text in the search box
(2)
, the set of snippets is filtered to show only those
 that contain the entered text either in the name of the snippet or anywhere in the code of the snippet.

Use the Copy button
(3)
 to copy the snippet to the clipboard.

Use the Show / Hide Init Code
(4)
 To toggle the visibility of the top panel containing common
 initialization code (such as imports or connecting to server).

Default snippets are stored in

C:\ProgramData\Thermo Scientific AutoScript TEM\CodeSnippets
.
 To add custom snippets, you can either add them to this directory or create a new one. The tool can display snippets from
 multiple source directories if you use the
File/Append Snippets folder
 menu function.

Jupyter Notebook

Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web application that allows you to create and share documents that contain live code, equations, visualizations, and narrative text. It is widely used for data cleaning and transformation,
 numerical simulation, statistical modeling, data visualization, machine learning, and much more. Jupyter Notebooks support numerous programming languages, including Python, R, and Julia, making it a versatile tool for data scientists and researchers.
 To learn more about Jupyter Notebook, visit the official website:
https://jupyter.org/
.

AutoScript comes with Jupiter Notebook pre-installed. It is available in the Start menu by navigating to
Thermo Scientific AutoScript > Jupyter Notebook
.

PyCharm Editor

PyCharm is a dedicated Python Integrated Development Environment (IDE) from
JetBrains
.
 It provides a wide range of essential tools for Python developers, tightly integrated to create a convenient
 environment for productive
 data science development.

The AutoScript TEM product includes the PyCharm Community editor. A detailed user manual for PyCharm IDE can be
 found online on the vendor's website

https://www.jetbrains.com/help/pycharm
.

During product installation, PyCharm is extended
 with custom plugins that provide AutoScript-specific functionality. Below is a screenshot of the PyCharm editor
 with the AutoScript extensions installed:

Microscope API Browser

The panel visualizes the microscope API structure and allows you to easily navigate between objects,
 their methods and properties. Double-clicking on an API element copies a code snippet to the editor area.
 additionally double-clicking on the root
Microscope
 element copies the AutoScript initialization code to the
 editor. Additional functions are available from the context menu.

Image Viewer

The panel can be used during code debugging to visualize the contents of variables of type
AdornedImage
.
 This is especially useful when applying image processing routines to the image, as you can immediately see the
 effects of the processing.
 To add a variable to the panel when debugging, type its name in the text box at the bottom or right-click the variable in the
 "Variables" tool window and choose "View as Image".

Integrated documentation

Pressing Shift + F1 while the cursor is on an API element, such as class, method or property, opens this
 reference manual to a page describing the
 details of the element, often with usage examples.

Pause/Stop requests

PyCharm with AutoScript plugins installed allows creating requests to pause or graceful stop of the script
 execution at a specific script
 line (see
User guide: Pause/Stop script
 execution
).
 Pause or stop requests can be created directly in the PyCharm editor thanks to the AutoScript plugin.

The AS icon in the main toolbar shows a drop-down menu with "Request Pause" and "Request Stop"
 entries displayed. These buttons that can be clicked during script execution. The stop or pause request can be
 cancelled by clicking the given button again.

Button color schemes

- the buttons are disabled, request can not be sent. The script is either not running or a different action has
 already been requested.

- the buttons are clickable and clicking them will request the corresponding action.

- the corresponding action has been requested. It is possible to cancel the request by clicking the button again.

- the script execution has been paused. Clicking the button
 button resumes script execution.

It is also possible to pin the request buttons directly to the main toolbar. By default, the buttons are
 accessible only from the AS drop-down menu to keep the main toolbar clutter-free.
 Pin the request buttons to the main toolbar by following the instructions below:

Right-click on the main toolbar area (next to the "AS" button) -> Customize Toolbar... -> Select area on the main toolbar (i.e. Left) -> Add.. ->
 Expand Plugins -> Expand
 AutoScript Browser -> Select Request Pause/Stop actions-> Click OK

The main toolbar with the two pinned buttons looks like this:

ght-click on the main toolbar area (next to the "AS" button) -> Customize Toolbar... -> Select area on the main toolbar (i.e. Left) -> Add.. ->
 Expand Plugins -> Expand
 AutoScript Browser -> Select Request Pause/Stop actions-> Click OK

The main toolbar with the two pinned buttons looks like this:
In the current version of the AutoScript plugin, it is not possible to send pause/stop requests for multiple
 running scripts in PyCharm.
 If multiple scripts are running in one instance of the PyCharm editor, the Request Pause/Stop buttons only work for
 the most recently executed script.

Python distribution

AutoScript comes bundled with the Python 3 distribution from
Enthought
.
 Alongside the 64-bit Python 3 interpreter, the distribution includes a selection of pre-installed packages for scientific computing,
 image processing, and data analysis.

Enthought Deployment Manager (EDM)

When the AutoScript product is installed, an initial Python environment with the name "AutoScript"
 is created. You can manage packages within this environment as well as create or remove new environments
 using the standard tooling provided by Enthought - the
Enthought Deployment Manager
 command
 line tool - "EDM". For more information about using the EDM tool, see the Enthought website online at

https://docs.enthought.com/edm
.

Please note that AutoScript installs its own version of EDM without registering it in the system path.
 This approach is intentionally taken to prevent interference with other EDM installations.
 To ensure smooth functionality, we recommend starting the Windows command prompt using the
AutoScript
 EDM Shell

shortcut available in the Start menu. By doing so, the command prompt will open with all the necessary
 environment
 variables pre-configured to work with the EDM shell provided by AutoScript.

The
Python package management
 section of the manual
 provides further details on how to install packages to environments.
 Additionally, it showcases the usage of the AutoScript

Package Manager
 UI tool,
 which allows you to work with packages without relying on the EDM command-line interface.

Python environment management

In this chapter, we elaborate on the methods for creating and removing virtual environments within the Python
 distribution included with AutoScript.

The recommended method for managing virtual environments is to use the

Enthought Deployment Manager
 (EDM) tool.
 It offers a variety of built-in functions tailored for this task.
 While other popular managers like
Venv, virtualenv, Pipenv
, or
Poetry
 exist, they may not
 consistently deliver reliable results across all scenarios when used with the Enthought-based Python distribution.

The AutoScript installation creates a default environment named
AutoScript
 that contains all necessary packages
 and some common scientific libraries. However, this environment is deleted and re-created with each AutoScript upgrade, so any
 additional packages or modifications are lost. Therefore, it is recommended to create a new environment for working with
 AutoScript.

The Python version of the environment cannot be changed after creation. If a Python upgrade is needed, a new environment
 must be created. The AutoScript Package Manager always creates environments with the current AutoScript Python version (3.11).

There are two options for managing environments:

AutoScript Package Manager
 (preferred method)

EDM command-line interface

1. AutoScript Package Manager

Example 1:
 Create a new environment "Test" and initialize it with AutoScript packages.

Launch the Package Manager from the Start menu
Thermo Scientific AutoScript

AutoScript Package Manager
.

On startup, the application scans the available and installed packages.
 The name of the active environment is displayed in the drop-down box
(1)
.

Click on the
Environment
 button
(2)
 and choose
Create Environment
.
 A dialog box opens.

Enter the name of the environment and click on the
Create
 button.
 The name of the environment must be unique, and it must be a valid file name supported by the file
 system.

Check the
'Initialize with AutoScript packages'
 checkbox to install AutoScript client packages
 and all their dependencies into the newly created environment. This process may take some time,
 as the packages are downloaded from the Internet.

The environment has been created and set active. Note that the environment is only set active for the
 Package Manager, it is not a system-wide setting.

Example 2:
 Remove the "Test" environment.

Activate the "Test" environment by selecting it in the drop-down box
(1)
.

Click on the
Environment
 button
(2)
 and choose
Remove Environment
.
 In the confirmation dialog, press
Yes
.

2. EDM command-line interface

Example 1:
 Create a new environment "Test" and initialize it with AutoScript packages. Follow these
 steps in the
AutoScript EDM Shell
 prompt:

Create the new environment:

edm env create Test --version 3.11

Activate the new environment:

edm shell -e Test

Initialize the environment with minimum mandatory dependencies of the AutoScript client packages:

edm install colorama numpy pillow_simd opencv_python matplotlib

Install the AutoScript client packages using pip. The AutoScript client packages are provided in the form of
 *.whl (wheel) packages.
 The files are placed in the product installation directory under

c:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript\PythonPackages
.

pip install "c:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript\PythonPackages\*.whl"

Example 2:
 Remove the "Test" environment.

Activate the "AutoScript" environment:

ges.
 The files are placed in the product installation directory under

c:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript\PythonPackages
.

pip install "c:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript\PythonPackages\*.whl"

Example 2:
 Remove the "Test" environment.

Activate the "AutoScript" environment:
edm shell -e AutoScript

Delete the "Test" environment:

edm env remove Test

Python Package Management

This chapter summarizes methods for installing, updating, or removing Python packages from virtual environments.
 We recommend starting with the chapter on Python distribution to gain a basic understanding of the Enthought
 Deployment Manager (EDM) tool.

There are three options for managing packages:

AutoScript Package Manager
 (preferred method)

EDM command-line interface

Pip command-line interface

All three options require an Internet connection to access the online packages repository, which can be either
 the Enthought deployment server (options 1 and 2) or PyPI (option 3).

Some Python packages may have additional hardware requirements, such as the presence of a graphics processor
 from a particular vendor, etc. Neither of the options checks whether these requirements are met and therefore
 whether the package will work correctly.

1. AutoScript Package Manager

The Package Manager serves as a GUI extension to the EDM command-line tool,
 providing a more user-friendly experience for package management.

Install a package example

To install the popular open source machine learning package
PyTorch
, follow these steps:

Launch the AutoScript Package Manager from the Start menu,
Thermo Scientific AutoScript TEM

>

AutoScript Package Manager
. On startup, the application scans the available and installed
 packages
 and displays them in the left and right panes.

Enter the name of the package "torch" in the search field above the left pane to limit the list of
 available packages to those containing "torch". Packages can be "filtered" by their license by clicking the

License
 button and choosing the desired license types. The
License
 options
 correspond to EDM's package repositories.
 Selecting a License displays packages inside EDM's repository of the selected license name.

When you select the package in the left pane, its available versions are displayed.
 Select the latest version and click the
"Install Selected Version"
 button.

A confirmation window will open with a summary of all changes to be made to the environment.
 The changes may include adding, upgrading, or downgrading multiple packages to satisfy dependencies of
 the installed package. Click
Yes
 when ready.

The package has been downloaded and installed. It now appears in the list of installed packages in the
 right pane.

Note:
 The License options change which repositories are available when
 listing/installing/upgrading packages. Each license group is
 a separate EDM repository. Consequently, upgrading a package that belongs to a disabled license group is not
 possible.

Update user environment

User-created environments are not automatically updated. To update AutoScript packages, select the
autoscript_client

package from the list of installed packages in the right pane and click
Update to Latest Version
.
 Note that AutoScript packages require a minimum Python version of 3.11, so upgrading them in an environment with an older Python version is not possible.

2. EDM command-line interface

Enthought Deployment Manager (EDM) is Enthought's environment and application manager with support for virtual
 environments. Full documentation for its command line interface is available online at

https://docs.enthought.com/edm
.

Examples

To list all installed packages in the "AutoScript" environment, open the
AutoScript EDM Shell

from the Start menu and enter the following:

edm list

pport for virtual
 environments. Full documentation for its command line interface is available online at

https://docs.enthought.com/edm
.

Examples

To list all installed packages in the "AutoScript" environment, open the
AutoScript EDM Shell

from the Start menu and enter the following:

edm list
To download the latest version of the
PyTorch
package from Enthought deployment server and
 install it to the AutoScript
 environment:

edm install torch

To create a new virtual environment "Experiment" based on Python 3.11 runtime and initialize it with the newest version of the package

NumPy
:

edm env create Experiment --version 3.11
edm install numpy -e Experiment

3. Pip command-line interface

To access packages that are not available on the Enthought deployment server but are present in the online PyPI
 repository, you can utilize the
pip
 package manager.

Combining packages from two separate repositories in a single environment poses potential risks.
 These include the possibility of installing packages with incomplete dependency trees or facing conflicts
 that could disrupt existing packages. It's important to note that EDM is not aware of packages installed via
 pip, and they won't be visible in the Package Manager tool.

Generally, it's recommended to avoid mixing Enthought and PyPI packages.

Example

To download and install the
HyperSpy
 package along with all its dependencies into the
 AutoScript environment, enter the following command in the AutoScript EDM Shell prompt:

pip install hyperspy

Python compatibility

The AutoScript client installation bundles AutoScript packages with a Python distribution. This may sometimes conflict with the
 existing Python environment (different distribution or version) on the user's machine. As a workaround, the client packages
 can be installed separately in a different Python environment.

Most parts of the AutoScript API will work with any Python version, except for the
EmdFile

structure. This structure provides functionality to open and modify EMD files in Python and depends on a pyd library that is compiled with a specific Python version.
 Therefore, this structure is not compatible with a different Python version.

Installing AutoScript packages to a different Python environment

AutoScript packages can be installed using the pip command line tool and a requirements file.
 Note that you may encounter package compatibility issues related to the current version of the dependencies, pip or python in your environment.
 We recommend following the steps below:

Make sure that the python environment's version is 3.11 or newer. AutoScript client packages don't support older Python versions.

Install the AutoScript client with the standard installation executable. This copies all AutoScript packages along with the
requirements.txt
 file
 to the following directory:

C:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript TEM\PythonPackages

The PythonPackages directory can be copied to a different location on the machine or to a different machine. The requirements file contains a complete
 list of required packages.

Open a command line and activate the Python environment where you want to install the AutoScript packages. If you are using conda, it could look something like this:

conda activate {environment-name}

Utilize pip to install both the packages and their dependencies using the requirements file:

pip install -r {path-to-requirements-file}

For example, to install the AutoScript TEM packages to a Python environment on the same machine, use the following command:

pip install -r "C:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript TEM\PythonPackages\requirements.txt"

This approach can be utilized to create a hybrid environment with packages of both AutoScript products (AutoScript and
 AutoScript TEM) installed at the same time. Note that you may encounter issues with displaying these packages in the
 AutoScript Package Manager in such hybrid environments.

To create such an environment, follow the steps below:

First, install both AutoScript products (AutoScript and AutoScript TEM) using the standard installation executables.
 Make sure you check the option to install the python client packages.

Next, to install a product's packages navigate to the directory where the packages are stored, typically:

AutoScript TEM:
C:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript TEM\PythonPackages

AutoScript:
C:\Program Files\Thermo Scientific AutoScript\PythonPackages

After that proceed as described in the previous example to install the packages to your environment.

Support

Software center web page

See the Software Center Web site
 (
https://www.fei-software-center.com/tem-apps/autoscript-for-tem/
)
 for information about the latest AutoScript versions and release notes. There you will also find sample scripts and an overview of the product's features.

How to report an issue

If you encounter a problem with the AutoScript TEM software, we encourage you to report it so that we can address it in future releases.
 Please provide as much detail as possible to help us understand and resolve the issue. To ensure efficient resolution, please follow these steps:

Open the AutoScript Diagnostic Report application from the Start menu and use it to create a zip file containing diagnostic information.

Describe the problem you are experiencing, including details such as error messages, unexpected behavior, and the frequency of the issue.

Include relevant parts of the script you are using to better illustrate the problem. Add screenshots if they help explain the issue visually.

Attach the files to an email and send it to the support contact email listed below.

If you are using remote scripting configuration, assess if the issue is related to the remote environment (server) or the local setup (client)
 and create the report there. If not sure, create diagnostic reports for both the server and client.

Support contacts

If you would like to contact the AutoScript TEM software development team directly for technical support, you can use the following
 email address:
autoscripttemsupport@thermofisher.com
.

This chapter shows examples of how to acquire images in AutoScript. It is assumed that the imports
 are done and the object 'microscope' has been connected. See

Getting Started

for details.

STEM Images

To acquire a STEM image from the HAADF detector of 1k x 1k pixels with a dwell time of 1 Âµs:

microscope.optics.optical_mode = OpticalMode.STEM
 haadf_image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_image(DetectorType.HAADF, 1024, 1e-6)

The image that is returned is an 'Adorned Image'. It contains both the image data and metadata.

The image can be saved as a TIFF file by calling
haadf_image.save(filename).

To acquire STEM images from multiple detectors at once,
acquire_stem_images()
 should be called
 which returns a list of images, in the same order as the list of detectors was specified in the first parameter:

images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_stem_images([DetectorType.HAADF, DetectorType.BF], 1024, 1e-6)

Camera images

To acquire a 4k image with an exposure time of 1s, you can use
acquire_camera_image()
 function:

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, 4096, 1.0)

Acquiring series

Image series can only be taken with cameras.
 The entire series must fit in memory and therefore the number of images (frames) is limited to a maximum of 64.

To acquire series of 32 4k images with the Ceta camera, with 2s exposure time each:

images = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_series(CameraType.BM_CETA, 4096, 2.0, 32)

This chapter shows how to
start
 an AutoScript client

and
connect
it to a microscope.

Before proceeding with code snippets below,
import AutoScript packages
 using the following code:

from autoscript_tem_microscope_client import TemMicroscopeClient
 from autoscript_tem_microscope_client.enumerations import *
 from autoscript_tem_microscope_client.structures import *

First,
create a microscope client
 object:

microscope = TemMicroscopeClient()

Connect the client
 to the AutoScript server running on the microscope computer with an IP address of
192.168.0.1
:

microscope.connect("192.168.0.1")

or
 connect the client
 to the server at the local computer:

microscope.connect("localhost")

By default, the client attempts to connect to the standard address
192.168.0.1
:

microscope.connect()

Connect the client
 to the server with certain host name, e.g.
MPC-TALOS-A2
:

microscope.connect("MPC-TALOS-A1")

To
disconnect
 the client:

microscope.disconnect()

This chapter shows how to
utilize vision capabilities
 of
AutoScript TEM Toolkit
 add-on.

Before proceeding with the code snippets listed below, initialize AutoScript TEM with the following code.
 Do not forget to set the server address or host name (parameters of the
connect()
 function) according to your environment.

from autoscript_tem_microscope_client import TemMicroscopeClient
 from autoscript_tem_microscope_client.enumerations import *
 from autoscript_tem_microscope_client.structures import *

microscope = TemMicroscopeClient()
 microscope.connect("localhost")

Import vision package from AutoScript Toolkit:

import autoscript_tem_toolkit.vision as vision_toolkit

Cut out image region
using
relative coordinates
.

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)

region = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, relative_center=[0.40, 0.40], relative_size=[0.20, 0.20])

ui_toolkit.plot_image(image)
 ui_toolkit.plot_image(region)

Cut out image region
 using
pixel coordinates
:

image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)

region1 = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, center=[140, 96], size=[120, 120])
 region2 = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, top_left=[80, 36], bottom_right=[200, 156])

ui_toolkit.plot_image(image)
 ui_toolkit.plot_image(region1)
 ui_toolkit.plot_image(region2)

Locate feature in the image
 using
default template matcher
 and inspect the result:

# Acquire a full frame image and cut out a template from it
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)
 template = vision_toolkit.cut_image(image, relative_center=[0.40, 0.40], relative_size=[0.20, 0.20])

# Locate feature from the template in the original image
 location = vision_toolkit.locate_feature(image, template)
 location.print_all_information()

ui_toolkit.plot_match(image, template, location.center_in_pixels)

Locate feature in the image
 using
specialized HOG (histogram of gradients) template matcher
 and inspect the result:

from autoscript_tem_toolkit.template_matchers import *

# Acquire a full frame image
 image = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_4096, 1)

# Acquire an image with a reduced size
 template = microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA, ImageSize.PRESET_256, 1)

# Locate feature from the template in the original image
 hog_matcher = HogMatcher(microscope)
 location = vision_toolkit.locate_feature(image, template, hog_matcher)
 location.print_all_information()

ui_toolkit.plot_match(image, template, location.center_in_pixels)

This chapter gives an introduction to controlling the detectors with AutoScript.
 For the complete reference of detector calls, see

detectors
 section of the
 reference manual.

Before proceeding with the following code snippets, make sure to
initialize
 AutoScript
.

Main screen

The main screen is the main fluorescent screen, which is also used by the SmartCam or Flucam.

The screen can be
inserted
,
retracted
 and the current can be

measured
.

To print the screen current in pA:

microscope.detectors.screen.insert()
 print(str(microscope.detectors.screen.measure_current() * 1E12) + " pA")

> 1149.4356973629922 pA

Camera detectors

Available camera detectors are exposed as a list of camera names. The names can be used in

acquisition calls

to select a camera.

print(microscope.detectors.camera_detectors)

> ['BM-Ceta', 'Flucam']

Scanning detectors

Available scanning detectors are exposed as a list of scanning detector names.

The example below show how to gain access to the BF-S
detector object
, set the

gain
 in dB and get the
collection angle range
:

print(microscope.detectors.scanning_detectors)

> ['BF-S', 'DF-S', 'HAADF']

bfs = microscope.detectors.get_scanning_detector("BF-S")
 bfs.gain = 0.5

print(bfs.collection_angle_limits)

> Limits(min=0,max=0.2)

EDS detectors

Available EDS detectors are exposed as a list of names.

available_detectors = microscope.detectors.eds_detectors
 print(available_detectors)

EELS detectors

Available EELS detectors are exposed as a list of names.

available_detectors = microscope.detectors.eels_detectors
 print(available_detectors)

This chapter provides an introduction to optics control with AutoScript. For the complete reference of optics
 calls, see the
Optics section

of the reference manual.

Magnification

TEM

In TEM mode,
magnifications
 and
camera lengths
 are exposed as lists in

optics.magnification
 and
optics.camera_length
.
 Magnifications and camera lengths have a
nominal
 value,
calibrated
 value,

rotation
 and a
label
.
 The label is a complete description of the camera length or magnification and can be used to set the projector
 directly.

print(microscope.optics.magnification.value.label)
 print(microscope.optics.magnification.value.calibrated)
 print(microscope.optics.magnification.value.nominal)
 print(microscope.optics.magnification.value.rotation)

> SA 8600 x
 > 9030.0
 > 8609.428
 > 4.71238898038469

To print
labels
 of all magnifications:

for mag in microscope.optics.magnification.available_values:
 print(mag.label)

> Mi 2050 x
 > Mi 2600 x
 > Mi 3300 x
 > SA 4300 x
 > SA 5500 x
 ...

To set the projector from a label:

microscope.optics.set_projector("SA 5500 x")

STEM

In STEM mode, the
 field of view
can be controlled. The displayed magnification is
 by convention 0.1 / field of view. To set a field of view of 0.5 Âµm (or 20 000 x):

microscope.optics.scan_field_of_view = 0.5e-6

If necessary, the field of view will be clipped to the valid range.

Focus

The focus object can be used to adjust the
focus
and
defocus
of the
 microscope.
 The (de)focus value is given in meters in STEM or imaging mode, and is unitless in diffraction mode.

Setting the focus to 0.0 is equivalent to setting the
eucentric focus
:

microscope.optics.focus.value = 0.0

You can get and set the defocus as well.

The function
reset_defocus()
 sets defocus to zero without changing the objective lens strength.

Apertures

The apertures can be controlled by interacting with the aperture mechanisms:

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.insert()

Depending on the type of microscope, not all mechanisms may be present. To list all apertures in a particular
 mechanism:

for aperture in microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.apertures:
 print(aperture.diameter)

> 10.0
 > 40.0
 > 200.0
 > 800.0

To select the 800 Âµm aperture, select number three from the list (counting from zero):

microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.aperture = microscope.optics.aperture_mechanisms.SA.apertures[3]

AutoScript allows you to pause or stop script execution at a specific script line. This gives the user the ability to pause the script before a critical moment occurs and check the state of the microscope to ensure that the experiment is running as expected. In addition, the script execution can be gracefully stopped in a controlled manner when it is safe to do so for data consistency and/or the condition of the microscope.

Basic requirements

Two actions are required for the pause/stop functionality to work:

1. Call an API function

There is a function for both pausing and stopping the script on a specific line. To perform the desired action, call the selected function from within the script.

# Check if a pause has been requested, if so pause the script execution
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.check_pause_requested()

# Check if a stop has been requested, if so gracefully stop the script execution
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.check_stop_requested()

2. Request Pause/Stop

The second action to take is to request a pause or stop of the script execution. If only the API function is called, but no request is made, the script execution is not affected in any way. The request can be made by clicking the appropriate button in either the
AutoScript Runner
 or the
PyCharm editor
 (see their manuals, section "Pause/Stop requests").

Example of usage

Scenario
 - We want to run an experiment on the microscope. Perform the first part of the experiment on the microscope and then pause the script to inspect the state of the microscope. Then resume execution and proceed to the second part of the experiment where we define
stop_condition
. If the
stop_condition
 becomes True (for example
microscope.optics.intensity == 0.0
) the script execution gracefully stops.

First we prepare the script:

from autoscript_tem_microscope_client import TemMicroscopeClient
 from autoscript_tem_microscope_client.enumerations import CameraType

microscope = TemMicroscopeClient()
 microscope.connect("localhost")

# Perform the first half of the experiment
 # ...

# Pause the script if a pause is requested and check the state of the microscope or the intermediate results of the experiment
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.check_pause_requested()

# Resume the script execution and perform the second part of the experiment
 # ...

for i in range 10:
 # Gracefully stop the execution if the tool gets to the state where the stop_condition is True and a stop is requested
 if (microscope.optics.intensity == 0.0):
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.check_stop_requested()

# Continue the experiment if the stop_condition was not met
 microscope.acquisition.acquire_camera_image(CameraType.BM_CETA,1024,1)

Then we choose either
AutoScript Runner
 or
PyCharm editor
 to run the script so we can create the pause/stop requests. In our example, we use
Runner
 to run the script and then click on request pause button. Once the script execution encounters the
check_pause_requested()
 line, the script will be paused as shown in the screenshot below.

Once paused, the script can be resumed by clicking the Resume button or stopped by clicking the Abort button. We resume the script and then click the request stop button to make our script stop when the
stop_condition
 is met.

If the
microscope.optics.intensity == 0.0
 in any iteration of the for loop and a stop is requested, the script execution is automatically stopped by throwing the KeyboardInterrupt exception.

the script and then click the request stop button to make our script stop when the
stop_condition
 is met.

If the
microscope.optics.intensity == 0.0
 in any iteration of the for loop and a stop is requested, the script execution is automatically stopped by throwing the KeyboardInterrupt exception.
Additional API functions

There are two other auxiliary functions that provide information about whether a particular action is currently requested. The following functions return a boolean value and have no effect on the script execution.

# Returns True if pause is requested, False otherwise
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.is_pause_requested

# Returns True if stop is requested, False otherwise
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.is_stop_requested

These additional functions can be used, for example, when
the script execution is too fast
 and there is not enough time to create a pause/stop request.

import time

# Sleep until pause is requested
 while not microscope.service.autoscript.client.is_pause_requested:
 time.sleep(0.1)

# Once the pause is requested, the loop is terminated and the script execution can be paused
 microscope.service.autoscript.client.check_pause_requested()

Remarks

In the current state, the start/stop functionality only works if the user actively creates the requests. Without the requests, the API functions have no effect on the script execution. This in turn means that if we do not need to stop or pause the script at some point, the script does not need to be modified. If the requests are not created, the script will execute exactly as if the API functions were not called.

For example, the user can insert multiple
check_pause_requested()
 lines into a script, but pause only at selected places (or not at all) on each run, as needed.

This chapter shows how to perform absolute or relative movements with the microscope stage.
 Movements can be performed in a normal or safe manner - resetting the tilts before the movement and restoring
 them after
 the movement to reduce the likelihood of pole contact.

Note: Distances are in meters and tilts are in radians.

Before proceeding with the following code snippets, make sure to
initialize
 AutoScript
.

Move to an
absolute position
 of 100 Âµm in the X axis and 213 Âµm in the Y axis. The Z,
 A and B axes are not changed:

microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(StagePosition(x=100e-6, y=213e-6))

Tilt
 to A = 30Â° and B = 4Â°

import math

p = StagePosition(a=math.radians(30), b=math.radians(4))
 microscope.specimen.stage.absolute_move(p)

Read
 the stage position and inspect it:

print(microscope.specimen.stage.position)

> StagePosition(x=0.000123, y=0.000456, z=2.34e-05, a=0.17453293)

Perform a
relative movement
 by -20 Âµm in the Z axis:

p = StagePosition(z=-20.0e-6)
 microscope.specimen.stage.relative_move(p)

Get the
holder type
:

print(microscope.specimen.stage.get_holder_type())

> DoubleTilt

In this part of the reference manual you can explore the AutoScript functions by means of short
example code snippets
.

AutoScript must first be initialized before it can be used in a Python script.
 The following chapters explain how to import AutoScript packages and start an AutoScript client:

Once initialized and connected to the microscope, the AutoScript client is ready to accept microscope control commands.
 Please select one of the following chapters to learn more about a specific function area:

AutoScript comes with an additional
 AutoScript TEM Toolkit
 package that provides image processing functions.
 In the following chapter you will find information about its capabilities:

Prior to proceeding with any code snippets below, make sure to
initialize AutoScript
.

The vacuum object is now used just to report the state of the vacuum system:

print(microscope.vacuum.state)

For controlling the column valves refer to

vacuum.column_valves

title: About AutoScript TEM
text:
About AutoScript TEM

AutoScript TEM
 is a comprehensive software package from Thermo Fisher Scientific designed to
 facilitate transmission electron microscope control and related data processing tasks
 within a Python 3 language environment.

The package encompasses the
Python 3 distribution

with an interpreter
 and a selection of widely used packages like
opencv
,
numpy
 or
scipy
.

Most notably, it incorporates a set of packages specifically tailored for Thermo Fisher Scientific electron
 microscope control.

These include
autoscript_tem_microscope_client
 with
 microscope control functions, and
autoscript_tem_toolkit
 with
 domain-specific data processing functions such as fine-tuned algorithms for computer vision.

Another part of the installation is
PyCharm
; a Python integrated
 development
 environment with AutoScript customizations to enhance the ease of writing and debugging scripts that leverage
 the AutoScript API.

AutoScript TEM adopts a client-server architecture, with communication handled over TCP/IP.
 This enables clients to connect both locally and remotely, supporting simultaneous connections for multiple
 clients.

This reference manual was generated for AutoScript TEM 1.15.0.484.

title: AdornedSpectrumImage
text:
Handle to the spectrum image result existing on the server.

Properties

Methods

save()

Transfers the spectrum image file to the client and saves it to disk.

Remarks

This object represents a spectrum image file that resides on the MPC disk. It can be sent to the client over the network
 using the
save()
 method.

The file is valid on the MPC for about 24 hours and is then removed.

title: AdornedSpectrumImage.save
text:
.

Transfers the spectrum image file to the client and saves it to disk.

Syntax

save(path)

Parameters

path

str

Path of the file to be saved.

Remarks

Transfers the acquired spectrum image to the client and saves it to the specified path. The only supported file extension is *.emd.

title: DetectorSegment
text:
Represents a single segment on a
ScanningDetector
.

Properties

detector_name

[Read only]
 Name of the detector containing this segment. Uses values from
DetectorType
.

gain

The gain of the segment. The unit depends on the detector type.

is_enabled

Whether this segment is currently enabled.

name

[Read only]
 Name of the segment. Uses values from
DetectorSegmentType
.

offset

The offset of the segment. The unit depends on the detector type.

title: EdsDetector
text:
Contains properties and enables control of a EDS detector.

Properties

Methods

Remarks

EDS detectors are uniquely identifiable by name. The enumeration
EdsDetectorType
 contains all supported EDS detectors.

title: EdsDetector.get_enabled_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of enabled segments.

Syntax

get_enabled_segments()

Return value

Remarks

This function can be used to create a list of segments for the spectrum acquisition function acquire_spectrum().
 after the segments have been selected for acquisition by calling
EdsDetector.set_enabled_segments()
.

Examples

Enable all segments on SuperX detector:

# Enable all segments on the SuperX detector (4 segments in total)
 super_x = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)
 super_x.set_enabled_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.ALL)

# 4 segments
 enabled_segments = super_x.get_enabled_segments()

See also

set_enabled_segments()

title: EdsDetector.get_segment
text:
.

Returns an object representing one detector segment. Enumeration
EdsDetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segment(segment_name)

Parameters

Return value

Remarks

Only single segment names are valid (i.e.
ALL

is not allowed).

See also

EdsDetector.get_segments()

title: EdsDetector.get_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of segments by their names. By default returns all available segments. Enumeration
EdsDetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segments()
get_segments(segment_names)

Parameters

segment_names

str | List[str]

Return value

Remarks

The parameter-less function returns all segments that are on the detector.

Segment name or a list of segment names can be passed, group segments are 'unpacked' and translated into their members
 (e.g.
ALL
 is translated into all available segments).
 The objects are returned in the same order as the names specified in the input list.

Examples

Enumerate all segments on the SuperX detector:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Get a list of segments on the detector and inspect their names
 segments = detector.get_segments() # 4 objects returned

# Same as
 # segments = detector.get_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.ALL)

for segment in segments:
 print(segment.name)

Get specified segments of the SuperX detector:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Get a list of specific segments
 segments = detector.get_segments([EdsDetectorType.SEGMENT1, EdsDetectorType.SEGMENT2]) # 2 objects returned

# Same as
 # inner_ring_segments = detector.get_segments(DetectorSegmentType.INNER_RING)

for segment in inner_ring_segments:
 print(segment.name)

See also

EdsDetector.get_segment()

EdsDetectorSegmentType

title: EdsDetector.set_enabled_segments
text:
.

Enables a given segment and disables all others. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
EdsDetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_enabled_segments(segment_name)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

Remarks

The function can act on a single segment or multiple segments. It accepts the input parameter in several forms:

A string representing a single segment, such as
"Segment1"
.

A string representing a group of segments, e.g.
"All"
.

A list of segment names, e.g.
["Segment1", "Segment2"]
.

In any case, it is recommended to use the
EdsDetectorSegmentType

enumeration instead of strings to avoid typos.

Examples

The following examples show several ways in which segments can be enabled:

# Get SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Enable all segments
 detector.set_enabled_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.ALL)

# Enable a single segment, disable all others
 detector.set_enabled_segments(EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)

# Enable the first two segments, disable all others
 detector.set_enabled_segments([EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1, EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT2])

It is also possible to access the
is_enabled
 property directly on the segment object.
 Note that this approach doesn't allow for batch processing (acting on multiple segments at once).

# Get the SuperX detector object
 detector = microscope.detectors.get_eds_detector(EdsDetectorType.SUPER_X)

# Enable its first segment
 segment1 = detector.get_segment(EdsDetectorSegmentType.SEGMENT1)
 segment1.is_enabled = True

See also

EdsDetectorSegment.is_enabled

title: ScanningDetector.get_segments
text:
.

Provides a list of segments by their names. By default returns all available segments. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

get_segments()
get_segments(segment_names)

Parameters

segment_names

str | List[str]

Return value

title: ScanningDetector
text:
Contains properties and enables control of a scanning (STEM) detector.

Properties

collection_angle_limits

[Read only]
 The range of the collection angles (annular detectors) in radians.

display_name

[Read only]
 The commercial name of the detector.

gain

The gain of the detector. The unit depends on the detector type.

gain_limits

[Read only]
 The range of valid gain values. The unit depends on the detector type.

insertion_state

[Read only]
 The insertion state of the detector. Maps to
DetectorInsertionState
 enumeration.

is_insertable

[Read only]
 Whether the detector can be inserted/retracted.

name

[Read only]
 The identifier of the detector.

offset

The offset of the detector. The unit depends on the detector type.

offset_limits

[Read only]
 The range of valid offset values. The unit depends on the detector type.

relative_gain

Gain value relative to its range. The range is from 0 to 1.

relative_offset

Offset value relative to its range. The range is from 0 to 1.

Methods

title: ScanningDetector.set_enabled_segments
text:
.

Enables a given segment and disables all others. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_enabled_segments(segment_name)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

title: ScanningDetector.set_segment_gain
text:
.

Sets gain on a given segment. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_segment_gain(segment_name, value)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

value

float

title: ScanningDetector.set_segment_offset
text:
.

Sets offset on a given segment. Accepts a single segment name or a list of segment names. Enumeration
DetectorSegmentType
 can be used.

Syntax

set_segment_offset(segment_name, value)

Parameters

segment_name

str | List[str]

value

float

title: AdornedImage
text:
Contains microscope image data along with metadata describing the state of the microscope under which the image was acquired.

Items

width

[Read only]
 int

The width of the image in pixels.

height

[Read only]
 int

The height of the image in pixels.

bit_depth

[Read only]
 int

Bit depth of the image data.

metadata

[Optional]

AdornedImageMetadata

Metadata containing information about the system setup at the time the image was captured.

data

[Read only]
 Numpy.ndarray

The data arranged either in 2D (for grayscale images) or 3D (for RGB images) numpy array.

encoding

[Read only]
 int

Encoding of the image. To explain this property use enumeration
ImageDataEncoding
.

checksum

[Read only]
 int

The checksum of the raw data.

thumbnail

[Read only]

AdornedImage

The thumbnail of the original image.

Methods

load()

Loads an image from a file. Supported formats: tiff, png, bmp.

save()

Saves the image to the specified path. Supported formats: tiff, png, bmp, gif.

title: Variant
text:
Defines an untyped variable. It can contain an integer, float, boolean or string value.

Items

Remarks

The Variant structure enables dynamic typing within the otherwise statically typed AutoScript API.

title: DriftCompensation
text:
Contains settings for the scan drift compensation.

Items

Remarks

The area of the drift measurement must fit into the defined dimensions of the scan size. The dimensions are defined
 by the size parameter of the acquisition or are defaulted as the maximum scan size of the system.

title: DriftCompensation.measurement_area
text:
.

Defines the measurement region for the drift compensation algorithm.

Data type

[Optional]

Region

Remarks

If the measurement region is not specified, the region of the acquisition is used instead. If the acquisition region is not
 specified, the compensation uses full FOV to measure the drift.

title: EdsSpectrumImageSettings
text:
Contains settings for EDS spectrum image acquisition.

Items

Remarks

This structure contains a set of settings used for the EDS spectrum image acquisition. Not all settings are intercompatible.
 A valid Settings structure must adhere to the following criteria:

dwell_time
,
shaping_time
,
 and
dispersion
 must be specified.

Either the
size
 or the
region
 must be specified.
 If both are specified, the region must fit into the size dimensions. If the size is not specified, the maximum scan size of the system is assumed.

region
 has to contain exactly one shape.

Either
scanning_detectors
 or
scanning_detector_segments

must be specified. If both are given, they cannot overlap. In other words, segments from a detector listed in scanning detectors can't be used.

eds_detector
 must be specified, configuring the EDS segments is optional.

Scan region

When a region is specified, both the scanning area and scanning time are reduced. This technique can be utilized for
 optimization purposes. Additionally, the resulting images will have a smaller size, as they will be cropped to match the
 specified region area.

title: EdsSpectrumImageSettings.save_eds_event_stream
text:
.

Defines whether EDS data events are to be saved. True by default.

Data type

[Optional]
 bool

Remarks

Disabling this option will prevent EDS data events from being stored individually in the output file.
 As a result, the file size is significantly reduced, allowing for faster transportation to the client.
 However, the data will only be accessible in a compressed format using proprietary compression algorithm.
 This means that only Velox can be used for further analysis of the acquired data. Additionally, certain analysis features,
 such as frame removal, will no longer be possible without the individual data events.

When EDS events are enabled, one summed spectrum per segment (stream) is also saved to the EMD file.

title: EdsSpectrumImageSettingsInternal
text:
Contains internal only settings for EDS spectrum image acquisition.

Items

Remarks

A valid Settings structure must adhere to the following criteria:

measurement_area
 must fit into the size dimensions. If the measurement area is not specified,
 the region is assumed instead.

number_of_frames
 must be greater than zero.

Setting the value of
save_all_stem_images
 to false
 deactivates the saving of all STEM images. If deactivated, only the last STEM frames for each detector/segment are saved.

Drift compensation

A
DriftCompensation
 structure can be used to enable frame-based
 drift compensation while the scan is running. If the structure is defined empty, all settings are considered default.
 A measurement area region can be used to set up drift compensation so that a specific FOV region is used for the shift measurements.
 In this case, it is recommended to use a region with high-contrast edges, as this increases the precision of the drift measurement algorithm.

title: OpticsAlignmentParameter
text:
Identifier of the optical alignment parameter.

Items

element

str

Optical function element.

parameter

[Optional]
 str

Optical element parameter.

Remarks

The structure is hierarchical, with the first level being the optical function element, and the second level being the parameter.

See also

optics.alignments

title: RunApertureCenteringSettings.check_only_mode
text:
.

Runs the procedure in CheckOnly mode to retrieve the alignment's execution state. Procedure is ready to run when the state is 'execute'. The Alignment is not executed in CheckOnly mode.

Data type

[Optional]

title: RunApertureCenteringSettings
text:
Contains settings for the aperture centering routine.

Items

aperture_mechanism_type

str

The type of the aperture mechanism to be centered. Uses values from
ApertureMechanismType
. Currently only C2 is supported.

maximum_allowed_distance

[Optional]
 float

The maximum allowed distance from the desired position in meters. Default value is 0.

aperture_names

[Optional]
 List[str]

A collection of apertures to be centered. When empty, only the currently selected aperture is centered.

maximum_iterations

[Optional]
 int

The maximum number of aperture-center iterations.

beam_diameter_change_allowed

[Optional]
 bool

If True, the alignment is allowed to change the beam's diameter.

stage_movement_allowed

[Optional]
 bool

If True, the alignment is allowed to move the stage.

check_only_mode

[Optional]
 bool

Runs the procedure in CheckOnly mode to retrieve the alignment's execution state. Procedure is ready to run when the state is 'execute'. The Alignment is not executed in CheckOnly mode.

title: RunBeamCenteringResults
text:
Contains result data from the beam centering routine.

Items

quality

str

Procedure's result quality. Uses values from
ResultQuality
.

off_center_distance

[Optional]
 float

The beam centering offset from final to target position in meters.

message

[Optional]
 str

Optional message regarding the result of the alignment.

title: RunBeamCenteringSettings
text:
Contains settings for the beam centering routine.

Items

maximum_allowed_distance

[Optional]
 float

The maximum allowed distance from the desired position in meters. Default value is 0.

target_position

Get:
[Optional]

Point
Set:
[Optional]

Point
 | list | tuple

Target position as a unitless 2D vector (x, y). (0, 0) is the centered position on the optical axis, (1, 1) is top right, (-1,-1) is bottom left.

maximum_iterations

[Optional]
 int

The maximum number of beam-center iterations.

beam_diameter_change_allowed

[Optional]
 bool

If True, the alignment is allowed to change the diameter of the beam. Beam diameter is restored to initial when the ResultQuality is 'Bad' or when execution fails.

stage_movement_allowed

[Optional]
 bool

If True, the alignment is allowed to move the stage. Stage position is restored to initial when the ResultQuality is 'Bad' or when execution fails.

check_only_mode

[Optional]
 bool

Runs the procedure in CheckOnly mode to retrieve the value of the aligned parameter. The Alignment is not executed in CheckOnly mode.

title: RunProbeCorrectorResults.probe_optimum_d50
text:
.

Theoretical optimum diameter of the electron probe that contains 50% of the intensity, calculated for a perfectly aligned system (no correctable aberrations remaining) [m]. This is the calculated limit of the intended resolution.

Data type

float

title: RunProbeCorrectorResults.probe_total_d50
text:
.

Measured diameter of the electron probe that contains 50% of the intensity [m]. This is the actual limit of the intended resolution. A well-tuned correctorâ will show a Total D50 that approaches the Optimum D50 value.

Data type

float

title: About the internal reference manual
text:
About the internal reference manual

The internal reference manual for AutoScript only covers the internal part of the API (internal parts of the API or types used in it).
 This part is for internal use only (or for selected customers) and is locked by the need for an internal license.

The complete public API manual is covered by the AutoScript reference manual.

This reference manual was generated for AutoScript TEM 1.15.0.484.
